Title: Comment Submitted by Mark Pickett
Comment:
This seems like a necessary rule for civilian water travel. Given some people's propensity for danger and curiosity during natural disasters, this rule would help to curb injuries and casualties during natural disasters. Considering the increasing number of natural disasters our coasts are expected to be subjected to in the coming years, this rule seems like a necessary measure to prevent more damage to property or human life. If enacted, this provision could save innumerable lives!
In years past, my hometown in South Georgia was ravaged by hurricanes and tornadoes, and one of the first things people want to do in the midst of natural destruction is drive around and see the damage first hand. Since this rule would prevent this sort of rubbernecking on South Floridian waterways, it would greatly benefit both civilians and first responders who are better trained for water travel and more justified in their use of the waterways.

Title: Comment Submitted by James Lingberg
Comment: Rather than a 250-yard transit zone, why can't we have a 50 yard restricted area on the Virginia side for recreational paddlers and other "slow movers" that prevents them from nearing the shoreline.  #1 - easier for users to estimate distances and accomplish the same goal.  We SUP all the time near Riley's and many times don't go far enough to exit the secure zone.  Largely just paddling within a couple hundred yard area and enjoying the weather and views.  To force older, slower recreational paddlers to immediately clear that zone is pretty burdensome and may effectively take them off the water.

Title: Comment Submitted by Cami Cutler
Comment: I think that having extra security surrounding could definaltye help protect the areas contents and features along with the people alongside. Although I am not a supporter of President Trump myself, I think that it's important for everyone to feel safe and be comfortable with their level of safety provided.

Title: Comment Submitted by Katie C.
Comment:
I support the permanent adoption of the interim rule that modifies the existing security zone that cover Potomac River waters next to Trump National Golf Club at Potomac Falls. 

Potomac River is utilized by members of the community and small local businesses and non-profit organizations. Members of the public access the river for fishing, boating, jet skiing, swimming, kayaking, and canoeing. There are even kayak and canoe training classes specifically for disabled veterans to assist them with rehabilitation. 
The previous rule entirely restricted access to the security zone that covered the waters next to Trump National Golf Club at Potomac Falls when persons protected by the U.S. Secret Service, such at President Trump, were on the Golf Club property. When the security zone would be enacted under these circumstances, the U.S. Coast Guard was required to enact the security zone, without notice, restricting access to the public who intended to use the river. 
This caused more than an inconvenience to the public. Businesses and non-profits providing recreational activities to the public were required, without notice, to stop business. This impacted the taxpayers enjoyment of the water, the consumers access to recreational activities, and cut short the summer camps that had been pre-paid. Further, when the restriction was enacted after individuals were on the water, it could prevent them from getting back to the docking station. This is not only inconvenient, but potentially dangerous as individuals often expect to spend a specified amount of time using rented equipment on the river. The previous security zone caused a danger to the public who were already on the rivers as boaters, who are generally without phones, food, medication, sun protection, or other necessities when on the water, did not have the notice to prepare for longer time on the river. 
This modified rule allows for a 250-yard transit lane, farthest from the course, to continue to be used when the security zone is enacted. As a result, it allows the camps to continue as scheduled, it does not economically impact the small businesses, and it does not leave recreational users stranded on the water unnecessarily. Further, the U.S. Secret Service protectees safety is not compromised. In short, the modified rule serves both the safety of high-level government officials as well as the recreational and safety interests of the general public.

It is not coincidental that the original rule was promulgated in 2017, the year President Trump took office. It is also not coincidental that this rule did not need to exist prior to the time that the President took office and elected to use a golf course, owned by his organization. Though this rule need not comply with Executive Order 13771 because it is not a significant regulation action, we should consider how future rules created specifically for high-level government officials to utilize personal businesses for recreation may begin to inundate those creating and enforcing rules, as well as further infringe on the interests of the public.
It is my personal opinion that government officials with security detail using their own personal businesses to enjoy recreational activities (i.e., not acting in an official business capacity) not on government property (e.g., Camp David, The White House), should not require the general public to pay for the officials recreational activities (through tax dollars) and also sacrifice their own recreational activities. Though my opinion may seem irrelevant, we should consider all of the businesses owned and/or accessed by high-level government officials and if this rule change causes a slippery slope. By that I mean, will there be additional regulations put into place by government agencies that further restrict the publics use of land or water in an effort to support the vacation and recreation activities of high-level government officials?

I also would implore the government to continue to consider how this particular security zone (and future zones) impact the First Amendment rights of citizens. It has been suggested that the security zone was enacted to prevent individuals from peacefully assembling and petitioning the government when high-level government officials were present at the Golf Club. While individuals are permitted to contact Geoffrey White or Dennis Holland, program managers for the U.S. Coast Guard and Department of Homeland Security, to coordinated protest activities, the public should have the right to appear on public property (without infringing on others rights) to protest without coordination, consistent with our fundamental, constitutional rights. 

Though the interim rule is a decent compromise that still allows for the security protection of high-level government officials and ensures public use of the waterway, issues of future rules and the First Amendment should continue to be considered.

Title: Comment Submitted by Edward Gertler
Comment:
I am a paddler who has been using this section of the river since the mid-1960s. The shortening of the security zone, a transit zone by the Maryland bank, and the establishment of a corridor to access the Potowmac Canal (aka George Washington Canal) and keep us away from Dam #2 should mostly address our needs. 

I would prefer that the transit zone be instead simply a corridor outside the security zone. I assume a transit zone was done to maintain control over traffic, if needed. I am not clear on what getting permission from the Captain of the Port entails. I am of the impression that it means being given the go-ahead by some on-site Coast Guard staff, not some advanced permit. To that end, I am concerned that the individual on duty is fully briefed on what this rule allows. I have had experiences involving access to previously restricted waters where the rule had changed, but officers with authority over access, did not know of or understand the change. Supporting this concern, I have been hearing some accounts by fellow boaters who have been stopped for no apparent reason.

I lived through the Kennedy assassination, so I fully understand the burden and need for protecting our president. I am confident that the proposed accommodation for river recreation will not compromise security.

Topics: Penalties,Reporting and Recordkeeping Requirements,Schools,Seamen
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Mark Grossetti
Comment:
For original, increase-in-scope, and raise of grade officer endorsements, I believe it is critically important that officers continue to be required to have recent service on vessels that have navigation and lifesaving/firefighting equipment that vessels ten or twenty years ago did not have.  There are constantly changing upgrades to EPIRBs, electronic charts, navigation tools, firefighting/lifesaving equipment, etc., that a modern professional mariner must be familiar with.  It is also especially critical for officers to have recent familiarization of vessel handling, seakeeping, and docking characteristics on appropriate sized vessels for which the mariner seeks license authority for.

The reasons for Congress to extend the recency requirement for uniformed service personnel to seven years is a matter of record.  However, the USCG has no statutory mandate to change the recency requirement for all mariners.  For the reasons stated above, it could be detrimental to public safety and the environment if the recency requirement is extended to seven years for all mariners and/or if the recency requirement were to be eliminated.

Note that the recency requirement was in effect even before the USCG licensing/manning regulations were overhauled and rewritten in the 1980s.  There was discussion during that rulemaking project regarding if the recency requirement should be kept or eliminated.  I have firsthand knowledge that the recency requirement was kept for the reasons stated in my first paragraph above.

It is especially important to note that the recency requirement has always contained the wording appropriate tonnage or horsepower, and the word appropriate should remain intact and even emphasized.  For example, to obtain a 500 GRT deck officer endorsement the regulations require a certain amount of sea service on vessels over 50 GRT.  The USCG National Maritime Center (NMC) evaluators are currently being trained to apply this tonnage part of the recency requirement for deck officer endorsements over 200 GRT.  I concur with this practice, as it would not be appropriate if the over-50 GRT service was many years ago.  If the recent service was on a vessel under 50 GRT, then the mariner would not have recent experience on a vessel of appropriate tonnage regarding vessel handling, navigation equipment, firefighting/navigation equipment, etc.

But I find it detrimental to public safety and the environment that the NMC is training evaluators to ignore the tonnage portion of the recency requirement for deck officer endorsements of 25 to 200 GRT (see attached page from NMC evaluator training).  This exception appears to be randomly interpreted and applied, as no such exception wording appears (or has ever appeared) in USCG regulations.  And note that the recency regulation is not in a subpart that applies exclusively to officer endorsements over 200 GRT.  The tonnage part of the recency requirement is just as important (if not more important) for officer endorsements up to 200 GRT.  NMC has been issuing 100 GRT officer endorsements to mariners who have no recent service on vessels of appropriate tonnage.  An example would be a 55 year old mariner applying for a 100 GRT master endorsement whose only service on vessels over 50 or over 33 GRT was as a deckhand when he was a teenager.  NMC would issue him a 100 GRT license allowing him to be the master of a 99 GRT T-boat even if his recent service was on a 16 bass boat.  Keeping in mind my opening paragraph, the safety/navigation equipment and handling characteristics of a 16 bass boat do not even compare to those of a 99 GRT T-boat.

The recency regulation does not apply to, and has never applied to, renewals of national officer endorsements.  That should remain unchanged, because sea service is not required to renew officer endorsements.  Sea service is only one of several renewal options, therefore sea service is not a renewal mandate.  Another renewal option is an open-book renewal exercise that the USCG mails to mariners to complete at their leisure using any available reference material.  With that being such an easy renewal option, I see no compelling reason to make the sea service renewal option more stringent by making the recency requirement applicable to renewals.

Mark Grossetti, LCDR, USCG (Retired), Marine Inspector

Title: Comment Submitted by Joseph Langjahr
Comment: With the elimination of the requirements of NFPA 10 there is no longer a standard for maintaining fixed fire extinguishing systems.  I suggest that you use language similar to that contained in proposed 175.310 and modify proposed 175.315(a) to read:  "(a) A fixed fire extinguishing system must be of a type approved or accepted under 46 CFR part 162 when it is installed and must be maintained in good and serviceable working condition."

Title: Comment Submitted by Larry Akins
Comment:
Moving recreational vessels away from commercial vessels requirements is a good change.

However fire extinguishers (both portable and fixed automatic for engine rooms) still need to be inspected at least annually.  
Without annual inspections the extinguisher could be inoperable with out the vessel owners knowledge.

As a manufacturer of fixed automatic engine/machinery room we recommend annual inspection of our extinguishers. Without a USCG requirement boat owners are put into a dangerous situation of having an extinguisher that is inoperable.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jim Brownlee
Comment:
I am a recreational boater and owner of a 40' powerboat that appears to be currently subject to these regulations.  I am in favor of this change.

Also, in researching the fire extinguisher requirements, the current publications do not clearly differentiate between requirements for USCG documented recreational vessels and state registered vessels, so it would be helpful to make any distinctions clear in published material.

Thank you to the Coast Guard for the protections that they provide to use.  Their service is greatly appreciated by those of us on the water.

Title: Comment Submitted by James Gunnoe
Comment: Recreational boaters should not be included in NFPA 10 as it applies to commercial vessels. We, as responsible recreational boaters, maintain all of our systems including firefighting equipment and fire detection sensors to include carbon monoxide and smoke. Our families and friends depend on our safety conscious practices.

Title: Comment Submitted by Peter Eikenberry
Comment: This would be a good move, and remove any confusion or ambiguity about Fire Extinguisher regulations on Recreational Boats. Regulations pertaining to recreational boats properly belong in 33 CFR.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mike Lauman
Comment:
This is one of those laws that, when it was written and put in force, inadvertently included a group of boaters ( recreational boaters}.  Now is the time to remove recreational boaters from this law.  

I recommend this law be passed.

Title: Comment Submitted by Derald Lary
Comment: I support this change.  The current regulation puts an undue burden on recreational boaters.  Even worse, it doesn't pass the giggle test.  The current regulation imposes a requirement that will not be followed by the boating public and therefore accomplishes nothing.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rusty Mayes, Carpe Diem Marine Specialties
Comment: I am in support of removing recreational vessel owners from the inspection and record keeping requirements of on board fire extinguishers. It puts an undue burden on those it was not intended to apply to and is unnecessary. I am in support of public education campaigns regarding all aspects of boating safety and having operational fire suppression equipment on board should be highlighted in these messages.

Title: Comment Submitted by Brad Arrington
Comment: I am in support of removing recreational vessel owners from the inspection and record keeping requirements of on board fire extinguishers. It puts an undue burden on those it was not intended to apply to and is unnecessary. I am in support of public education campaigns regarding all aspects of boating safety and having operational fire suppression equipment on board should be highlighted in these messages.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Easterday
Comment: Recreational boaters should not be included in NFPA 10 as it applies to commercial vessels. We, as responsible recreational boaters, maintain all of our systems including firefighting equipment and fire detection sensors to include carbon monoxide and smoke. Our families and friends depend on our safety conscious practices.

Title: Comment Submitted by Daniel Gassaway
Comment: Docket USCG-2018-0099 "Fire Protection for Recreational Vessels":In the proposed rule making, the Coast Guard proposes to further define the differences between fire suppression equipment on recreational boats and fire suppression equipment on commercial boats. A change in Federal law would apply to boaters in all 50 states and 6 territories and violations could result in penalties, tickets, insurance claims, court actions, property damage and/or personal injury and medical treatment. By definition, recreational boaters are more likely to be engaged in activities other than boating for most of their time, so are reliant on agencies such as the Coast Guard or fire department to provide reliable guidance in appropriate safety measures during their maritime past-time boating activities. While a change in the rules is proposed, this comment focuses on the ambiguous terms "good and serviceable" with the suggestion that these terms are not appropriate for recreational fire extinguishers and should be redefined or clarified during the rule making revision. Part 175 Sub part E 175.310 defines criteria such as weight, dates of service, pressure gauge reading, etc. that may define "good", but are not "serviceable" for disposable fire extinguishers commonly available and utilized by recreational boaters. In addition to modifying the terms "good and serviceable", recreational boaters should be aware that the different ignition sources on their boats may require different types and sizes of extinguishing or suppressing equipment. A novice attempt to fight a fire with the improper extinguisher may be more hazardous than donning their life jackets and abandoning ship. Regardless of the length or method of propulsion, many boats have electrical wiring (lights, horns, radios, etc.), cooking equipment (gasses, frying lard or shortening, microwaves, flames, etc), pyrotechnic signals (flares), recreational smoking devices, gas lanterns, generators, etc. that could possibly lead to accidental fires. In summary, the Coast Guard, for good reasons, proposes to further separate safety requirements on board pleasure craft and working vessels. I would suggest that the terms "good and serviceable" are not well-defined enough to apply to recreational boaters to be a law or enforceable policy. Adherence to the law would save life and property and non compliance with the law could lead to adverse enforcement actions and/or unacceptable risk to life and property in a recreational endeavor. With property and injury at stake, the policy should be modified to reflect current practices of disposable devices that are typically not serviceable. A review of available data for the type of fires encountered on boats (grease, electrical, paper, explosion, etc) may shed light on the type (A,B,C, etc) of equipment needed by the boater to be safe.  The burden of the rule revision is insignificant compared to the burden of a burned boat or personal injury due to improper equipment carriage and/or usage.

Title: Comment Submitted by Nicole Vasilaros, National Marine Manufacturers Association
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by John McDevitt
Comment:
Docket USCG-2019-009
In the last 15 years or so the Coast Guards role has changed greatly.  Homeland Security activities, among other things, have expanded the Coast Guards responsibilities outside recreational boating.

While I dont have a problem removing the record keeping requirements for portable fire extinguishers, I do believe the monthly inspection requirements for fire extinguishers should remain in place.  Brief, monthly inspections are not a burden.  Many recreational boats are not in use for the full 12 months of the year so a monthly inspection would only take place perhaps 6 or 8 times a year.

If a fire occurs in a building or on a boat at the dock, occupants have the reasonable safe opportunity for egress.  Most will flee and call for help.  But when a fire occurs on a boat that is out on the open water, occupants have a very limited opportunity for safe egress, and the availability, type, size, operation and number of fire extinguishers becomes a very critical part in the life safety process.

I have concerns that the limited and challenged Coast Guard resources have resulted in the Coast Guards diminished role in the recreational boating industry oversight.  This proposal will remove the fire extinguisher requirements for recreational boats from the monitored and managed 46CFR part 25.30 to the relatively unmonitored and unmanaged 33CFRPart 175.
Regardless of what the CFR eventually contains the existing fire extinguisher requirements, the information as published (updated in 2016) in the current 46CFR part 25.30 are not appropriate recommendations.  Fires and fire extinguishers have three different classifications  A - B and C.   An A fire is normal combustibles, wood, paper, fiberglass, cushions.   B fire is flammable and combustible liquids and a C fire is an electrical fire.  All three of these potential fires exist on a boat and therefore A-B-C capable fire extinguishers are necessary and should be installed.  The current Coast Guard fire extinguisher requirements only call for B capable fire extinguishers to be carried on the boat.  The recognized need for A and C capable fire extinguishers is ignored. 

In addition, the current Coast Guard requirements specify an inadequate number of extinguishers be carried on board.  For example, a 62 foot boat with a fixed engine room fire extinguishing system, requires only two 2lb (B type) extinguishers.  A 2 lb extinguisher contains about 6 to 8 seconds of fire fighting use.  Both the fire extinguisher type and quantity are inadequate as specified in the CFR.

There are a number of well intended state, local and private boating safety concerns who download, reprint and distribute these federal recreational vessel fire extinguisher requirements.  This information does not advise the boating public appropriately. 

Other regulatory groups participate in the safety standards process for recreational boats.  The American Boat and Yacht Council (ABYC) is the primary recreational boating standards organization in the United States.  The ABYC publishes over 50 standards and technical bulletins which are each maintained and updated every three to five years.  ABYC A-4 Fire Protection Equipment is one of these standards but A-4 has been reviewed only once in the last 11 years.  This is not an oversight.

The National Marine Manufacturers Association maintains the Boat and Yacht Certification Program.  This boat builder program contains about 50 ABYC Standards and Technical Bulletins that a builder must adhere to in order to achieve the NMMA Boat and Yacht Certification.  Conspicuous by its absence, the ABYC A-4 Standard is not part of the NMMA certification.  This too is not an oversight  this is a strategy that the ABYC and NMMA should explain.

The US Coast Guard publishes annually Boating Safety Statistics.  The number of reported recreational boat fire events are published in this report.  NFPA Vehicle Fire reports comprised of data taken from fire departments in the United States suggest that occurrence and losses from boat fires is approximately 6 or 7 times that of the USCG statistics.  
       
Summary
Move the portable fire extinguisher requirements for recreational vessels from 46 CFR to 33 CFR (with no measurable positive impact) as proposed.  Perhaps the requirement for recordkeeping should be excused but the multiple use of the word burden in the Federal Registers Request for Comment is not at all appropriate when it comes to the fire protection preparations for a recreational boat owner.  Inspecting an important piece of marine safety gear is not a burden for a prudent boat owner/operator. 
Please insure that the recreational boating community is protected with an appropriate, applicable and managed fire protection standard. 

John McDevitt
Marine Safety and Fire Protection
USCG Licensed Master  100 Tons  Since 1992
Accredited Marine Surveyor  SAMS
Chairman  NFPA 302 Watercraft

Title: Comment Submitted by Jack Seitzinger
Comment:
33 CFR Part 155                                                                                                                         15 AUG 19
[Docket No. USCG20180493]
The decision on the part of the USCG to allow for the use of a Letter of Designation (LOD) as Person in Charge(PIC) of fuel transfers on inspected vessels under this Part is commendable.  Particularly for the applicability to the maritime towing industry currently in transition from uninspected to inspected under Subchapter M.  We have been using an LOD process for PIC for many years. In procedures within our TSMS, the trainee (i.e. new hire deckhand) assist in all aspects of multiple vessel specific F/O transfers (refueling), L/O replenishment, etc., until that person has gained sufficient formal instruction from the operator [the Company] and [the Company] ensures their ability to safely and adequately carry out the duties and responsibilities of the PIC.  When the vessel Captain (PIC) makes this determination by review the individuals supervised refueling history, knowledge of vessel systems and emergency response procedures, the Captain designates that person as PIC by letter to the Company Designated Person and certifies this designation by endorsement to that letter. A Fuel Transfer Authorization Log is updated and the PIC Designation Letter is maintained onboard the vessel. This is a vessel specific Designation and not transferable between vessels. Upon reporting to a vessel new to the deckhand, the PIC vessel specific LOD process starts anew as we have no sister vessels.
Per request in this NPRM, there would be no additional cost incurred to this Company under this proposed Rule.
In the interim, I would encourage the USCG, having the authority under 46 U.S.C. 3703 (a)(4), to implement the LOD option via Policy Letter pending the effective date of this Rule.  Towing vessels are being certificated on a daily basis and the requirement (Policy Letter 01-17) for an MMC with endorsement of Tankerman Person In Charge (PIC) Restricted to Fuel Transfers on Towing Vessels remains for those vessels without tankerman required to mid-stream during refueling. This is currently burdensome and in my view, without qualitative research, may become detrimental to safely conducting refueling operations for the following reasons;
	Cost of Tankerman (PIC) Restricted to Fuel Transfers on Towing Vessels endorsement is $140 (MMC and evaluation). Since the Master, Mate, or Pilot most often must remain in the wheelhouse (i.e. maintaining position along a fuel flat), virtually all unlicensed deckhands assigned to vessel must have this endorsement.
	A licensed employee (with MMC) may demand higher pay rates with no additional gain in experience, training, or knowledge.
	Risk level may actually increases. Despite the fact that most companies have a PIC process as noted above, specific training requirements for this endorsement itself, per Policy Letter 01-17, are waived. 
	The Tankerman (PIC) Restricted to Fuel Transfers on Towing Vessels endorsement is not vessel specific and there is no regulatory requirement for such creating a likely potential for an endorsed deckhand new to a vessel whom conducts transfers while unfamiliar with vessel specific procedures.
v/r

Title: Comment Submitted by John Hughes
Comment:
I am opposed to this regulation.  As a crew member I see too many accidents and spills that are not reported from untrained crews. Companies do not want to pay trained and competent workers. I have sent several qualified personnel to apply but companies do not want to pay a meaningful wage. The pay offered to one person I sent to apply came out to be only a little over $8 an hour.   

In the last several years I have seen a serious decline in safety and an increase in small accidents. I have seen numerous small spills that have gone unreported and one large spill which was over 14000 gallons we were told by management was 14 gallons.  All of these were preventable and caused by either poor training,  negligence or bypassing safety requirements. 

In addition mariners are over worked. Companies have been pushing STCW watch hours and pushing crews to work 14hrs a day illegally. 

I have worked on commercial vessels for 20 years and I have never seen as many safetu problems as I have in the last few years.

Title: Comment Submitted by Horatio Nelson
Comment:
Caving to pressure from industry when there are mariners who have taken the time to get the required time and training in to qualify as a PIC and capitalize is unfair to them.  The recent GAP closure training is a similar situtio while shielding foreign mariners on foreign vessels from complying with that change while disqualifying US Mariners was a blatant coddling and protection of industry by forcing Americans to comply while allowing foreign mariners and companies to profit.

Additionally,  lowering standards so industry can cut costs is the standard response when a regulation hinders industry but keeps things safe for mariners, the environment safe.  Witness Deepwater Horizon where drilling in ultra-deepwater everywhere else in the world required two blow out preventers give one in the Gulf of Mexico.  The argument was industry knew what was safe and the government did not.  How did that work out? Also with the rise in accidents in the inland industry in the last few years, I feel, as a professional marine for 40 years and retired Coast Guard, this pandering to industry must stop and mariners, the environment need to take priority and if those costs for better safety passed on to the users.

I am decidely against the proposed rule making to relax PIC requirements...   There's no sustitution for required training and obtaining loads and discharges.  

"Letters of Designation" which relieve PIC's of gaining required training and/or Loads and Discharges is a faulty avenue which will bring more spills and accidents.  

There should be a PIC- Fueling certification for those who Bunker and Transfer aboard the smaller Uninsepcted Vessels who will be soon Certificated.  

ALso, there must be NO easy avenue where individuals could apply this to obtain Tankerman-PIC for service aboard Tank Vessels without advanced schooling...

Title: Comment Submitted by Andrew Samworth
Comment: I agree with the proposed rule.

Title: Comment Submitted by Thomas Ebner
Comment: Current fuel transfers requiring a Letter of Designation in lieu of PIC, keep scrutiny of training and oversight to a greater extend in regards to actual transfers the LOD enables to the particular vessel. Pacific Tugboat Service LODs are attached to the particular vessel they apply to.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
This proposed rule is opening a can of worms concerning mariners with/without PIC endorsements and what is required.  As a senior engineering officer aboard a Jones Act qualified product tanker, I see first hand the issues with Engineers and PIC requirements.  My employer requires all officers to maintain a Tankerman PIC endorsement, even Engineers with no involvement in the cargo transfer process.  The company maintains the belief that fuel/bunker transfers are equally dangerous, hence requiring the PIC endorsement.  99% of Engineers in my fleet could not knowledgably transfer cargo.  It's just not something we do.  Same as a Deck Officer could not repair the Main Engine.  

The requirements for when a Tankerman PIC endorsement is required should be revised.  A Tankerman Engineer endorsement is satisfactory, provided the classroom requirements focus on fuel/bunker transfers, which is ultimately what Engineers are primarily concered with.  Not every ship in the Jones Act fleet is an oil tanker, thus obtaining the Tankerman PIC endorsement is not possible.  A basic level of education - and the responsibilities involved - in the dangers of fuel/bunker processes is paramount.

As to persons working aboard the bunker barges, the above should equally apply.  If a ship is required to have a Tankerman endorsement (PIC or Engineer) maintain responsibility for the transfer, the person working aboard the transferring barge should also be endorsed and educated to the same level of care.  When I receive bunkers from a barge, I cannot control the actions of the barge, pumping the fuel on board my ship.  If an incident were to occur, the level of education and formal training would factor into the investigation when determining fault.  The barge personnel would then be absolved from certain aspects of the investigation based solely on their status of being lesser endorsed/educated.  Meanwhile, the PIC/Engineer endorsed person aboard the ship would bear the brunt of liability based on their endorsements/education, notwithstanding their inability to control the actions of the bunker barge and/or personnel.

Title: Comment Submitted by Eileen Stoll
Comment: I believe this is a reasonable change to the current rules in place regarding regulated navigations. The facility layout and types of vessels that come to the facility have changed, so the area in which they visit, should also change to keep up. The public input also went into this proposed rule, which further supports the claim that changes need to be made to ensure the safety of the operations.

Title: Comment Submitted by Unni Menon, Shell Trading US Co., Shipping & Maritime, Americas
Comment:
We welcome the opportunity to comment on the proposed revision of the RNA. The revision is timely due to the changes to the facility with LNG being exported rather than imported, and the possibility of small scale vessels calling to load at Elba Island.

While we agree with and welcome the proposed changes, we also notice that key sections of the RNA that apply only to large scale LNG Tankships, for which the RNA was intended, were inadvertently left unrevised. During the Public Meeting held on July 25, 2018, it was proposed that these paragraphs that are applicable only to large LNG Tankships be amended due to the possibility of smaller vessels in the future and all participants agreed.  We therefore propose that these paragraphs be amended as below:

Please note that the numbers of the paragraphs below are as in the original unrevised RNA, not as in the revised version, where d (3) (i) and d (3) (ii) are to be renumbered as d (2) (i) and d (2) (ii)

1.	Remove paragraph (d) (1) (iii) (D) that reads:
While transiting the RNA, LNG tankships carrying LNG in excess of heel, shall have a minimum of two escort towing vessels with a minimum of 100,000 pounds of bollard pull, 4,000 horsepower and capable of safely operating in the indirect mode. At least one of the towing vessels shall be FiFi Class 1 equipped.

2.	Remove paragraph d (3) (i) and d (3) (ii) that read:
(d) (3) (i)
An LNG tankship moored inside the LNG facility slip shall have two standby towing vessels with a minimum capacity of 100,000 pounds of bollard pull, 4,000 horsepower, and the ability to operate safely in the indirect mode. At least one of these towing vessels shall be FiFi Class 1 equipped. The standby towing vessels shall take appropriate action in an emergency.

(d) (3) (ii)
If two LNG tankships are moored inside the LNG facility slip, each vessel shall provide a standby towing vessel that is FiFi class 1 equipped with a minimum capacity of 100,000 pounds of bollard pull and 4,000 horsepower that is available to assist.




As an alternative, if the paragraphs are not to be removed, we then propose as a second preference,  that the text be amended as below to make clear that the requirements apply only to large scale LNG Tankships, as was intended in the old version of the RNA, but not clearly identified as such:

Please note that the numbers of the paragraphs below are as in the original unrevised RNA, not as in the revised version, where d (3) (i) and d (3) (ii)  would be renumbered as d (2) (i) and d (2) (ii)

(d) (1) (iii) (D)
While transiting the RNA, LNG tankships of cargo capacity over 120,000 m3, carrying LNG in excess of heel, shall have a minimum of two escort towing vessels with a minimum of 100,000 pounds of bollard pull, 4,000 horsepower and capable of safely operating in the indirect mode. At least one of the towing vessels shall be FiFi Class 1 equipped.

(d) (3) (i)
An LNG tankship of cargo capacity over 120,000 m3, moored inside the LNG facility slip shall have two standby towing vessels with a minimum capacity of 100,000 pounds of bollard pull, 4,000 horsepower, and the ability to operate safely in the indirect mode. At least one of these towing vessels shall be FiFi Class 1 equipped. The standby towing vessels shall take appropriate action in an emergency.

(d) (3) (ii)
If two LNG tankships of cargo capacity over 120,000 m3 are moored inside the LNG facility slip, each vessel shall provide a standby towing vessel that is FiFi class 1 equipped with a minimum capacity of 100,000 pounds of bollard pull and 4,000 horsepower that is available to assist.
______________________________________________________
Submitted by: Shell Trading US Co., Shipping & Maritime, Americas.

Title: Comment Submitted by David Missroon
Comment:
After review of the recent Notice of Proposed Rule Making for Elba LNG RNA, the Georgia Docking Pilots would like to offer comments.

There is concern with the following revision of the RNA;
Additionally, because transiting vessels can communicate and safely transit each other using VHF communications the Coast Guard has proposed removing various bridge watch requirements for vessels moored at the Southern LNG facility. These proposed changes are necessary to ensure the safety of persons and property within the RNA during LNG tankship operations and transfers after changes in the facility layout.

By removing the Docking Pilot as watch stander on the bridge of the LNG tankship one of the layers of safety is being eliminated. The Deck Officer will not have local knowledge of the Savannah River. The Deck Officer is not trained or proficient with communicating with inbound and outbound traffic, nor to give orders to the standby tugs.

There are numerous instances where tugs in the RNA have acted under the command of the Docking Pilots and incidents have been averted. This has been proven true when an LNG tanker in the slip was pulled off the dock by an inbound tanker. Further damages were diminished by the Docking Pilot and tugs. Immediately, the Docking Pilot properly positioned the tugs to safely maneuver the vessel back alongside. A ships Deck Officer does not have training or experience to coordinate this situation. This happened within a matter of minutes.

The Docking Pilot and River Pilot have been able to use their expertise collaboratively to avoid many issues. The Docking Pilot was able to assign the proper tugs to guard the LNG tanker or the passing vessel with no incidents.

To our knowledge, no other port has such a narrow channel where two post panamax vessels pass by a docked LNG tankship. Also, these large vessels are passing at low tide so they may safely pass under the Talmadge Bridge. During low water there is a greater chance of surge. Therefore, the proposed change of removing the bridge watch will not ensure the safety of persons and property.

All vessels in the Savannah River are to standby channels 13 and 16. More times than not, when the tugs or pilots are trying to speak to a docked vessel for communications you are unable to reach them. Once the vessel has been reached during an emergency, the vessels communications are generally difficult to understand.

Title: Comment Submitted by Darrell Smith
Comment:
I am responding to this expanded new survey with a different criteria. As a boater and a commuter crossing this specific bridge, a scheduled opening of 2x hour 24/7 days a week is reasonable compromise for both marine and vehicular traffic. Everyone can adjust their schedules accordingly to minimize any inconvenience. 
This is consistent with the other drawbridges in operation and this particular bridge should not be any different. 
Actual signage postings, visible from the water and the road, would be very useful to the uninformed.

Title: Comment Submitted by Tim Simos
Comment: It is good to see the scheduled openings on the half hour. The 20 minute schedule was too frequent, only giving motorists about 10 minutes between openings.  However, I can see where on busy weekends, every half hour may not be frequent enough.  I trust that the USCG will do the best for the majority.  The last thing that I would like to say is that more "No Wake" enforcement is needed in the Manatee zone in between the bridges.  Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by David Denton
Comment: The twice an hour opening of the drawbridge is fair for both motorists and boaters.  Many days while bridge is open traffic backs up onto Hwy 1.  By eliminating one opening on the three times an hour will alleviate one possible traffic mess per hour during busy traffic times.  I don't feel boaters are being unfairly delayed.  In times of heavy winds when the maneuverability of larger sailboats is questionable, then exceptions can be made.

Title: Comment Submitted by Gale Broderick
Comment: The new opening schedule on the hour and half hour, if needed, works very well. We know exactly how to plan our drives across the bridge and avoid the long long delays incurred when the bridge is open. Makes a lot of sense.

Title: Comment Submitted by Keith Pickering
Comment: The twice per hour on the 1/2 hour opening seems fair to automotive and maritime traffic at the bridge. This allows both maritime and automotive traffic that know of this accommodation to prepare for openings and potentially save much fuel and aggravation caused by the "on demand" openings previously used at this bridge. I think going away from the "on demand" openings on weekends of the pervious test period is a wise choice.

Title: Comment Submitted by Carol Schubert
Comment: I am pleased that the bridge schedule has been changed to twice an hour, seven days a week.  My sincere hope is that this  schedule will become permanent as it seems this is working well for everyone.

Title: Comment Submitted by Chris Fuller
Comment: Yesterday (Thursday) at 12:20 in the afternoon, we were coming south over the bridge in Ft. Pierce to get to N. Hutchinson Island.  The bridge tender opened the bridge for one boat (seemed to be a fishing boat) that immediately took a turn to the left and seemed to be going into a dock.  Apparently this bridge tender is familiar with this person and if this type of thing continues, the study on bridge openings will not be worth anything.  Yes, there are exceptions and that is acceptable, but opening the bridge for someone who may be an acquaintance isn't.  If it were an emergency I'm sure the boat would have been going a little faster, but it wasn't.

Title: Comment Submitted by Carol K.
Comment: Scheduled bridge openings twice an hour seven days a week are ideal and reasonable, especially considering that that is the norm in areas with more boat traffic than here. When I have appointments I am able to avoid being late by planning around the bridge opening. It is unfair for people who are working to be inconvenienced by boaters who have time to wait for a bridge to open. Furthermore, scheduled openings reduce air pollution and traffic snarls at the bridge and around Route 1.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Alton
Comment: Very much appreciate the new schedule opening only at top and bottom of hour, seven days a week.  Has made a noticeable difference in vehicular traffic flow on and off North Hutchinson Island.  Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by Glenn Burket
Comment: I appreciate the bridge being on the 1/2 hour schedule.  It works so much better for traffic to and from North Hutchinson Island.  Thank you and I hope it is made permanent

Title: Comment Submitted by Glenn Burket
Comment:
I think that opening the bridge on the half hour is enough.  Please continue this practice.

Glenn Burket

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I think it is working well ..can plan your appointments much better using this system ! I give it a thumbs up  !

Title: Comment Submitted by Michael Cason
Comment: please continue the on hour and 1/2 hour openings for the Ft Pierce bridge openings.  Make permanent.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joan Fusco
Comment:
Love the scheduled opening time.  Saves a lot of time knowing when to go over the bridge.  Please keep it this way.

Joan and Robert Fusco
5305 Montego Circle 
Hutchinson Island

Title: Comment Submitted by Edwin Santa
Comment: Please keep the opening of the drawbridge to the hour and half hour it make traveling on and off the island easy to plan travel and appointments.  thanks Ed Santa 5295 keel way N. Hutchenson Island Fl. 34949

Title: Comment Submitted by Roger Wroblewski
Comment:
Please retain the schedule of opening the bridge on the hour and half hour.
I find that it is easier to plan my trips to Fort Pierce with this schedule.

 Thank You
 Roger Wroblewski

Title: Comment Submitted by Janet Smith
Comment: As the end of the comment period is approaching, I am responding to the new temporary bridge schedule of twice an hour and seven days a week. The designated opening times is a great compromise for both vehicular traffic and boats.  This current schedule certainly seems to allow a reasonable and safe solution for both vehicles and boat to move safely and efficiently.  While commuting over this bridge several times a days, I personally have not observed a backup of boats waiting for passage. Please make this schedule permanent!

Title: Comment Submitted by Genevieve Giornesto
Comment: The 1/2 raising and lower, as needed seems to work well and I support making it permanent.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeri Bullock
Comment: As a year-round resident and property owner on North Hutchinson Island I appreciate the change to the drawbridge schedule.   Every 30 minutes  is much better than every 20 minutes.   I would like to see this schedule made permanent.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jean Downing
Comment: please keep the current (30 min,) schedule. I find it works well with less traffic backups.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeff Jones
Comment: I support the opening of the bridge at 1/2 hour intervals as needed.

Title: Comment Submitted by Linda Kilgallon
Comment: I recommend keeping the current schedule of opening on the half hour.  It is much improved. I am an owner on N. Hutchinson Island.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mary Jane Rekito
Comment: Please make the bridge opening schedule of opening every half hour as needed, a permanent schedule. Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by Elizabeth Flaherty
Comment: I would like to see the bridge open on the hour and half hour or less if no one is waiting.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I am in favor of keeping the schedule for the bridge to open every half hour. This has made it much easier to schedule coming and going from the island.

Title: Drawbridge Operation Regulation; Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway, Fort Pierce, FL

Title: Comment Submitted by Darrell Smith
Comment:
The proposed language contained in Regulation 117.261
(n) A1A North Causeway Bridge, mile 964.8 at Fort Pierce. The draw shall open on the hour and half-hour. is correctly delineated and should be implemented permanently. Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by Catherine Moon
Comment:
As I have repeatedly stated, each time you have asked for comments, I am very much in favor of twice-hourly bridge openings (when needed) on a 24/7 basis. It has been a godsend for those of us who live on North Hutchinson Island. 

In addition, it saves wear and tear on an admittedly aging bridge -- and I wouldn't be surprised if it helps St Lucie County businesses also, since the scheduled openings make it easier for people to get to Fort Pierce and south to shop instead of taking the northern route to Indian River County.

Please make the current experiment permanent!

Title: Comment Submitted by Patrick [Last name Unknown]
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment. As a boat owner who transits this area, I would like to see more frequent openings. I do not see a vehicle traffic flow study in the file but I will offer some time suggestions. Of course data would allow for more accurate timeframes. My issue with the infrequent openings 24/7 is waiting at times of the days for up to 30 minutes in a sailboat or large motor boat. Keep in mind that often there is significant tidal flow in the area that may hinder a vessel from staying safely in the channel.
I will make 2 proposals that I would hope you consider.
1) Restrict openings from 0700 - 0900  and 1600 - 1800 on weekdays. All other times would be on demand.
2) Restrict openings from 0700 -1900 during weekdays only.

Keep in mind that boat owners support area business. We often stop at the marina, eat in local restaurants and shop in near by stores or even visit the farmers market.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Alton
Comment: Am in support of making the current schedule for the bridge operation a permanent one.  By this, I mean opening only top and bottom of the hour, when needed, seven days a week.

Title: Comment Submitted by Carol Schubert
Comment: Am in total support of making the current schedule permanent.  Opening twice an hour, every day (only when needed) is more than adequate.  Must also respond to "Patrick"'s comment.  If boaters would learn the schedule and plan their leisure trips better, they wouldn't have to wait long at all.  After all, we motorists have been waiting on sailboats for years at this bridge.  Posting the schedule on marker buoys and A1A would also help inform all who pass under and over the bridge.  Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by j. Magnum
Comment:
Thank you for recognizing and accommodating the need for both vehicular and 
the boating traffic flow at our North Bridge. This proposed regulation in its final form is consistent 
with the intent of Federal Regulation 33 U.S.C. 499-Amendment 1988.   A 
schedule allows everyone to time a bridge opening with ones commute or 
marine navigation. This regulation is also consistent in practice with the other 
31 drawbridges on the Florida East Coast ICW. Actual  signage postings, 
visible from the water and the road, would be very helpful to the uninformed 
or inconvenienced. Please implement permanently without further delay.

Title: Comment Submitted by Darryl Daigle
Comment:
Document 2019-07519
The deviation test period was a great success. It worked really well for automobile and boat traffic. Knowing the time in advance when the bridge would open for boat traffic allowed everyone to plan ahead of time. Lines of vehicles waiting at the bridge were much shorter because most local residents knew it was best not to try to cross the bridge in the first 15 minutes of the hour. Boat traffic passing through the bridge on the hour were able to group together instead of just one boat at a time passing through when the bridge opened on demand. 

The on the hour opening reduced the chances an emergency vehicle (fire truck, ambulance) and medical first responders would be blocked from crossing the bridge by at least 50 to 60%. 

The lifespan of the bridge will be increased with the limited number of openings. This will save taxpayers added cost for repairs and replacement.

I believe that everyone will benefit if the deviation is made permanent. 

Please feel free to call me if I can be of any help to solve this major problem for many.

Title: Comment Submitted by Chester Cedars
Comment: In my capacity as the President of St. Martin Parish, I have discussed with the residents of the affected area the impact of the deviation test period.  Moreover, the Parish Council representative for that area has also had discourse with residents on this issue.  As such, St. Martin Parish embraces the proposition that the bridge be opened  as requested by the La. DOTD.  Indeed, we have been advised that the deviation test period was successful in reducing both boat and vehicular traffic congestion.

Title: Comment Submitted by Kimberly LeBlanc
Comment: We are in favor of extending the temporary deviation schedule.  We use the bridge for water and highway crossings.  Hourly opening for river traffic is a sensible alternative.  I do not feel that barge traffic or other large river vessels should be required to wait for an hourly bridge opening/closing.

Title: Comment Submitted by Linda Cooke
Comment:
I am asking that the Belle River bridge be opened for boat traffic only once an hour.  As a resident of Belle River, I often have to wait as much as 15 minutes on one side of the bridge to cross, complete my errands and then have to wait 15 minutes or more to get back across.  At certain times of the year this situation is even worse.  There is now a new boat launch on the south side of Hwy. 70 at the bridge so boaters can tie up, walk across the highway to the local bar with no need for the bridge to open..
   Vehicular traffic waiting for the bridge to open for them often stretched nearly a mile on Hwy. 70 toward Morgan City and an equal distance on Hwy. 70 coming from Pierre Part.  
   I personally have been late for meetings, and work sitting at the bridge waiting to cross.  I don't think sports boats should be able to cause the bridge to open at random.  If a set time is established everyone will be able to abide by the rules.  Linda Cooke

Comment:

Title: Comment Submitted by Matthew Flanders
Comment:
This proposition to close the drawbridge in Old Fort Bayou, MS for specified times throughout the half of the year should be allowed because it will provide further knowledge to the coast guard for travel times to be estimated. As well as this by closing this road you can see how essential the drawbridge road is to the city and understand what it is worth to them. Title: Extension of Comment Period for the Port Access Route Study: Alaskan Arctic Coast
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Cherie Jones Das
Comment:
I am thankful that the Coast Guard will be studying port access in Alaskan Artic Coast. It us my ardent hope that your study obtains scientific input inrather than simply allowing oil drilling and more vessel traffic that could result in oil spills in a very remote area that lacks infrastructure. 

I agree with the letter submitted by 
Audubon Alaska, Friends of the Earth International,Oceana, Ocean Conservancy, Pacific Environment, Pew Charitable Trusts, The Nature Conservancy, World Wildlife Fund that it is vitally important to "seek out and incorporate the best available information about the marine ecosystem.... seeking out and incorporating both science and traditional knowledge, and treating both knowledge systems with equal respect...[and]... Conduct[ing] a robust outreach effort that solicits and incorporates information from key stakeholder groups and satisfies the Coast Guards legal obligation to consult with Alaska Native federally recognized tribes and tribal organizations."

I also very much agree with them that you must "Consider the highly dynamic nature of the region, taking into account both seasonal and longer-term changes in sea ice, marine wildlife migrations and subsistence hunting practices. The Coast Guard should be mindful that the region is changing rapidly, and it may not be possible to accurately identify the time and location of future maritime activities. Vessel traffic mitigation measures should be flexible enough to account for this uncertainty." 

My fear is oil drilling and shipping vessel oil spills and fervently hope you will be extremely careful that any changes in the artic coastline be done to minimize any negative environmental impact.

Title: Comment Submitted by Suzanne Sorkin
Comment: Please do NOT study how to create port access routes in the remote Alaskan Arctic Coast region. This region has very limited infrastructure with which to cope with the inevitable vessel accident or, God forbid, an oil spill. People's lives and livelihoods depend on the pristine marine environment. Your studying how to put in port access and to drill the Alaskan Arctic Plain threatens those lives and livelihoods as well as the environment which will never recover.

Title: Comment Submitted by Summer Rife
Comment:
I think this is a great study. I appreciate the aspects of this study that will consider a. how increased shipping traffic will impact local communities and their ability to continue to utilize the land and ocean for subsistence living and b. studying the wildlife migration patters and how they may be affected by increased shipping traffic. Because the area is so isolated I suggest a strong focus on gathering information from and about the local populations in the geographical areas of interest. This information can shape future studies that will become important if shipping to these areas is, in fact, increased.

Relevant information pertaining to local communities that could benefit this and future studies could include:

Noting a communities medical and legal resources (how many doctors, hospitals, clinics, police stations, police officers, courthouses, judges, etc.) An increase in shipping traffic means an increase in people and likely an influx of potential sources of illness and disease (if a local community has been isolated from contact and exposure to diversity). An increase in traffic could also increase the need for law enforcement officers or the need for a City to update its civil and criminal code. A lot of these communities are already struggling with these issues. Noting the different capacities a community has and gathering this information while on the ground during this study could provide valuable information about a community's ability to grow and deal with an increase in increased shipping traffic.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joan Knipe
Comment: Because this region is remote and has little to no infrastructure means that the impacts of a serious vessel accident, especially an oil spill, could be devastating to the marine environment and the people whose lives and livelihoods depend on a healthy ocean. This idea needs to be stopped.  No study needed.  We the citizens have rights.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I OPPOSE STUDY OF A ROUTE TO A PORT. The remoteness of the region and lack of infrastructure means that the impacts of a serious vessel accident, especially an oil spill, could be devastating to the marine environment and the people whose lives and livelihoods depend on a healthy ocean.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mary O'Neill
Comment: Why are we going out of our way to destroy our natural resources.  Global warming has allowed this passage to be open because of mans usage of fossil fuels.  We need renewable energy and not transporting oil in an area that has no infrastructure to handle an oil spill or other toxic chemical that is being transported through this passage.

Title: Comment Submitted by Colonel Stephen Waller (retired)
Comment: I strongly oppose study of access to remote Alaska Arctic ports. As stewards of that pristine, irreplaceable environment, we must not take actions that would mess it up for future Americans. The precautionary principle tells us that access to Arctic ports will inevitably lead to unintended consequences, like oil spills, wrecks, and trash.  We must not act when we can be so sure that it will cause harm. We should act like adults, not creating any messes that our descendants will have to mitigate and clean up.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lesley Hopson, The Alaska Eskimo Whaling Commission
Comment: The Alaska Eskimo Whaling Commission respectfully requests for an extension for March 31, 2020. Due to distances and meeting or quorum requirement of village councils, and AEWC quarterly tri-annual meetings only.  AEWC is most interested in this project and ruling as it will have a long lasting impact on Arctic Coastal Villages subsistence resources and nutritional needs. On behalf of my Commissioners and Tribal Villages of Kaktovik, Nuiqsut, Utqiagvik, Wainwright, Pt. Lay, Pt. Hope, Kivalina, Wales, Little Diomede, Savoonga, and Gambell I hereby submit this request for this extension.

Title: Comment Submitted by Claire Gibson
Comment: There is no doubt the Alaskan Arctic Coastal area is changing due to such factors as a declining ice pack and increased maritime traffic. If the intent of the study is truly to promote safety on the waters, protect the rights of indigenous people and the unique and fragile ecosystems of the area, then I support it. It must be based on -and work from- the conclusions of rigorous scientific investigations and thorough consideration of the special populations of people and wildlife who inhabit that area, NOT on reaping the most economic gain (i.e. from oil exploration and drilling, mining, etc.). I am disheartened by the efforts of other US agencies, such as the EPA , the Dept. of the Interior, and the BLM, who have loosened environmental regulations and encroached on public lands and waterways, at great environmental expense, for the benefit of a few. This Alaskan Arctic Coastal area and its inhabitants must be treated with respect and care to best manage the variety of activities taking place while avoiding an ecological disaster.

Title: Extension of Comment Period for the Port Access Route Study: Alaskan Arctic Coast
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Timothy Schneider
Comment: With the amount of glacier ice that has melted in the past, it would be incredibly beneficial to the United States if we find another port access, especially something north of our country. With regards to what the study will measure, I do not think studying the port itself is fair when considering its future use during commerce. I believe the Coast Guard should also study the ecosystem of that region, and whether or not vessel commerce will harm ecosystems in the region. Even though much of the wildlife is suffering in the region, it is not fair to only look at vessel safety, but additional animal and wildlife safety, and precautions that vessels can take to not harm the ecosystem. Does vessel velocity and weight impact its surrounding ecosystem by additional melted ice? If so, there should be proper restrictions on what types of vessels travel through this passage, and in which style they are allowed to travel.

Title: Comment Submitted by Suzanne Sorkin
Comment: Please do NOT proceed with studying this area for potential vessels/routes/ports. This area is extremely remote and lacks infrastructure. If a serious vessel accident or, God forbid, an oil spill occurred here the results would be devastating. The people who live here and depend on a clean ocean for their livelihoods would never recover; nor would the marine life. Please stop looking at this area for vessel routes, ports, etc.

Title: Comment Submitted by Helen Yost
Comment:
WIRT Comments on Draft EA & Navigation Impacts of Proposed BNSF Railway Bridges in Sand Creek & Lake Pend Oreille, Idaho

I respectfully offer these written comments and accompanying documents on behalf of Wild Idaho Rising Tide (WIRT) and its over 3,200 climate activists, members, friends, supporters, and allies, including north Idaho and Lake Pend Oreille shoreline residents and other U.S. citizens owning property, working, and/or residing in or near Sandpoint and  Bonner County, Idaho, and the surrounding watershed, who would be impacted by Burlington Northern Santa Fe (BNSF) Railways proposed, Sandpoint Junction Connector project construction and operation of railroad bridges across Sand Creek and almost one mile over Lake Pend Oreille (project herein).  We object to BNSFs project invasion of the Pend Oreille lake and river ecosystem, and to its significant, direct and indirect, cumulative impacts on reasonable, public needs of navigation, as described in December 19, 2018, U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) public notices D13-PN05-18 and D13-PN06-18 and other, pertinent, government documents, and on the socioeconomic and environmental factors insufficiently identified and analyzed by the projects draft environmental assessment (EA) and 13 accompanying documents offering limited, public information via docket number USCG-2018-1085.  Furthermore, we incorporate by reference into these remarks the written and oral comments of WIRT and all persons and organizations raising concerns about this project, its draft EA, and associated documents and processes, through all local, state, and federal, public input avenues before, during, and after this USCG comment period on the projects draft EA.  (Comment continued in Attachment1)

Title: Comment Submitted by Matthew Nykiel on behalf of the Idaho Conservation League (2nd Comment)
Comment:
Please accept the comments and associated attachments on behalf of the Idaho Conservation League.

Regulations.gov will not allow us to upload Attachments B, C, and J because of file size limitations. We will submit these attachments via email to Steven Fischer, USCG District Bridge Manager to ensure they are part of the administrative record.

Thank you for your time and consideration. Please contact me if you have any questions about these comments.

Title: Duplicate Comment Submitted by Bradley DeAustin (0053)
Comment:
Lake Pend Oreille shelters bull trout, an endangered species, and Kamloops Rainbow Trout, Kokanee Salmon and a variety of warm water species.  Before our community commits itself to a rail bridge that will likely stand for 100 years, I think these vulnerable species deserves a harder look from the Coast Guard. For instance, how might a crude oil train derailment impact bull trout and other fish.  Not to mention impacts on our drinking water and recreational resources. Please complete an Environmental Impact Statement, so we have the benefit of more analysis and public participation to assess the potential impacts to this wonderful community. 

Regards, 
Bradley DeAustin

Title: Duplicate Comment Submitted by Sherry Ennis (0057)
Comment:
I was pretty disappointed to read the Coast Guard's environmental review of the second bridge proposal across Lake Pend Oreille. So many of the claims in that document are not supported with scientific analysis or reports. Take the claim that accident risk is a function of ton-miles of freight moved and number of miles traveled. Couldn't accident risk also come from train speed? Or inclement weather? Or whatever the train is carrying? Lake Pend Oreille deserves better than this. Please complete an Environmental Impact Statement. 

Regards, 
Sherry Ennis

Title: Duplicate Comment Submitted by Suzanne Troje (0056)
Comment:
Lots of people feel strongly about BNSF's proposal to add a second rail bridge across Lake Pend Oreille, and there are respectable arguments on both sides. But, one things that's certain is the level of public controversy is high. And, it's no wonder given the potential risks to an environment as vulnerable as Lake Pend Oreille's. Do the community to the favor of completing an Environmental Impact Statement, so that people on either side of the argument get the benefit of a thorough process and review. 

Regards, 
Suzanne Troje

Title: Duplicate MM2 Comment Submitted by Stephen Dault (0106)
Comment:
Lake Pend Oreille shelters bull trout, an endangered species. And, before our community commits itself to a rail bridge that will likely stand for 100 years, I think this vulnerable species deserves a harder look from the Coast Guard. For instance, how might a crude oil train derailment impact bull trout? Please complete an Environmental Impact Statement, so we have the benefit of more analysis and public participation to assess the potential impacts to this wonderful fish.

Additionally, other water life will be impacted by the addition of the bridge, which influences the birds in the area also. 

Regards, 
Stephen Dault

Title: Comment Submitted by Shelby Rognstad on behalf of the City of Sandpoint regarding the proposed BNSF Sandpoint Junction Connector Project
Comment:
Please accept the attached comments submitted on behalf of the City of Sandpoint regarding the proposed BNSF Sandpoint Junction Connector Project. We appreciate your careful consideration of these comments and strongly urge the United States Coast Guard (USCG) to prepare a thorough Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for this project.

Clean air, clean water, and good stewardship of taxpayer dollars has a significant impact on our current and future economic and social vitality as local jobs, tourism, and livability are all fueled by a healthy environment.  We strongly urge the USCG to require an EIS that includes comprehensive studies that will specifically addresses how the proposed BNSF Sandpoint Junction Connector Project will impact the residents and visitors of Sandpoint.


SANDPOINT MAYOR SHELBY ROGNSTAD
SANDPOINT CITY COUNCIL

Title: Comment Submitted by Ira Silverman
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I am writing in support of the proposed BNSF Railway Sandpoint Junction Connector Project across Lake Pend Oreille in North Idaho. Idaho and the entire Pacific Northwest region stand to gain immensely from this project. The environmental assessment (EA) done by the U.S Coast Guard (USCG) demonstrates a robust and comprehensive evaluation of potential impacts to the surrounding community and I applaud your leadership in moving this critical infrastructure project along in a timely fashion. 

The US has built a network of interstate highways encouraging the use of fuel inefficient trucking with no consideration on either the environment or development.  The BNSF has proposed the construction of a bridge to increase the use of environmentally friendly rail.  It would be a crime to retroactively deny them the ability to construct this bridge.

The proposal to build a second rail-bridge over the lake will further improve the rail system, which serves as the backbone of regional trade, supports countless industries, and benefits the economy throughout the Northwest and beyond. Just like adding an additional lane to a highway, this upgrade will expand the efficiency of freight moving across the region.

As defined in the EA, the improvements to rail infrastructure across Lake Pend Oreille are expected to relieve rail traffic congestion, reducing wait times for locomotives on the track and at important community crossings. Additionally, this increased rail capacity is expected to also reduce excess emissions from idling trains on the tracks or locomotives that need to power up to resume traveling. This project will not increase rail traffic. Any decreases or increases in rail volumes are determined by the market. What this project does do is ensure that current traffic levels can run more proficiently than it has in the past with just the single track.

The EA also concludes that the Sandpoint Junction Connector will not result in significant impacts to any elements of the human or natural environment. In fact, the company worked collaboratively with the USCG to identify important mitigation efforts for certain fish. BNSF is clearly invested in proactively ensuring this project will achieve full compliance with stringent environmental standards that will keep our community healthy and safe. 

The Pacific Northwest depends on an efficient rail network to safely deliver the goods that we use every single day. As the economy continues to grow and consumer demand rises, the need for increased rail investment follows right alongside this upward trend.

After reviewing the EA, I am confident that the Sandpoint Junction Connector project will be held to the highest of standards, have no significant impacts on our community and deserves swift approval. Plus, since private investment is funding 100 percent of this project, the community will benefit from this critical infrastructure upgrade without having to pay for it.

Thank you for your consideration of this important matter.

Sincerely,

Title: Comment Submitted by Ione Fine
Comment:
Dear Mr. Fischer,

 I'm concerned that the scope of the Coast Guard's environmental assessment, as drafted, is too limited to adequately inform rail line communities of all the impacts associated with this project, if it were approved.

As someone who lives along the coast, I have already had experience of BNSF carrying out inadequate environmental assessments which led to our community being seriously impacted without ever having having been included in an environmental review. 

We were fortunate, and the threat of legal action persuaded BNSF to make changes in where their trains idled  (since they were idling for hours 20 feet away from a heavily used community park!). However the whole situation could have been avoided if BNSF had carried out an adequate environmental review that included ALL of the affected communities.

The plan to go ahead with a second bridge will impact rural and urban communities throughout the Pacific Northwest. I am concerned that this is another example of inadequate environmental assessment.  The Coast Guard's environmental assessment, as currently drafted, without full input from the community, cannot adequately public weigh all the costs, benefits, and risks of BNSF's proposal.

I request the United States Coast Guard require and complete an Environmental Impact Statement, before any further decisions are issued on BNSF's proposal to construct a second rail bridge across Lake Pend Oreille.

Thank you,

Ione Fine

Title: Comment Submitted by William Remy
Comment:
Dear Mr. Fischer,

A project of this magnitude must not be rushed - we deserve all the facts. I'm concerned that the scope of the Coast Guard's environmental assessment, as drafted, is too limited to adequately inform rail line communities of all the impacts associated with this project, if it were approved. Furthermore, I'm concerned that many statements and claims in the environmental assessment, including claims that the project proposal will reduce rail congestion and vehicle delays, are not substantiated with studies or data. 

Rural and urban communities throughout the Pacific Northwest are impacted by how BNSF manages rail operations in "the Funnel" between Spokane, Washington and Sandpoint, Idaho - I'm worried that opening the Funnel with a second rail bridge will turn this rail line into a fire hose. More fluid rail operations may be in the corporate interests of a national rail company, but it may not be in the interest of local communities that could experience more frequent, vehicle-delaying, train traffic - some of which carry dangerous and hazardous materials that can pollute our environment and harm people. Even for communities outside Idaho, these impacts may be significant. But, the Coast Guard's environmental assessment, as currently drafted, fails to help the public weigh all the costs, benefits, and risks of BNSF's proposal.

If nothing else, I'm concerned about the risks to Lake Pend Oreille, the 5th deepest lake in the United States. Lake Pend Oreille is part of the ancestral homeland to indigenous people of the inland Pacific Northwest. The Lake is also an ecologically critical area for endangered bull trout and is a unique part of America's national heritage. I would be appalled if our federal government failed to provide the highest level of environmental review a place like this so clearly deserves.

I used to live in Bonner County,  ID, and worked in Sandpoint.  Any spillage on this lake would cause and environmental catastrophe.  This lake has a fragile ecosystem, which was seriously imperiled by decisions made by shortsighted people in the early part of the 20th Century.  However, over the past few decades, decisions have been made which have helped the lake and its native species, begin to recover.  A new railroad bridge to transport more oil and coal would likely increase the chances of an accident which would have serious repercussions on the Lake and the economy of the area.  Much of the economy is based on tourism around the Lake.  If that were disrupted, it would destroy an economy which struggles to survive.  That economy survives on the summer tourism that the Lake provides.  Many businesses make enough money during the summer months to allow them to get by during the winter months.  If an environmental catastrophe happened which polluted the Lake, many of these businesses would dry up and blow away.  This project is poor in conception and should be roundfiled!

I request the United States Coast Guard require and complete an Environmental Impact Statement, before any further decisions are issued on BNSF's proposal to construct a second rail bridge across Lake Pend Oreille.

Thank you,

Title: Comment Submitted by Mayme Trumble
Comment:
Dear Mr. Fischer,

I oppose tar sands oil coming on trains through my state of Oregon! Let's stop with this dirty, nasty export. Let countries fend for themselves in their energy needs. In the long run this is best. Stop transporting this stuff.

Thank you,
