Title: Comment Submitted by Charles Fox
Comment: It makes no sense to encourage the expansion of an industry like oil that is soon to be replaced by alternate industrial resources.  Rather than take yet another chance at ecological disaster, please consider, for all the sake of us all, telling those guys they'll have to limit their oil traffic and would do well to change their energy strategy to something less destructive than more rail distribution alternatives, such as the railroad bridges across Sand Creek, and more oil trains.

Title: Comment Submitted by Micheal Nicholson
Comment:
I believe we need to increase the capacity of our railroads. It is of great importance that we keep our economy moving, and when I see increases in rail activity, I see our economy moving in the right direction. I'm in favor of building a second bridge.

I also would like to see an increase in the amount of freight being transported by rail because of safety concerns. If we limit the amount of freight on rail, we increase the amount of freight on roads, where the incident of a crash is far higher and far more dangerous. 

With all that being said, Sandpoint is a major hub for rail activity with a North, West, East and South rail. Now is the time for the City of Sandpoint and Bonner County to demand more rail crossing arms, more safety features and better efficiency moving the trains through our area (which I believe is what the second bridge is being designed for). 

As for the likely-hood of a derailment, it's a risk/reward scenario. For the amount of the rail activity everyday in our country and across the globe, the percentage of a derailment is very low. Take the risk and mediate. Same with flying, the risk is low and the reward is high.

For Emergency Response, increase training and hire the proper people in case of a derailment. Burden should lie on the rail roads for this and not all on the local communities.

As for Socioeconomic & Cumulative Effects, I have no comment. Sounds like there is some great projects going on. Get the bridge built while the building time is good.

As for the Bull Trout, this is a straw argument and holds no water. Lake Pend Oreille is flush with Bull Trout and is one of the greatest bodies of water in the world for Bull Trout survival. A second bridge will have absolutely no bearing on that fish species. In fact the bridge will create more cover and shade for other species of desirable fish (Small & Largemouth Bass, Walleye, Pike, Perch and I would assume other trout species). 

As for Contaminant Mobilization, this is a small risk and measurements by qualified water testers should be conducted everyday during construction. If changes in heavy metal deposits are found, alter the consumption during that time and study how the construction can be done safer. My suspicion is that the heavy metal problems exist upstream of Lake Pend Oreille and that the bed of earth the second bridge will be using is under constant water movement with the lake turning into Pend Oreille River, will help dilute the water quick.

As for the Draft EA Errors, I don't see them as errors. I see them as common sense. Bring a large amount of people to an area for construction, those people are going to spend money in our community. As for more rail lines, less waits at crossing arms is a natural conclusion. 

This demand for a more stringent EIS is a stall tactic being used far too much in our country. All it will do is give a bunch of attorneys more paper work to come up with that wastes time and money. Not falling for the scare tactics. I say build the bridge. Get it done.

I support Lake Pend Oreille Waterkeeper & Idaho Conservation League because I love where I live and the lake I live on, but I don't support measures like this with a hidden agenda based on emotional thoughts and scare tactics.

Title: Comment Submitted by Sara Edlin-Marlowe
Comment:
Please do not put another railroad bridge in Sand point.
The creek  and lake are precious commodities
We don't want them spoiled by horrible leaks, spills, etc.
Sara Edlin-Marlowe

Title: Comment Submitted by Susan Brudnicki
Comment:
Dear US Coast Guard,
We already know what the potential impacts of a second rail bridge over Lake Pend Oreille would be. BNSF is a bad neighbor and doesnt clean up their derailment spills and no matter what they told us, their refueling depots leak into the ground and contaminate the groundwater. This has occurred over and over again all across the country. Please do not give this corporation the opportunity to destroy our pristine lake! The impacts of an oil spill on their rail line or near the lake would have devastating impacts upon the aquatic habitats and environments of the lake. Even the smallest probability of an accident is too big a risk to take. 

Please do not allow BNSF to build another bridge. The price we all are forced to pay is too high.

What would the impacts be if something happened and a lot of oil or other substances poured into the lake? Please provide a detailed Environmental Impact Statement to address these and other questions. Thank you.

Comment: Make sure your plans are guaranteed to not cause any environmental damage, ever. I seriously doubt you can do this, so build your rails in a more environmentally resilient place. Thank you

Title: Comment Submitted by Cheryl  Mitchell
Comment:
I understand that a second rail bridge over Pend Oreille Lake is being proposed by Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad. I oppose this for a variety of reasons, the first of which is public safety. In order to have a comprehensive assessment of this proposed project, it is essential to be able to predict the potential impacts of this bridge. The following questions must be answered before this project is approved:

1) What potential impact would a derailment have on the lake?
2) What information has been published about potential derailments over the Pend Oreille Lake? 
3) How many accidents have occurred on BNSF's rail lines across the nation?
4) What were the causes of the accidents?
5) What were the costs associated with the accidents?
6) Were there any deaths associated with the accidents?
7) Were there any property losses associated with the accidents?
8) Were there environmental conditions (water contamination, ground contamination, etc.) that were associated with the accidents?
9) What is the possibility that an accident could occur on BNSF's rail line near or over Lake Pend Oreille?
10) How would an oil spill effect aquatic habitat and environment of the Lake?

Please use an Environmental Impact Statement to help the public understand the potential impacts to Lake Pend Oreille and the surrounding environment more fully.

Title: Comment Submitted by Stan  Mrzygod
Comment: I think that this bridge is a bad idea. The environmental risks to the Pend Oreille River and Lake Pend Oreille are considerable. Already in recent memory rail grain cars and Boeing 737 fuselage assemblies have made their way to the river's banks so we know that railway accidents and failures do occur. Clean up on dry land is a nightmare. I cannot imagine the costs of an effective oil or coal clean up, or if it can even be accomplished thoroughly in a river or lake. There are still lingering effects in Alaska, the Gulf Coast and numerous other global locations from oil spills in oceans, lakes and rivers. Long term effects are still being felt in these areas. This is not a risk worth taking. NO to the bridge. Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Looking at the probabilities of a derailment by accumulating the data of how many derailments occur, looking at the environmental impacts of a derailment into Pend Oreille Lake, requiring a bond for funding the costs of a clean-up from any company transporting environmental toxins might all be warranted.  Thanks.

Thank you for your time.

Title: Comment Submitted by Tim & Sally Quirk

We understand that there is a 2nd proposed railroad bridge to cross Lake Pend Oreille. Tim & Sally Quirk
Spokane

Title: Comment Submitted by David Robinson
Comment:
Please accept these comments as compiledby Lake Pend Oreille Water Keeper, et al to the Draft Environmental Assessment
BNSF Sandpoint Junction Connector Project Proposal Summary of Deficiencies
As Identified by Lake Pend Oreille Waterkeeper & Idaho Conservation League
Acronyms and Definitions
BNSF  Burlington Northern Santa Fe railway company; project applicant
EA  Environmental Assessment; determines whether or not a federal action has the potential to cause significant environmental impacts
EIS  Environmental Impact Statement; the most thorough environmental review option under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1970; performed if the project will likely have significant environmental impacts
Why an Environmental Impact Statement is needed
An EIS is needed to thoroughly evaluate impacts to the human, economic, and environmental health. Most importantly, an EIS will identify measures to mitigate impacts resulting from the project and identify any remaining unavoidable and significant adverse impacts for the benefit of rail side communities and the health of Lake Pend Oreille.
Rail Traffic & Derailment Risk
 The EA does not consider how projected increases in rail traffic volumes in our area will increase the risk of a derailment.
 According to the Idaho Statewide Rail Plan from 2013, train volumes on Idahos network are projected to increase by 143% by 2040.
 BNSF transports hazardous materials, the majority of which is volatile Bakken crude oil.
 A derailment of hazardous materials within the vicinity of the Lake Pend Oreille basin could
have serious consequences to human and environmental health and our local economy.
 Projected train traffic volumes directly relate to an evaluation of spill risk and derailment.
A study under the EIS framework is needed to clarify what these projections are and how they might impact the amount of freight moved and number of rail miles traveled.
           

         Emergency Response
 The EA does not consider how the Lake Pend Oreille and Pend Oreille River Geographic Response Plan (GRP) will need to be modified to accommodate new challenges resulting from the project.
o One of the emergency response boat launch sites is Dog Beach.
o According to the EA, Dog Beach will have limited-to-no access during construction.
 To our knowledge, the GRP is the only framework currently available for emergency
responders to use when addressing a derailment over the lake.
 The EA does not consider the limitations of the GRP in its current state, nor how BNSF would mitigate those short-comings.
An EIS would bring to light how construction would limit implementation of the GRP under all scenarios and how such limitations could be amended. An EIS could inform community leaders and emergency responders of the shortcomings of the GRP and also enables the proposal of mitigation options.
Socioeconomic & Cumulative Effects
 The EA does not consider all potential socioeconomic costs, benefits, or cumulative effects (e.g., noise pollution from construction and existing train traffic) to rail side communities.
o e.g., in Sandpoint, at least three other major construction projects are proposed to occur during the project timeline. These include the City of Sandpoint (COS) Downtown Revitalization Project and various other COS master planning efforts, construction to replace and repair buildings affected by the February 2019 downtown fire, and a proposed Best Western remodel.

         Draft EA Errors
Several contradictions are made within the EA text, which highlight the need for a more thorough analysis. And, references needed to support assumptions or conclusions are often lacking or are all-together missing. Here are a few:
 While the EA asserts that the project need is based on the limited ability of existing infrastructure to handle the continued growth of freight rail service demands in the BNSF northern tier; it also asserts that the project would not increase or change rail traffic volumes on BNSFs northern tier...
 The EA eliminated socioeconomic impacts from review based on assumed minimal or no effect. Without citing any evidence, the EA asserts that the project would not impact businesses in the Sandpoint area. It also asserts that businesses within Sandpoint would temporarily benefit from the influx of economic activity during construction, yet no study of economic impacts is referenced.
An EIS would address these shortcomings by studying vehicle transportation and emergency response in the study area. An EIS would describe impacts on wait times at grade crossings and emergency response that could result from operation of the Proposed Action vs. the No-Action Alternative. Finally, an EIS would provide an opportunity to clarify, revise, or omit any EA statements that were made either without supporting evidence or with inappropriate inferences.

Title: Comment Submitted by Tracy Morgan
Comment:
In the following reports - Lake Pend Oreille has been clearly defined as a critical habitat for Bull Trout.

https://www.fws.gov/pacific/bulltrout/pdf/Justificationdocfinal.pdf
Lake Pend Orielle Critical Habitat Subunit
"The Lake Pend Oreille CHSU is essential to bull trout conservation because it is among the more secure and stable bull trout refugia across the range of the species and may provide a very important stronghold against potential extinction. Adfluvial bull trout comprise the predominant life history form present in the CHSU, and the CHSU has averaged over 800 bull trout redds annually over the last 10 years with a high of greater than 1,250 redds in recent years. Lake Pend Oreille not only provides important FMMO habitat to bull trout local populations in Lake Pend Oreille tributaries and Pend Oreille River tributaries but to bull trout populations in the Lower Clark Fork River CHSU. Bull trout local populations have not been recently
documented in Pend Oreille River tributaries that were known to be historically present. Reestablishing local populations that are broadly distributed throughout the CHSU has been identified as necessary for bull trout recovery (see Appendices 1 and 2 for more detailed information)."

In this report - it is clearly stated that Lake Pend Oreille is considered a 'core area' in the Bull Trout Recovery plane:
https://www.fws.gov/.../Bull_Trout.../Chapter3_Clark_Fork_River_Recovery_Unit_M...
"The goal of the bull trout recovery plan is to ensure the long-term
persistence of self-sustaining, complex, interacting groups of bull trout distributed throughout the species native range so that the species can be delisted."

Furthermore, migrations of Bull Trout to the Clark Fork critical habitat subunit or that of tributaries such as Trestle Creek, must be ensured through studying any interruption in the emigration of these species which have been known to migrate up to 150 miles.
https://www.fs.fed.us/rm/pubs_other/rmrs_2006_horan_d001.pdf

Given the construction of the bridge will disturb the sediments of the mouth of the Pend Oreille River and Sand Creek and impact turbidity downstream, a thorough study on the potential for disturbing habitat and spawning locations in the associated tributaries and at Lake Pend Oreille is necessary in order to comply with the endangered species act and all critical habitat requirements.

Title: Comment Submitted by Connie s Scherr
Comment:
My name is Connie Scherr.  I have lived in Bonner Co. for the last 41 years.  My husband  Les and I moved to the Sandpoint area while I was pregnant with our daughter who is now 41 years old and our 2 1/2 year old son who is now 43.

We started our own business, a insulation business and did all the energy programs backed by the government and in our area was run through Northern Lights.  I stayed home until our daughter started school and then started working for the Apline Ski shop owned by the original owner and his wife.  I helped manage the shop up at Schweitzer and in town.  Our family received  wonderful season pass discounts for me working at the ski shop and i got to ski free.  Because of Les's work, working with all the contractors in the area and me working at the ski shop and being active in our local church and in the schools we new everyone in town.  We could say Hi to everyone.  It was small town and we loved the fishing, skiing, hiking, working, gardening here.  We were never rich and sometimes strugled but life was good.

We originally moved here from Utah but I am originally from Minnesota and my husband from California.  I pushed for the life style I wanted our family to have, similar to mine in Minnesota, we got it here in Idaho, minus massvie mosquitos and humidity.

When we first came through in 1970 on our way to Canada for some classes my husband was taking we fell in love with the beauty and the pristine nature of this area. We are adamantly opposed to a double bridge across Lake Pend Oreille. We think it will be devastating to the area not only from an environmental perspective, what if theres a spell into the lake? But from the perspective of tourism, which this county relies heavily on. Noise, pollution, traffic. There are already too many trains as it is. We live very close to the tracks and this will adversely affect our lives, as well as many others.

My husband has read and studied up on the impacts this has on the enviroment, childrens lungs, brains, our lungs.  I could go on and on but I wont. I hope you have read this and I thank you if you have.  I am 68 years old, moved there when I was 28.  We love Sandpoint, how long have you lived in this area?  Why do you live here?

Please think carefully and I pray you try to stop this from going through.

We are adamantly opposed to this double tracking and will do whatever it takes to resist. Please listen to your hearts. You dont want this blood on your hands. Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Impacts of Project Construction on Sandpoint City Residents, Businesses, & Water Users
The current Sandpoint Connector Proposal Report fails to adequately address the impacts of the project on the City of Sandpoint, the navigational safety of boaters, and the access of residents to Lake Pend Oreille and the city water system. 
Construction of the bridges within Sandpoint and across Lake Pend Oreille will have a significant impact on quality of life for residents, businesses, visitors, boaters, and the tourism industry.  Over 12,000 visitors come to Sandpoint each year, pumping $43,000,000 into the local economy.  In summer, the focal point of this industry is Lake Pend Oreille and the City Beach. The Draft EA plan would include the building of two temporary and two permanent bridges each over Sand Creek and Lake Pend Oreille, as well as an overpass above Bridge Street, which is the access to City Beach. I will focus on three concerns:  navigational safety, noise from pile driving, and closure of Bridge Street.
a)	Navigational SafetyAt the end of the described project there would be two permanent bridges over Sand Creek and Lake Pend Oreille; during construction there would be an additional work bridge at each site. Drawings in Draft EA: Appendix A, Drawings 8 & 9, show that when the project is completed, the posts/piles on the two permanent bridges at Sand Creek and the posts/piles on the two permanent bridges on Lake Pend Oreille will NOT be aligned. In Appendix A and in the Draft Narrative we learn that the new bridge across the Lake will have navigational spans between posts/piles that are twice as wide as the spans on the old bridge (3.9). New bridge piers would align approximately with every other pier on the old bridge (3.9). (EA p. 58, hard copy). Thus, a boater navigating through the middle of two posts on the new bridge, would be directly and immediately confronted with a post on the old bridge, since the posts do not align. The two bridges would be only 50 feet apart (EA, p.20 hard copy), giving boaters only a few seconds to react, probably not enough time to even turn their boats. Boaters use this route at night with limited visibility. In addition, there is no description of how the working bridge posts would align with those of the two permanent bridges. This is a prescription for disaster. An EIS is needed to clarify and resolve this safety situation.
b)	NoiseThe most disruptive noise from construction will come from the driving of 1,100 bridge piles for the temporary and permanent bridges. For the Sand Creek Permanent Bridge located in the City, there will be 64 piles driven with 1,200 strikes per pile; for the Lake PO permanent bridge there would be 288 piles with 1,600 piles at 101-110 decibels. Fifty-five decibels is the measured ambient noise; 75 decibels is the threshold for human harm. The EA estimates that two piles per day can be driven. That means that up to 3,200 strikes at harmful hearing levels could be driven each day for up to a year and half for the Lake PO Bridge. Residents within a mile radius of the pile driving will experience the noise as louder than the ambient noise around them. In addition, humans are affected not only by the loudness of noise, but also by the pitch and frequency of noise, whose effects are not analyzed in this Draft. The Draft states that bubble curtains will be used to reduce noise; these work to reduce noise that is below the water; it is unclear how much noise is reduced. An EIS is needed to better assess the effects of noise on aquatic and shoreline creatures, human residents, and daily quality of life for the duration of the construction project. The EA provides numerous charts and narration related to construction noise (p. 17-24, 50, 57-58, 68, all hard copy)
c)	Bridge Street ClosureThe Bridge Street Closure is only casually mentioned as a possibility on EA pages 79 and 87, hard copy, yet even a temporary closure would cause critical disruption. (Page 11 also mentions potential of congestion in this area due to equipment). Bridge Street currently has parallel highway and railroad overpasses; the Draft EA proposes to add another rail overpass. Any closure of Bridge Street will cut off access to: City Beach, Sandpoint Water Treatment Plant, City Marina, RV Park, Seasons Condominiums, Best Western Inn, and the Amtrak station. Bridge Street narrows at the overpass, with concrete supports on either side; beyond that is water; there is no possible alternate route. The EA does not address the frequency, duration, or timing of Bridge Street closure(s), or its impact on the population, the vital tourist industry, public access to Lake Pend Oreille, access to the city water system, or residential access to homes. An EIS is needed to further assess the necessity for closure and what actions (if any) can be taken to maintain access.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Bull Trout References 

EA = Draft Environmental Assessment: BNSF Sandpoint Junction Connector Project, Bonner County 
	File Name =  USCG 1085-0014 Draft Environmental Assessment (PDF) [USCG]
Appendix F: Biological Assessment, Sandpoint Junction Connector Project

	 Bull Trout

In this EA and its Appendix F: Biological Impacts, BNSF concedes that fish within the construction impact zone may be harmed and killed, with damage to internal organs (Hard Copy, p.55), loss of food supply (Hard Copy, p.58), and an increase in predation (Hard Copy, p. 57). In the EA, these effects are dismissed as short term, only affecting a small portion of the bull trout population (Hard Copy, p.84), whose loss will be mitigated by the increase in bull trout population when the USACE Albeni Falls Dam Fish Passage Project on the Pend Oreille River is completed; however, fish from this Project would need to pass directly through the construction zone to migrate into Lake Pend Oreille.

Bull trout are designated as a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act. Bull trout migrate between Lake PO and its mountain creek and river tributaries to spawn and rear juveniles; thus the interface of rivers and creeks with the Lake are critical areas for survival.  A Critical Habitat Map (EA Hard Copy p. 54; Appendix F, Hard Copy p. 42) shows the migration patterns of fish between the PO River, Pack River, the Clark Fork River along with their myriad creeks and the northern area of Lake PO. The entire northern area of Lake Pend Oreille is designated as a Critical Habitat Area for the bull trout (Appendix F: Biological Assessment, Hard Copy p. 41).  Figure 6: Action Area Map (Appendix F, Hard Copy, p. 30) shows that the construction zone for the Sandpoint Connector Project overlaps the critical habitat zone of the bull trout (Figure 8: Bull Trout Threshold Distances (Appendix F, Hard Copy, p. 50).  This is corroborated by Appendix F: Construction Timing Table: BNSF Sandpoint Junction Connector: Key Element Construction Timing with Bull Trout Migration (PDF page 122), which shows that the construction project will interfere with fish migration (and thus, spawning as well) for a four-year period.
 
What the EA does not address is that the construction impact zone is in the critical migration paths of bull trout between the Pend River and Lake Pend Oreille. This includes fish currently entering the PO River from the East River Basin of the Priest River (EA, Hard Copy p. 53) and the migration path of fish that will be released from the Albeni Fish Passage Project. Bull trout also migrate in and out of Lake Pend Oreille from several rivers/creeks just to the east of the construction zone (Appendix F: Hard Copy p.40). Thus it appears that the construction impact zone may have a significant effect on the migrating bull trout population, their life cycle, and their ability to spawn and produce future generations; this issue is not addressed in the EA. An EIS is needed to address the overlap of the Bull Trout Critical Habitat Zone, the Bull Trout Migration Zone, and the Sandpoint Connector Construction Zone.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jerry White, Jr, Spokane Riverkeeper
Comment:
Dear Commandant J. Christopher Jaufmann

I am writing in response to the proposed Burlington Northern Santa Fe (BNSF) Bridge Construction Project. Docket ID: USCG-2018-1085

The Spokane Riverkeepers mission is to protect and restore the health of the Spokane River watershed and to defend our right to a clean Spokane River.  The Spokane Riverkeeper advocates for clean water and educates the public about issues that impact our waters. Citizens are encouraged to get involved and stay connected to their Spokane River, one of the regions most valuable natural assets.  

This proposed project would create numerous direct, indirect and cumulative impacts affecting the city of Sandpoint, Bonner County, Idaho, and for the down rail region in the Spokane Valley and the City of Spokane, Washington.  

1.	If constructed the proposed bridges would create potential impacts for species listed under the Endangered Species Act (ESA).  Bull trout are threatened under the ESA and no longer occupy much of their former range in the interior mountain west.  The proposed fill as well as the potential of trains spilling coal and/or oil under transport pose grave dangers to these already vulnerable populations of native fish in Lake Pend Oreille.  Additionally, when completed, the bridges will exacerbate the potential impacts to interior redband trout living in the Spokane River, down rail in the Spokane Valley.  These species of native trout are listed as a species if concern in Washington State and any spill of coal or oil could irreparably damage redband trout populations and their long term habitat.

2.	The traffic that is added to the down rail lines in Washington State have other cumulative impacts.  There is an increased risk of an oil spill over the Spokane Rathdrum Prairie Aquifer. It should be noted that a spill into Lake Pend Oreille could pose pollution to our Spokane Rathdrum Prairie aquifer which draws some water from Lake Pend Oreille.  Additionally, down rail, this aquifer would be vulnerable to spilled oil as it is very shallow, and protected only by a shallow lens of gravel in most places.  This aquifer has been designated by the  Environmental Protection Agency as a sole source of drinking water for the entire region.  A spill of Bakken crude oil or Alberta diluted bitumen oil could cause irreparable harm to this valuable community resource.  Increasing rail traffic only increases the odds of such an accident.

3.	Additionally, the increased traffic that this project would bring, puts our communities at risk. Spokane City fire fighting officials have identified deep concerns with the transportation of crude oil by rail through these down-rail communities.  An oil spill in down town Spokane that catches fire, presents a situation for which there is no immediate or appropriate response.  Many citizens would be put at risk in such a scenario.   Washington State has identified oil spilling by rail a significant potential in the permitting process for other west coast oil by rail projects.

Spokane Riverkeeper is asking that you evaluate BNSFs proposal as a serious risk to the environment region wide.  It also presents localized impacts to the areas under construction at Lake Pend Oreille.  As such, we request that a full Environmental Impact Statement be written and considered for this proposal and that it consider impacts to down rail environments and communities.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Jerry White, Jr.  Spokane Riverkeeper

Title: Comment Submitted by Gavin Cunningham
Comment:
I live close to this bridge and have fished under the river bridge many many times. When a train comes by the sound is deafening but the biggest problem I have is that debris is dropping, flying off the rail cars and splashing all around me. One must pull under the bridge to avoid being hit by  debris including coal chunks. The increased environmental regulations are ignored largely by BNSF. Oil cars are supposed to be pushed, not pulled for safety reasons and most often they are pulled. This is reflected by the fact that there is no engine noise coming from the rear locomotives most often. Night time transport is often used illegally for unsecured loads.

At the bridge location this river has significant navigational issues especially in high traffic summer months and during high volume water flows.The addition of another bridge will increase navigation hazards by multiples. It's not a matter of if an accident willl happen it is when and how often it will occur. 

A full environmental study impact statement should be required by BNSF to completely identify all hazards environmental and navigational so that proper risk management solutions and disaster preparedness. The second bridge is being built primarily to accommodate increased loads of highly toxic chemicals and further review is maximum.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bruce Grimm
Comment:
RE: USCG 2018-1085   FRN 2019-06241 Filed 03-29-2019 RIN 1625-AA09

The replacement of railroad bridges across Lake Pend Oreille and Sand Creek on the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad Company Hi-Line will relieve a known chokepoint in the mainline rail system and the project needs to proceed.  The rail traffic through Sandpoint, Idaho, the largest city in Bonner County, is an important economic stimulus and vital link for interstate and foreign commerce.  

The proposed steel and concrete structures over the water will be constructed with the most modern safety technology that can be applied to modern railroading.  This is in contrast to the existing 115-year old bridge which has been updated several times but is now obsolete.

Many federal, state and local laws and regulations govern and protect aquatic, riparian and terrestrial areas and the plants, animals and fishes that inhabit them.  Those relevant to this project include the Federal and State Endangered Species Acts, Fishery Management Acts, Marine Mammal Protections and Migratory Bird Treaty Acts.   

It is known that pollutants from rail roadbeds include fuel, oil, grease, industrial lubricants; heavy metals such as copper and zinc and land erosion.  The design and placement of the railroad bridge and advanced stormwater systems will help mitigate any pollutants released into the environment.

The plan to modernize this railroad bridge system makes good sense.  There is an urgent need for it to proceed to help ensure that the regions economy remains strong, a traffic chokepoint is relieved and modern controls are put in place through the design and build process so that various pollution concerns are addressed.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bonnie B.
Comment:
We are opposed to the 2nd rail line due to concerns that this would increase rail traffic which increases the likelihood of a derailment or spill.  Do you have a plan to fully mitigate any short- and long-term economic impact to this community as well as the physical damage to the environment should an accident occur?  There is already dust and exhaust going into the lake.

Unless you can guarantee there will not be an increase in rail traffic, and that you have a plan and reserved resources to deal with an accident, we are not in agreement to the second rail line. Additional rail traffic causes further polluting and putting our lake and surrounding environment at risk, to the cost of our community. There would be additional dust, exhaust, rail crossing delays, and noise.  Media coverage shows us how devastating a spill can be on the surrounding areas and the long-term impact of such an accident. This community depends on the natural beauty of the area for a significant portion of its economy and livelihood. Damage to the environment from rail traffic negates this pristine beauty.

Title: Comment Submitted by Suzanne Brooks
Comment: Build it. Adding another bridge will reduce congestion in the area and make for better flow of train traffic.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jennifer Brock Olson
Comment: An Environmental Impact Study is needed to properly assess the danger of a derailment to the community and the danger to threatened species. The project simply cannot proceed without a thorough understanding of consequences.

Please review and consider in your decisions the attached eight documents.

Helen Yost, MSEE
Wild Idaho Rising Tide
Sandpoint, Idaho

Title: Comment Submitted by Saptarshi Bhattacharya
Reason Withdrawn: Withheld â€“ travel agency advertisement, April 9, 2019.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bruce Grimm
Comment:
The South Park Bridge in Seattle, Washington is an important transportation link within the city for both vehicle and marine traffic.  The attendant bridge tender has a duty to ensure safety of both highway and marine traffic on this span over the Duwamish Waterway.

The proposal to not have a bridge tender at the span during certain hours is worrisome as it may lead to unintended consequences.  The current plan seems to contradict City of Seattle opening requirements that the bridge openings should be requested no less than one hour prior to the opening.  Emergency openings could very well be delayed.  Fog conditions may require an audible warning which may not be sounded if a bridge tender is not present.  In addition, the overnight bridge tender would immediately be on scene to report any accident or emergency on the four 11-foot driving lanes, sidewalks, bike lanes or to any bridge support.  A presence on the bridge also allows for a semblance of public safety or security.

Filling the bridge tender position from 11:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. should be explored as the public expects a certain predictability to operations so there is no question or ambiguity between bridge operations, vehicle and marine traffic.   Each bridge is unique, and this trunnion double leaf bascule bridge is no exception.  It seems that there should be qualified bridge tenders available to fill this position and maintain the public safety element or the benefits outweigh the costs if that is the real issue.  

Additional rule changes to 33 CFR 117.1041, in my opinion, are not in the public interest.

Comment: In respect to the safety of such events I think its highly recommendable to establish such a rule for the specific period of time during the race. Title: Comment Submitted by Chad Prejean, Houston Pilots
Comment:
See attached file(s).  

Dear Ma'am/Sir:  

This letter is in response to the Coast Guard's request for comments regarding the proposal to establish a 48 hour time limit in Anchorage area B in Bolivar Roads (Docket Number USCG 2019-0028).  

As background, the Houston Pilots is a voluntary association of 100 Texas state licensed ship Pilots.  Houston Pilots are commissioned by the Governor of the state of Texas to safeguard the interests of the State and citizens of Harris County by facilitating the safe and efficient movement of vessels in Texas state waters, which includes the Bolivar Roads anchorages and the Houston Ship Channel (HSC).  Last year the Houston Pilots safely conducted nearly 19,000 ship movements along the HSC and over 1600 movements to or from the Bolivar Roads anchorage.  

The Bolivar Roads anchorage is a relatively small and busy anchorage located inside the jetties leading to the ports of Houston, Galveston, and Texas City.  Time limits for vessels using these relatively low capacity anchorages ensure that vessels with the most pressing logistical and husbandry needs get access to the inshore anchorage in a safe, fair and predictable manner.  

For this reason, Houston Pilots supports the proposed rulemaking imposing time limitations on vessels using Anchorage B.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lloyd Mendonsa
Comment:
Dear Sirs 
BW LPG  would like to put on record that we support the establishment of a 48-hour time limit in Anchorage Area (B) in Bolivar Roads near Galveston, Texas to permit the safe transit of commerce and enhancement of navigational safety.

LPG Technical & Operations, Americas
BW LPG LLC

Title: Comment Submitted by C. Bisignano on behalf of Eric Johansson, Towboat and Harbor Carriers Association
Comment: Submitted on behalf of Mr. Johansson. D1 Bridge Branch.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joseph Clift
Comment:
This, "temporary deviation to test the proposed change to the bridge's operating schedule and determine whether a permanent change to the schedule is necessary to better balance the needs of marine and rail traffic," has been a great success, with no publicized vessel delays and no publicized train delays, a marked improvement from the year before the temporary deviation, when there were three separate occasions when tens of thousands of rail passengers were delayed due to bridge openings.

  The 180-day temporary deviation should be made permanent on September 9, 2019, the last day of the deviation period, this change better balancing the needs of marine and rail traffic. 

  Additionally the Coast Guard should investigate: 1) expanding the two-hour advance notice to 24 hours, as requested by Amtrak in its December 4, 2018 letter; and 2) eliminating the provision of bridge openings for tide restricted commercial vessels between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. and between 5 p.m. and 6 p.m.

  The hard statistics of extremely infrequent vessel traffic requiring the opening of Portal Bridge (an average of one vessel round trip every 6 weeks from January 2017 through October 2018) and the extremely frequent passage of trains and passengers across the bridge during the two five-hour periods of closure (267 of 455 daily trains and 149,000 of 197,000 daily one-way passengers, both in October 2017) provide the quantitative support for these changes.

Please refer to the following Railway Age op-ed article for more commentary on Portal Bridge: 
          https://www.railwayage.com/passenger/part-4-of-6-hey-wanna-buy-a-bridge/.

  Thank you for this opportunity to comment.

Title: Drawbridge Operation Regulation; Hackensack River, Little Snake Hill, NJ
Topics: Bridges
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by The Towboat and Harbor Carriers Association of New York/New Jersey
Organization Name: The Towboat and Harbor Carriers Association of New York/New Jersey
Comment: Submitted on behalf of Eric Johasson.

Title: Comment Submitted by David Alan, Lackawanna Coalition
Comment:
This comment is submitted for the Lackawanna Coalition,a not-for-profit organization of the State of New Jersey, in its capacity as a civic organization which advocates for better transit on the Morris & Essex, Montclair-Boonton and Gladstone Lines of New Jersey Transit, as well as connecting transit in the region comprising New York City and North and Central Jersey.  As a part of our purview, trans-Hudson transit mobility is important to us and to our constituents (NJ Transit's rail riders, as well as their towns and counties).  That includes continued smooth operation of trains over Portal Bridge, especially during peak-commuting hours, when large numbers of rail riders depend on NJ Transit and Amtrak trains to take them to their offices and other destinations in a timely manner.

The following material forms a portion the content of a letter sent concerning this matter, dated December 4, 2019.  We repeat parts of that content, to fit the limit of characters allowed, in this format.

DAVID PETER ALAN
Chair, Lackawanna Coalition



LACKAWANNA COALITION
Box 283
Millburn, N.J. 07041
www.lackawannacoalition.org


	The Lackawanna Coalition is a not-for-profit organization that advocates for better transit along the Morris & Essex, Montclair-Boonton and Gladstone rail lines of New Jersey Transit (NJT) and connecting transit.  Our constituents include thousands of commuters on the above-mentioned lines, as well as thousands more on the Northeast Corridor (NEC) and North Jersey Coast Line (NJCL) of NJT.

	We agree with the proposal for closing Portal Bridge as stated.

	However, we believe that the Coast Guard should strengthen this rule in the future, as follows:
	We call for the bridge closures during the specified periods to be mandatory and not permissive.
	We strenuously object to the proposed exception for draft-limited vessels.
	We call for a requirement of at least 24 hours' notice when any bridge opening is requested.
	We also call for the "closed" periods to start one hour earlier; at 4:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m.

	Rather than present extensive background information, we refer to and incorporate by reference an article entitled "Hey!  Wanna Buy a Bridge?" written by your commenter herein and posted on the web site of Railway Age, www.railwayage.com on June 18, 2019, as part of a series about Gateway.

	In that spirit, we endorse in principle the decision to keep Portal Bridge closed during the peak-commuting periods of 5:00 to 10:00 am and 3:00 to 8:00 pm on weekdays, so trains can pass freely over the bridge during those times.  We believe that the restriction at issue has substantially reduced the risk of significant delays to thousands of commuters and other riders into New York City, and some going in the other direction.  The results have been improved operations on the railroad, improved productivity for the riders, and consequent benefit to the regional economy.

	We strongly recommend in principle that the first sentence of proposed rule 117.723(e), which states: "The draw of the Amtrak Portal Bridge, mile 5.0, need not open for the passage of vessel traffic from 5:00 a.m. To 10:00 a.m. and from 3 p.m. to 8 p.m." be implemented, as modified here.  We also recommend that the phrase "need not open" should be changed to the stronger "shall not open" to indicate that allowing trains to pass freely during these periods is mandatory, rather than merely permissive.  

	We strongly object to the rest of the proposed rule, which would allow tide-restricted vessels to call for bridge openings between 7:00 and 8:00 in the morning and 5:00 and 6:00 in the afternoon.  We do not know how many such "tide-restricted vessels" are registered with the Coast Guard in the region, but we do know that bridge openings for maritime traffic occur only about once every six weeks on average.  We also know of no such openings during these hours within the period of March through September, 2019.  Other openings relate to maintenance and testing, which are never required when the railroad is busy.  In fact, those activities can be performed when railroad traffic is at its lowest level.  Without that objectionable loophole, even purported "tide-restricted vessels" would still have 14 hours available to call for bridge openings: five hours during the mid-day and nine hours during the evening and at night, and they would still have all day on week-ends.

	Therefore, the Lackawanna Coalition calls for continuation of the current policy of keeping Portal Bridge closed at least during the hours of 5 to 10 in the morning and 3 to 8 p.m.; preferably beginning one hour earleir.  We call for stronger language to make that policy mandatory, and we strongly object to the proposal to allow certain vessels priority during the peak of railroad commuting time, both in the morning and the late afternoon.  We also call for 24 hours' notice for any opening.

									Yours very sincerely,



									DAVID PETER ALAN
									Chair

Title: Comment Submitted by Joseph Clift
Comment:
I support the U.S. Coast Guard's (USCG) October 7, 2019 proposal to permanently change the Amtrak Portal Bridge Operating Regulations at 33 CFR 117.723(e) versus today's Regulations, but I suggest further changes as indicated below. I do not support the changes proposed by the Towboat and Harbor Carriers Association of N.Y./N.J.

The USCG's "temporary deviation to test the proposed change to the bridge's operating schedule and determine whether a permanent change to the schedule is necessary to better balance the needs of marine and rail traffic," was a great success, with no publicized vessel delays and no publicized train delays, a marked improvement from 2018, the year before the temporary deviation, when there were three separate occasions when tens of thousands of rail passengers were delayed due to bridge openings.

Quantitative support for the USCG's proposed changes in Portal Bridge Operating Regulations is very clear: extremely infrequent vessel traffic requiring the opening of Portal Bridge (an average of only one vessel round trip every 6 weeks from January 2017 through October 2018, reduced to less than half of that rate to one request an average of every 40 days from March 14, 2019 through July 12, 2019 - 9.125/year) and the extremely frequent passage of trains and passengers across the bridge during the two five-hour periods of closure (263 of 441 daily trains as of Thursday, December 5, 2019) and 149,000 of 197,000 daily one-way passengers (as of October 2017).

On an annual basis, the ratio of current passenger revenue train movements across Portal Bridge compared to recent bridge openings for vessel movements is more than 11,000 to one (103,400 trains/9.125 vessels=11,332).

Proposal:
I suggest that the USCG's proposed permanent Portal Bridge Operating Regulations at 33 CFR 117.723(e), be revised as follows: 
          The draw of the Amtrak Portal Bridge, mile 5.0, at Little Snake Hill, New Jersey, need not open for the passage of vessel traffic from 4 a.m. to 10 a.m. and from 2 p.m. to 8 p.m. At all other times the bridge shall open on signal if at least 48-hour advance notice is given.

If my suggested changes in the USCG's permanent Portal Bridge Operating Regulations are not incorporated at the end of this comment period, I request that a new test deviation period with opening regulations that incorporate all my suggested changes be initiated as soon as legally possible.

Going further:
In parallel with that new test deviation period, I propose that the USCG initiate an investigation into permanently leaving Portal Bridge closed, with an agreement by Amtrak to replace it with a new fixed bridge that increases vessel clearance at high tide from the current 23 feet to 25 feet. 

Thank you for this opportunity to comment.

Title: Comment Submitted by Frederick Mattera on behalf of Commercial Fisheries Center of RI
Comment:
COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CENTER OF RIS COMMENTS
TO THE US COAST GUARD FOR RI/MA WIND ENERGY
AREA ACCESS ROUTE (TRANSIT) STUDY
APRIL 14, 2019
COMMENTS IDENTIFIED BY DOCKET NUMBER:  USCG-2019-0131

THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO ENHANCE NAVIGATIONAL SAFETY BY EXAMINING EXISTING MARITIME TRANSITING ROUTES AND WATERWAY USES.  THE COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CENTER OF RI REPRESENTS ALL TYPES OF VESSELS (COMMERCIAL FISHING, CHARTER, RECREATIONAL & SAILING YACHTS) THAT WILL TRANSIT THROUGH THE RI/MA WEA.  OUR CONCERNS CENTER AROUND THE TRANSIT LANES LOCATION AND WIDTH OF THE LANES.  HUNDREDS OF FISHING VESSELS (TRAWLERS, LOBSTER & CRAB VESSELS, SCALLOPERS, GILLNETTERS & LONGLINERS) FROM RI, MA, CT, NY, WILL TRANSIT THROUGH THESE WEA TO THEIR TRADITIONAL FISHING GROUNDS AND RETURN TO THEIR HOME PORTS.  THEY WILL REQUIRE THE SHORTEST AND SAFEST TRANSIT LANES THROUGH THESE OFFSHORE WIND FARMS.  
CONCERNS AND NEEDS:
1.	NORTH & SOUTH, EAST & WEST AND NORTHWEST TO SOUTHEAST TRANSIT LANES.
2.	BEST OBSERVED DATA WOULD BE THE VMS TRACKING.  AIS IS LIMITED, IN TIME (2016 TO PRESENT) AND VESSELS 65 AND GREATER.
3.	TRANSIT LANE WORKSHOPS HAVE PRODUCED INDUSTRYS PREFERRED TRANSIT LANES VIA AN INDUSTRY CONSENSUS (MFWG).
4.	INDUSTRY HAS CONSISTENTLY DEMANDED 4-MILE-WIDE TRANSIT LANES TO NAVIGATE SAFELY.
5.	4-MILE-WIDE TRANSIT LANE RATIONALE; OSW DEVELOPERS REGARDLESS OF THE DETERMINED WIDTH WILL LINE THE EDGES WITH TURBINES, FORCING MOST PRUDENT NAVIGATOR TO ESTABLISH A  TO 1 MILE BUFFER FROM THE FENCE OF TURBINES.  AT 2 MILES THAT WILL HAVE THE ENTIRE FLEET NAVIGATING IN TWO-WAY TRAFFIC RIGHT DOWN THE MIDDLE OF THE TRANSIT LANE, HIGHLY SPECULATIVE AND DANGEROUS.  THE OFFSHORE FLEET THAT FISHES MULTIPLE DAYS (5-12 DAYS) NORMALLY LEAVES AND FISHES IN FAIR TO MARGINAL WEATHER CONDITIONS, BUT USUALLY IS DRIVEN HOME BY HEAVY WEATHER FORECAST AND CONDITIONS.  HIGH WINDS AND SEAS, LOW VISIBILITY, SNOW, TIDE CONDITIONS ARE CONTRIBUTING FACTORS ALONG WITH THE KNOWN BACK SCATTER FROM OUR RADARS, ARE ALL A RECEIPE FOR DISASTER IN A 2-MILE-WIDE TRANSIT LANE OR LESS.  ADDITIONALLY, ANY LOSS OF POWER AND OR PROPULSION, IMPEDING STEERAGE AND VESSEL MANUEVERABILITY AND LAYING DEAD IN THE WATER IN A 2-MILE-WIDE TRANSIT LANE WILL ONLY TAKE 10  30 MINUTES BEFORE COLLIDING WITH A TURBINE FOUNDATION CAUSING LOSS OF VESSEL AND LIVES.  AT 4 MILES WIDE THERE IS AMPLE TIME TO DEPLOY AN ANCHOR, TRAWL DOOR OR DREDGE TO SLOW THE VESSELS DRIFT UNTIL ASSISTANCE ARRIVES.  THE LIMITED TRANSIT LANES WILL FORCE A MYRIAD OF ALL CLASSES OF VESSELS TO TRANSIT THROUGH THESE DESIGNATED LANES, SMALL AND SAILING VESSELS WITH LIMITED LIGHTING AND VISIBILITY FOR THE LARGER VESSELS TO OBSERVE AND MOST DISCERNING ARE THE HIGH SPEED VESSELS MOTORING AT 20  40 KTS, UNBEKNOWST TO RULES OF THE ROAD (PORT  PORT) INCREASING THE POTENTIAL OF MORE COLLISION AT SEA, LASTLY, SHIPPING LANES HAVE BEEN DETERMINED BY THE USCG BASED ON SIZE, SPEED AND FREQUENCY OF TRAVEL WITH 4 MILE WIDE LANES THE ACCEPTABLE WIDTH.  ALTHOUGH, IN THE SHIPPING LANES THERE ARENT A FENCE OF TURBINES ALONG THAT 4 MILE PERIMETER, THERE IS FLEXIBILITY FOR ONCOMING TRAFFIC AND HEAVY WEATHER CONDITIONS, BUT NOT THROUGH AN OFFSHORE WIND FARM. 
6.	FISHING ACTIVITY (MOBILE & FIXED) MUST NOT BE PROHIBITED WITHIN TRANSIT LANES
7.	TRANSIT LANES MUST HAVE PROPER MARKINGS AND LIGHTING IN ORDER TO VISUALLY NAVIGATE A SAFE PASSAGE WAY
8.	NEW CHARTS WITH DETERMINED TRANSIT LANES HIGHLIGHTED MADE AVAILABLE FOR MARINERS
9.	US COAST GUARD SEARCH AND RESCUE, MEDEVACS, DEWATERING PUMP DELIVERY AND ANY ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE MUST ESTABLISH A NEW PROTOCOL IN THE WIND ENERGY AREAS.  MAY IMPEDE THE ABILITY FOR AT SEA ASSETS TO ASSIST, MOST NOTABLY HELO ACTIVITY DURING MARGINAL TO HEAVY WEATHER CONDITIONS AND LOW VISIBILITY.  THE HELO WILL NAVIGATE AT AN ALTITUDE OF 500 OR LESS, RIGHT AT THE LEVEL OF THE TURBINES, DEMANDING MULTIPLE SETS OF EYES TO AVOID A COLLISION.  THE ABILITY TO STOP THE TURBINES IN MINUTES HAS SOME MERIT, BUT, DOES BECOME ANOTHER HINDERANCE IN THEIR NAVIGATION WHICH MAY BECOME A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR IN ABORTING THE HELO AS AN ASSET.  
CORDIALLY,

FREDERICK J MATTERA
			                                                  EXCUTIVE DIRECTOR
					COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CENTER OF RI



Cc; Captain C.J. Glander, SNE Captain of the Port
      Edward G. LaBlanc

Title: Comment Submitted by Ben Goetsch, Empire Fisheries LLC
Comment:
My name is Ben Goetsch and I writing on behalf of Empire Fisheries and the other associated fishing companies that are based out of Stonington and New London, CT. We agree with and emphasize the comments you have already received from the Commercial Fisheries Center of RI. We specifically want to re-emphasize the importance of a 4-mile wide transit lane needed for the safe transit of all vessels and the likely limitations of USCG search and rescue within a Wind Energy Area. Transit lanes need to be specifically designed with these limitations in mind for the safety of all mariners that may transit the area.

However, and more importantly, we also want to ask that these transit lanes not only be studied and determined through the MARIPARS process but also that any USCG recommendations (including recommended transit lanes width, routes, and any other special considerations) that result from the MARIPARS be incorporated into rulemaking and the appropriate international agreements so that these important safety measures are binding on BOEM and on all future development within the wind energy area.  

In addition, we would also ask the USCG to tell BOEM to halt all development of all the Wind Energy Areas off the Atlantic coast (including the NY Bight) until all the PARS have been completed. To not have enforceable transit routes determined and mapped before the design and construction of any Wind Energy Area is simply putting the cart before the horse. The energy companies should have that information before they bid on a lease area and certainly before they submit a COP. Without that information, they are likely to waste time and resources pursuing designs that will inevitably endanger mariners. Transit lanes must be safely designed and routed in a comprehensive fashion so that they are all coordinated throughout the NE Lease Complex and beyond. The challenges of the NY BIght are similar to the NE complex and close enough geographically that any transit lanes in the NY Bight should also be coordinated with the lanes of the New England lease complex.

Title: Comment Submitted by Daniel Farnham
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing on behalf of the two New Bedford Massachusetts FV Gabby G and FV Megan Marie for the Coast Guards MA/RI wind energy area port access study. These vessels frequently navigate through WEA to get to fishing grounds to the south and east of the area.  As currently proposed the WEA will be a hazard to navigation and could end or curtail the ability of these vessels to utilize their traditional fishing grounds.  
Without the implementation of north/south and east/west transit lanes as proposed by RODA offshore vessels will not be able to safely get to port in a timely manner, which will reduce access to fishing opportunities.  One such example would be the Illex Squid fishery that takes place on the edge of the continental shelf south of the WEA.  Vessels in this fishery only have 48hours from when the first squid are caught until they must be offloaded in order prevent them from spoiling.  With a majority of these vessels offloading in New Bedford if there is not a direct line of transit to and from this port then the entire fishery could be wiped out.
 I must urge the Coast Guard to recommend that BOEM require the implementation of said transit lanes with a width of at least 3 nautical miles in order to ensure the safety of vessel traffic. The build out of the WEA will create natural bottlenecks and force all current vessel traffic into these lanes, thus transit lanes should be developed to allow a large number of vessels to safely navigate at the same time including in heavy seas and poor conditions, for that will be when they are needed most.  Vessel safety should be the number one priority in this project, with an adequate number, and width, of transit lanes to ensure this.  In addition all turbines should be required to have AIS and lighting equipment with backups to help aid in navigating these areas.  To emphasize this point there was recently an allision in Europe between a wind turbine service vessel and a turbine because the lighting equipment on the turbine had malfunctioned. 
	Id also like to request that the Coast Guard conduct a port access study for the proposed New York and New Jersey WEAs with the hope that transit lanes can be developed prior to the leasing of these areas.

Thank you for your time and consideration,

Daniel Farnham
Gabby G Fisheries Inc.
Blue Water Fisheries Inc.

Title: Comment Submitted by Marisa Desautel, Esq., Desautel Law on behalf of our clients, the Rhode Island Fishermen's Advisory Board (FAB)
Comment:
Please see the attached two letters, submitted by Desautel Law on behalf of our clients, the Rhode Island Fishermen's Advisory Board (FAB). The first letter comments on the FAB's objections to the Draft MARIPARS Report. The second letter conveys the FAB's adoption of opinions previously expressed by the Reliable Offshore Development Alliance (RODA) and the Commercial Fisheries Center of Rhode Island (CFCRI).

The FAB is an advisory body to the Rhode Island Coastal Resources Management Council, the agency in charge of the state's coastal management program under the Coastal Zone Management Act.

Title: Comment Submitted by Tim Roberts
Comment:
Offshore wind is critically needed to allow us to break the stranglehold of fossil fuels on our New England economy. This is urgent, and there are enormous climate, public health and economic benefits to our doing so, as quickly as we can. 

The commercial fishing industry is important, and/but quite small in Rhode Island. We should do what is reasonable to accommodate their needs, such as placing turbines in E-W arrays. I do not think we can afford to move from 1 mile to 4 mile spacing between them, and still produce the energy we need for our region. Models suggest our electricity needs are likely to double, as we electrify vehicles and home heating and water heating units.  

Thank you, and please let these offshore wind farms move forward. Our nation, region, and state need them.

Title: Comment Submitted by Francis McDonald, Massachusetts Maritime Academy

Title: Comment Submitted by James Violet
Comment:
The commercial fishing industry is facing enormous challenges in the development of the Mass/RI Wind Energy Area. Fishing in and safely navigating through the wind farm area is only possible with prudent one mile spacing of the wind turbines, in a uniform grid pattern. It is also imperative to include a series of 4 mile wide traffic separation lanes that will separate opposing streams of traffic, accommodate traditional fishing operations, and most importantly, allow for the Coast Guard to perform search and rescue operations
The current planning for the adjacent projects in the Mass/RI WEA have different turbine layouts, no traffic separation navigational corridors, and do not align the orientation of their wind turbines.  This will make it impossible to safely navigate through and fish in the wind farms
Based on data, annual vessel transit through the Mass/RI WEA range from 13,000 to 46,900. This does not include the many vessels that now transit the area without AIS or VMS units.  This is a average of 128 transits per day on average. However, during the summer months, this increased to 512 per day! During times of heavy fog or rain, transiting safely without a 4 mile wide traffic separation lane will be impossible. Wind farm developers have stated that due to navigational risks, vessels would likely go around the wind farm area. Coastal pilot associations have stated large shipping traffic as well as tug and barge traffic will avoid going through the wind farms and will go around, predominantly to the west of the wind farm area. This will create a funneling into a narrow area just west of the wind farm area, with the transit of as many of 500 vessels per day during the summer months. The passing of so many vessels in such a narrow zone, is inherently dangerous and creates a huge potential for collisions.  Requiring vessels to transit around the wind farm area is not practical, particularly for smaller vessels in adverse weather conditions such as gale or storms force winds and icing conditions. This might cause a more risky transit and require vessels transit further toward Open Ocean and away from safe haven. Economic impacts with the additional distance include increased fuel costs and loss of valuable fishing time.
My experience is that at certain times, there can be 20 to 40 squid, mackerel, butterfish, monkfish, and crab and lobster vessels fishing in or transiting through the wind farm area at any one time. There will also be an increase in vessel traffic associated with the construction of and support of the wind turbines.
Potential for interference with radar will also create difficult issues. False targets, multiple reflections, and ghost targets will all make transit through the wind farms dangerous.  The Coast Guard report recommends transiting through the wind farms in daylight and good weather. This comment shows the lack of understanding in commercial fishing operations. Typically, fishing vessels travel through the wind farm area at night, often following departing adverse weather conditions and heading back home through also at night during adverse weather conditions. If we waited for good weather, we would never go fishing.
The Coast Guard initiates about 10 search and rescue operations in the wind farm area per year. Wind and adverse weather conditions may not allow for USCG assets to go into the wind farm area. Search and rescue capabilities may also be impacted by the presence of the wind turbines, particularly USCG helicopters.
Finally, it is only reasonable, that the fishing industry which has operated in and adjacent to the wind farm area for over 100 years, can expect to safely navigate in and across the wind farm area. To do so, it is imperative to include multiple 4 mile Traffic Separation Schemes. This will accommodate opposing traffic streams of traffic, allow for course alterations to avoid collisions with other vessels or wind turbines. It will provide vessels with a safe path to pass when overtaking other vessels. It will also allow for mechanical failures and emergency stopping, possibly allowing vessels disabled time to anchor and avoid drifting into wind turbines. Finally, it should be expected to be able to safely navigate through wind farms, where freedom of movement is restricted by the very existence of the wind farms during unfavorable meteorological conditions. If no Traffic Separation lanes are included and the Coast Guard states we must travel through the wind farms at our own risk, it is entirely possible our insurance companies will not allow us to do so.

Sincerely,
James Violet
F/V Excalibur, Newport, Rhode Island

Title: Comment Submitted by Dennis Ingram
Comment:
The following are my comments on the wind farm turbine spacing.

I'm am writing you to express my concern with the Coast Guard recommendations.  The current plan has no allowance for shipping lanes, which in my option shows a disreguard for the safety of the men, woman and vessels that transit that area.   BOAM's own document suggest you take advantage of the fishermen, tug captains and shipping companies with years of experience transiting that area.  I can't find one that thinks it's a good idea to build these without properly planned shipping lanes. Can you?  Massachusetts Maritime Academy and the Pilot Association are recommending lanes.  Every fishing organization, fisherman and lay person with any knowledge of the area are recommending lanes.  Yet the Coast Guard recommendation is to transit through the wind farms in daylight and good weather.  That comment shows a lack of understanding of what happens in the real world of commercial fishing and shipping. I had to read it a couple of times to even believe what I was seeing.  Transiting through in any type of weather, gale force winds , heavy rain , snow or icing situations will be nearly impossible.  The amount of radar clutter and false echoes, never mind if there are other boats in the area will make it extremely difficult. You are asking smaller vessels that get caught in weather to not take a direct path to port, but to in best case run parallel to port and in some cases go further away from port.  For the life of me I can't understand an agency that is responsible for maintaining and enforcing navigational safety, would even consider not having shipping lanes in such a heavily congested wind farm?  We all have seen the data on the number of trips made in that area on a daily basis.

We are the last generation to look at open ocean, we all know these wind farms are going to change everything for better or worse.  I would encourage you to listen to the people who use and know that area, use some simple common sense.  Without those shipping lanes it's not a matter of if, but when will we have a major accident and may cost someone their life.
 

Respectfully,
Dennis Ingram
Newport, RI

Title: Comment Submitted by Rachel Dyer
Comment: I am writing this comment to commend the Coast Guard for a wonderfully thoughtful and prudent rule-making. I believe it is logical to close the area where the triathlon will be taking class in order to preserve life and limb. I also think it is prudent to only allow vessels that have been approved by the Captain of Port. I think it would be wise if only the most necessary vessels were allowed to pass and they had to follow some temporary special procedures to ensure the safety of the competitors.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bryan Baumgarten
Comment: I believe this is a regulation that needs to get passed. For people to train as much as they do to compete at such a memorable event, it is important that their safety isn't jeopardized by the wants and desires of spectators. Having said that, I believe if spectators are that interested in viewing specific portions of the race, it may be beneficial if there wear some technological improvements that could benefit spectators. Cameras or portable trackers that racers can were may be of value to those eager to watch. Hope this comment is of value.

Title: Comment Submitted by Frances Oliver
Comment: I support this proposed rule from the Coast Guard and DHS. There are only 2 days per year during the swim portion of the triathlon when it will come into effect, making it relatively easy and reasonable to enforce. Additionally, it promotes the safety of everyone involved; Iron Man participants, event runners, safety and emergency personnel, and the general public. That goes for event security as well; the ability to control the area around this event allows the Coast Guard and DHS to maintain security and protect all around.

Title: Comment Submitted by Meghan Cassidy and Munson Zimmerman
Comment:
Hello - we are students in a course on regulation commenting on the Special Local Regulation; Kailua Bay, Ironman World Championship and specifically looking at the time allocated for the special regulation of personnel and vessels not being in the predetermined water zones - 5 AM to 11 AM. 

We agree with this initiative and find it to be a unique problem that no one has yet addressed. As friends of athletes who have participated in the Ironman World Championship, we appreciate your thoughtfulness in caring for the athletes safety and success during practice and the race itself.

We suggest an enhancement to this regulation to improve the water conditions for the athletes swim as well as ensuring their safety. With the difficulty of swimming 2.4 miles in rough waters, we believe that it would be best to extend the hours of the regulation to 3:45 AM on both days in October. We found that this allotment of time would allow for 1) the waters to calm before the 2500 athletes compete and 2) the Coast Guard to have ample time to ensure the waters are clear of vessels and other personnel. We chose 3:45 AM as it is an hour before swim check-in begins. We find this will be useful especially in the first handful of years as the policy is being introduced to ensure effective communication to and understanding by impacted vessels. 

A point discussed within the proposed regulation was that this change should not have any significant economic implications. We believe extending the regulated time will have no additional impact on economic output or productivity. 

We appreciate your time and look forward to seeing this regulation put into action.

Title: Drawbridge Operation Regulation; Fox River, Green Bay, WI
Topics: Bridges
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: The Main Street Bridge was renamed the Ray Nitschke Memorial Bridge in 1998.

Title: Comment Submitted by Will Agen
Comment:
As long as vehicles are still crashing through the gates there should be a live presence, i.e. a Bridge Tender, on every bridge that is being operated.  
Instead of the risk and cost of an experimental wireless remote operation, just establish a call-in period.  By making Tilleman bridge a 4 hour call-in, 24-7, and by making Walnut and Nitschke bridges a 4 hour call-in from 11 pm to 7 am, you could reduce the number of Bridge Tenders to 6 (half of what they have now).  You would still have a live Bridge Tender on each bridge when they require an opening.

Title: Comment Submitted by Christine WIlliams
Comment:
As a tour boat company we feel it is in the best interest of auto, pedestrian and boat traffic to keep bridgetenders at Main Street Bridge, Walnut Street Bridge and the Tilleman Memorial Bridge.  We have seen first hand the need for a bridgetender to keep a pedestrian from walking over the bridge as it was going up.  In addition, a recent incident in Menasha with a bicyclist attempting to cross the open doors made national news (as it was videotaped).  This may save money, but it won't offer the safety required at these drawbridges.

Sincerely,

Christine Williams
owner
Fox River Tours, De Pere
(920) 749-0415

Title: Comment Submitted by James Van Vonderen
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Will Agen
Comment:
Having operated the Green Bay bridges remotely through the summer, I believe the Ray Nitschke Memorial Bridge (Main Street) is not ready for Full Remote Operation (no Bridge Tender on the remotely operated bridge).  The equipment and programming are still being troubleshot and the camera placements were influenced by convenience (existing poles) instead of desired results. 
     My major concern about going Full Remote is the recent decision by WISDOT to replace the current Green Bay City Bridge Tenders with Brown County Snow Plow Operators.  The plan calls for no overlap.  Therefore, 100 years of Bridge Tender experience will be replaced with 45 minutes if a lift needs to be done on any of the three bridges in Green Bay at midnight on December 1, 2019.  Making such a drastic personnel change this far into the process and on the tail end of the NPRM is irresponsible with respect to the public and maritime safety, and shows a certain disregard towards the Coast Guards approval process. 
     The four senior City Bridge Tenders were moved to Walnut Street Bridge in March, 2019 to facilitate and prepare for future Full Remote Operations.  The Tilleman Memorial and Ray Nitschke Memorial bridges have been operated remotely through the summer without major incidents.  There were a couple of gate crashes but that is a normal, infrequent occurrence.  Now, new operators, who have been trained in Sturgeon Bay and not Green Bay, will be responsible for all openings as of midnight on December 1, 2019.  
     As a current City Bridge Tender and a retired Coast Guard Officer, I strongly recommend that Full Remote Operations be delayed at least one more summer so these new operators can gain some experience.  Openings on a foggy morning, a dark rainy night, or a crowded Farmers Market evening are all situations the new operators should not be required or allowed to do alone for the first time.

Title: Safety Zone; Missouri River, Mile Markers 366.3 to 369.8, Kansas City, MO
Topics: Harbors,Marine Safety,Navigation (Water),Reporting and Recordkeeping Requirements,Security Measures,Waterways
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: For the safety of those in the areas and traveling to it within the time period, this proposed rule will be beneficial in ensuring safety. In the matter of small entities, the show along these lines tend to garner crowds that boost the local economy. Even if some are put off by the times in which the safe zone is in effect, they will ultimately benefit from the show and festivities that make a safe zone a necessity.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Lieutenant Commander Christian Barger.
    	Thank you for proposing to establish a temporary safety zone for safety reasons. The air show is an important event in the military. Therefore, considering the temporary safety zone also helps to boost up the morale. Also, your consideration of possible problems in terms of small entities and the relationship between federalism and Indian Tribal governments. 
You clarify that the impact of small entities would be insignificant according to 5 U.S.C. 605(b). Furthermore, as the environment perspective, according to the Department of Homeland Security Directive 023-01 and Commandant Instruction M16475.1D, you clearly define there would not be a significant impact on the human environment. All those concerns into account, it is important to establish a temporary safety zone.
    Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on it.

Title: Comment Submitted by Sanjiv Sarma
Comment: The proposed temporary safety zone is to be enforced from noon to 6 p.m. on July 4 and from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. on July 5 to July 7. This time range is precisely the range given by the KC Air Show Charities, Inc. as the duration of their air shows over the Missouri River in Kansas City, MO. I believe the proposed temporary safety zone duration should be extended to provide some cushion time for the air shows. This cushion time will be convenient should the air show be pre-poned or delayed for any reason. Also, it will ensure that any unauthorized persons or vessels do not enter the safety zone immediately before the scheduled air show.

Title: Comment Submitted by Tom Alvarez
Comment: What will be the plan for vessels or persons who need to navigate through this area to get to a certain destination. Will there be a planned detour route available? During the hours that this proposed riles would be enacted, how would the rule be enforced on the waters? This rule is needed though to keep the river safe during the show.

Title: Comment Submitted by Steven Tijerina
Comment: I think that implementing a safety zone change for the airshow is a good idea. People will need to keep a safer distance during this time period, so moving the mile marker back from the Missouri River should be able to help. I do not think that there is too much of a burden on the public, and people should be understanding of this regulation.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I believe people in "small entity" might be influenced by the safety zone during those 4 days. Even though six hours per day with four days is not a relatively long period, it still will cause some economically damages to people in "small entities". During that time, because of the prohibition to enter into the safety zone, small entities owners might have to reroute to approach their destinations to operate their businesses. Even worse, they might be forced to stop operating businesses during those four days. So, those two situations may cause them to increase their costs and lose money. In sum, I have to admit that the safety zone is necessary during that time and in that specific space. But, those small entities owners should be compensated for their potential monetary losses.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rick Lootens
Comment: This proposed rule is to serve the interests of the general public to prevent death or dismemberment of bystanders and is directly correlated with the KC Air Show Charities, Inc. performance between July 4-7, 2019. However, could the restriction of this area of the Missouri River be tailored to a daily basis only when the Air Show is ongoing? This would reduce interference in personal leisure and transportation as well as commercial companies such as barges traveling on the Missouri River.

Title: Comment Submitted by Catherine Tighe
Comment:
How do you plan to keep the area clear of all waterway traffic? Will there be stations set up? Will someone be patrolling the area during the designated times? 

Also, if a lot of small entities are against the safety zone what will happen? Will the waters not be usable for the airshow?

Title: Comment Submitted by Eric Benenson
Comment: I am a student at the Indiana University- Bloomington in a course studying government regulation. My issue with this regulation, Safety Zone; Missouri River, Mile Markers 366.3 to 369.8, Kansas City, MO, is that in section IV.B, it states that While some owners or operators of vessels intending to transit the temporary safety zone may be small entities, for the reasons stated in section IV.A above, this proposed rule would not have a significant economic impact on any vessel owner or operator. However, in section IV.A, the closest the regulation gets to giving reasons as to the economic impact on small entities is that they may be allowed to request entry into the zone. I propose that this regulation be more specific as to what conditions need to be met for small entities to be granted access to the zone. This would be fairer and more transparent to small businesses because they would understand why or why not they are being given access to this stretch of river as opposed to just being given or denied access.

Title: Comment Submitted by Milan Saidi
Comment: I think this proposal for a safety zone in the Missouri River during the KC Air Show Charities is a great idea! Since the Air Show is a charity event, there will be many local and tourist visitors. I think with so many people and high volume of traffic, a safety zone is very important. Additionally, I believe the safety zone can help save and protect all wildlife in and around the water during this time. Passing a Safety Zone will only provide help for charity participants and animals. With proper guidelines and help, the professionals working the KC Air Show Charities can find ways to continue the show without causing any disturbance or harm to the area. Furthermore, since the KC Air Show is in July, passing this rule can still give individuals enough time to prepare everything will taking the safety zone under consideration.
