Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
So, as stated, "This zone would be in effect up to six hours per day for four days total and would affect three and one-half miles of the Missouri River. Additionally, persons and vessels would be allowed to request entry into the zone from the COTP or a designated representative."

What are potential reasons that would allow one to request the entry and be accepted entry into the zone? It may have been stated within this piece, but it did not seem to stand out. People who may have legitimate causes that would be able to receive acceptance may not ask due to the fact that they either fear the potential rejection, or believe their legitimate cause is not legitimate and then would choose to simply not ask.

Title: Comment Submitted by Reece Rutledge
Comment:
As stated in the information provided you established that the Coast Guard will propose to "establish a temporary safety zone for the navigable waters of the Missouri River from mile marker (MM) 366.3 to MM 369.8. This action is necessary to provide for the safety of life on these navigable waters near Kansas City, MO, during an airshow from July 4 through July 7, 2019." 

However, later you developed that upon approval some vessels will be aloud to enter if approved by the Captain of the Port Sector Upper Mississippi River or a designated representative. One question that comes to mind is what are some potential scenarios that would allow a vassal acceptance into the safety zone? Of those that get approved to enter how can we ensure the up most safety for those vassals who are clearly a potential risk? With the waterways between MM 366.3 and 369.8 being closed for nearly six hours a day between the dates posted above is their a possibility to narrow the time frame down a vassal can get approval to enter the safety zone during this time? Possibly when you can ensure more safety can be provided?

With proper guidelines and help, the professionals working the KC Air Show Charities can find ways to continue the show without causing any disturbance or harm to the area. Furthermore, since the KC Air Show is in July, passing this rule can still give individuals enough time to prepare everything will taking the safety zone under consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Dalton Cole
Comment: The proposal for the safety zone of the Missouri River, mile makers 366.3 to 369.8, in the Kansas City, MO. I believe this proposal as a lot of good purpose behind it. I understand you have to have certain certification to get through those mile makers. Blocking it off for air show is a very reasonable purpose to do so. My only concern is the business that use this part of the river to travel, how can we make sure these vessels are safe traveling in the area? The main focus is to make sure that the vessels traveling through these mile markers are going to be in no danger. If you are willing to close it for a daily activities because of safety issues then you need to be clear on other vessels that have to come in and out of that area. Maybe look for a different location? For everyone not to be in danger.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Is there a certain reason why the location could not be moved? If the main issue is the flying zone over the water, move it to a park or field. This would open up the area of the river that is being cut off as well as provide a scenic area for the air show. If this is causing so many issues, then why not move it to an area just as scenic as it would be near the river. Once again, I am not aware if there is any significance of the area where the air show is being held, but if not why not move it? This blocking of the given area could affect local businesses as well as commercial, so if there is a way to not disrupt this passage way that route should be taken.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rita Maslanka
Comment: The proposed document by the Coast Guard suggests the temporary safety zone in the navigable waters of the Missouri River. I believe the safety zones are appropriate in order to ensure the safety life of the waters. The proposal keeps the unauthorized peoples out of the zones unless authorized by the Captain of the Port Sector Upper Missouri River. However, it is important to keep in mind that they prohibit travel in the area at certain times. How can the safety and management of these exact rules be enforced? Also, how does one obtain permission from the COTP or a designated representative in order to request entry? There is a lot to be considered with the potential impact of the proposal, such as the direct effect on the States, and the distribution of power and responsibilities among the levels of government. Regardless of what the decision is on the bill, the significant environmental impact from this proposed rule should be on the forefront.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I believe that the proposed safety zone is an appropriate measure that is upholding the safety and health of the community. As stated in the information provided you established that the Coast Guard will propose to "establish a temporary safety zone for the navigable waters of the Missouri River from mile marker (MM) 366.3 to MM 369.8. This action is necessary to provide for the safety of life on these navigable waters near Kansas City, MO, during an airshow from July 4 through July 7, 2019." The zone will likely have very insignificant economic impact on vessels intending to transit the temporary safety zone, especially since most vessels are small entities. The rule also provides the opportunity to obtain permission from the COTP or a designated representative if you must pass during the the three day period. It seems that the rule is proposed concisely and is intended to maintain the safety and health of everyone near the river during the 4th of July weekend.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous

In addition, vessels or persons still have opportunities to sub permission to enter the safety zone. In this way, I think it is an appropriate rule.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous

The impact of this rule on small businesses, the environment, or any other category is likely to be small or non-existence and therefore provides more reason for the passing of this rule.

Title: Comment Submitted by Elizabeth Lademan
Comment: I believe the temporary safety zones proposal is a valuable measure for public safety during the days surrounding the Fourth of July.  As mentioned in the proposal,  falling debris, especially from fireworks which would have the added factor of being extremely hot, is something that people who choose to roam the waters should be safe from.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ryan Williams
Comment: I absolutely stand with the Coast Guard for their proposition to establish a temporary safety zone for certain areas of Apra Outer Harbor. Since there will be a firework show on July 4th in this area, it makes total sense to establish a safe zone for the safety of vessels and other navigable waters in that area. Especially since the temporary safety zone would only last for a little over three hours on one day, it seems like a sound and reasonable proposition by the Coast Guard.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeremy Gumila
Comment: I think that this is a phenomenal idea as it raises awareness for sexual harassment as well as a more smooth process in terms of reporting. I think that this will make people more comfortable when filing a complaint in terms of sexual assault. With this idea I ask, how will you guys spread the news if this law is passed? It will be difficult to fully distribute the news right away and can take even more time even after the law is passed. Despite that con, I believe that is an issue that is out of anyones control. That being said, I still believe that this law should be passed, because it will have a great impact on the entire population of America.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I believe it is critical to designate an area as a "safety zone" during a fireworks display. Although I am not part of a business entity that would be affected by the Regulatory Flexibility Act, I would like to state that this regulation is quite considerate of the environment around the firework display. I would, however, like to raise concern on whether debris that comes from this display will affect any marine life. If any harmful damage can occur as a result of this display, it is essential to develop a plan or safety precautions to protect marine life; this can include netting, platforms that will collect the debris or implementing barriers in the water. Some individuals may argue that constructing these barriers or safety precautions may create a situation in which the costs outweigh the benefits. Although this may be true, it is critical to note that if this region continues to display fireworks in this area year after year, the cost will soon be irrelevant in comparison to the benefit. After all, it is probable that the United States will not stop celebrating Independence Day in the future.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jiake Wen
Comment: It is important to protect the ecosystem in this water body. Before making specific rules about what kind of people or vessels can be allowed to get into this region, it might be helpful to analyze how people and vessels are influencing this water body now.

Title: Comment Submitted by Franco Torres
Comment: I believe the Coast Guard should pass this proposed rule. Safety of civilians and property should always be a top priority and it is evident that the Coast Guard is seeking to prevent any injury from occurring. By passing this proposal, civilians will be at less risk of injury to person or property and the Coast Guard will prevent itself from any liability. I believe this rule benefits both parties and should therefore be approved.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joshua Dunn
Comment:
Overall, I believe that Safety Zone; Apra Outer Harbor, Naval Base Guam Rule is sensible and will ensure that avoidable accidents are prevented.

However, one question or concern I have is regarding the timing that the Apra Outer Harbor becomes a designated safety zone. As the rule reads now the Apra Outer Harbor becomes "a safety zone from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. on July 4, 2019." At the same time, the fireworks show is set to begin at 6:00 p.m. and last until 9 p.m. 

If the goal of the rule is "to ensure the safety of vessels and these navigable waters before, during, and after the scheduled 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. fireworks display," then the timing of the designated should be broader than the fireworks show itself.

As a practical consideration, this means that someone could lawfully be in the middle of the safety zone at 5:59 p.m. with the show set to start one minute later. Even if they were to be escorted out at 6 p.m., based on this rule, they could still be exposed to the potential dangers of being too close to a fireworks show.

Considering expanding the duration that Apra Outer Harbor is a safety zone, even from 5:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. would alleviate these concerns, not add too much of burden, and be consist with the safety concerns this rule is attempting to address.

Title: Comment Submitted by Sameet Solanki
Comment: The temporary safety zones for the water of the Apra Outer Harbor should be put in place for the coast guard because anyone wondering within these zones who are at risk of harm because of the firework display put in place should be restricted from entering the area. The safety of the people is always a top priority.

Title: Comment Submitted by Madison Wicklund
Comment: I believe this rule is necessary and beneficial for the safety of the community; however, I would like to know why the radius is 190 yards. How is the amount of yards determined? Also, how will this rule be enforced, will the Coast Guard be patrolling the area on the night of July Fourth? Lastly, how will the fireworks be cleaned up and what actions, if any, are in place to ensure that the firework debris will not be left in the Harbor?

Furthermore, demonstrations/shows occasionally do have accidents whether its a late reaction that occurs or a firework doesnt go the right direction. Having a safe zone can prevent the general public from being hurt while they still enjoy a great show.

Title: Notice of Availability of Navigation and Vessel Inspection Circular 01- 16 Change 2- Use of Electronic Charts and Publications in Lieu of Paper Charts, Maps and Publications
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Whitney Leake
Comment: Patriot Contract Services, LLC, a Ship Manager, fully supports the proposed Change 2 to NVIC 01-16.  Every Bridge has a computer on it that is used to access electronic publications, making these publications readily available.  Electronic versions are kept up to date by the provider, eliminating the need for the ship to correct the publication.  As all other nav pubs can be stored electronically, allowing electronic copies of the Nav Rules and VTS User Guides is a logical next step.

Title: Comment Submitted by Sarah Hirsch, Orange Coast College
Comment:
Thank you for sharing this Notice of Availability regarding NVIC 01-16 Change 2. 
I have 2 comments I'd like to share at this time. 

With regard to publications, I would like to note that the Subchapter T Inspection Checklist provided on Homeport (https://homeport.uscg.mil/Lists/Content/Attachments/2581/T-Boat%20PreInsp%20List.pdf) lists 46 CFR 166-199 as a Recommended" document to be carried aboard. I'd like to recommend that NVIC 01-16 Change 2 addresses this recommendation. Specifically, I'd like to suggest that 46 CFR 166-199 is recommended to be carried aboard in electronic or paper version, and that this recommendation is mentioned in the updated NVIC. 

Second, I would like to suggest that discussion is provided in NVIC 01-16 regarding mariner credentialing. Specifically, I recommend that approved training courses/programs are permitted and encouraged to train students in the use of electronic publications, including the applicable CFRs.

Title: Comment Submitted by Thomas Petersen
Comment:
Electronic navigation has been the norm for many years now. Requiring paper charts as a primary source of navigation information is analogous to requiring paper and pencil to do arithmetic problems when it is actually computers and calculators that do this sort of work. Paper charts are not as updated as frequently as electronic charts can be, require more space to use and storage when the modern vessels use all electronics throughout the vessel, it is silly to require paper charts. 

As a licensed captain, I have not had to use paper charts in well over 10-15 years.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bruce Grimm
Comment:
RE: USCG-2019-0348 FRN 2019-11020  OMB 1625-0037

The United States Coast Guard policies and standards for inspection activities provide for a system of reporting that is essential to safe operation of vessels.  The information collection for certificates of compliance, boiler and pressure vessel repairs, cargo gear repairs, shipping papers and NFPA 10 certification harmonizes how the CG conducts an examination and allows for consistency in evaluating vessels both foreign and domestic.

The information collection request verifies data needed to verify safety of operations under 46 CFR Part 97 etal.  The forms contain action codes, instructions and notices that are easily delineated and understood by users.

The certificate of compliance substantiates that a vessel is fit for duty and along with the other criteria helps to detect deficiencies in the safety management system of the vessel that hinder compliance.

The boiler and pressure vessel repair reporting where the regulations have a preemptive effect over state and local regulation in the same field make it essential to verify the nature of repairs to important maritime operational equipment.  It is a simplied format that is easily discerned by inspectors or repair persons.

Reporting on cargo gear repairs is important to determine condition and suitability of shipboard cargo gear such as masts, stays, winches, booms, cranes, elevators, running gear and other equipment.  The form is a certification that various tests including those required at least once in a year have been conducted.  

Shipping papers are important to verify quantity, proper shipping name, hazard class or suitability and other data for lading on vessels.  These forms are harmonized worldwide, and the information well understood by any experienced commercial mariner.

NFPA 10 certificates ensure that that fire protection systems are under an inspection, repair and maintenance program so that this important equipment is operational if needed. 

Synonymous data elements on federal forms and reporting mechanisms have sometimes been used interchangeably.  Common data elements standardize the information collection to promote increased efficiency and interoperability of the reporting process.

The paperwork burden on responders is minimal and the information captured is essential to protect the public.  The Coast Guard request for extension should be approved.

Title: Safety Zone; Big Foot Tension Leg Platform, Outer Continental Shelf on the Gulf of Mexico
Topics: Continental Shelf,Marine Safety,Navigation (Water)
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Nicholas Szelak, National Ocean Service - Office of Coast Survey, NOAA
Organization Name: National Ocean Service - Office of Coast Survey (NOS - OCS)
Comment:
Dear LCDR Michael Dougherty,

The Marine Chart Division (MCD) of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is responsible for charting U.S. coastal waters. Pursuant to that responsibility, NOAA depicts the locations of permanent safety zones established by the U.S. Coast Guard. The purpose of my comment is to provide feedback regarding the notice of this proposal to establish a permanent Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) safety zone around the Big Foot Tension Leg Platform, located in Walker Ridge 29 on OCS in the Gulf of Mexico. Refer to Federal Register / Vol. 84, No. 243 / Wednesday, December 18, 2019 / Pages 69348 - 69349.

My credentials follow:

Nautical cartographer, member since May 2016 in the Nautical Data Branch (NDB) of the MCD at NOAA.

Experience in vetting boundaries and regulations associated with Federal Register Proposed and Final Rules as they relate to nautical charting under the direction of senior cartographic reviewers.

Assigned by my branch chief to examine the Federal Register Notice associated with this proposal to establish a permanent OCS safety zone.

Experienced in using GIS software, i.e., ArcMap 10.5.1, in plotting geographic coordinates on NOAA nautical charts.

My feedback follows:

(1) Supplementary Information "III. Discussion of Proposed Rule" currently states "The Coast Guard proposes to establish an permanent OCS safety zone extending 500 meters (1,640.4 feet) from the coordinates: Latitude N 26-55 longitude W 90-31-14.952.

(2) Section "147.861 Safety Zone; Big Foot Tension Leg Platform, Outer Continental Shelf on the Gulf of Mexico." currently states "(a) Description. The Big Foot Tension Leg Platform (TLP) is in the deepwater area of the Gulf of Mexico at Walker Ridge 29. The Big Foot TLP is located at latitude N 26-55.308 and longitude W 90-31-14.952, and the area within 500 meters of the Big Foot TLP, is a permanent safety zone."

Discrepancies exist with the formatting of the coordinates specified in that the latitude of the former (1) is in degrees-minutes while the latitude of the latter (2) is in degrees-decimal minutes, and the longitude of both the former (1) and the latter (2) is in degrees-minutes-decimal seconds. I request to consider a revision of the formatting of the latitude coordinates specified in both (1) and (2) to degrees-minutes-decimal seconds. The horizontal datum (e.g. North American Datum 27 (NAD 27), North American Datum 83 (NAD 83), World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS 84)) of the coordinates is not specified. I request to consider an addition of the horizontal datum to the coordinates. The purpose of these considerations is to increase consistency and accuracy while to simultaneously eliminate any potential confusion.

Respectfully,

Nicholas Szelak, Cartographer
Nautical Data Branch / Marine Chart Division
Office of Coast Survey / National Ocean Service
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

Title: Special Local Regulations, Upper  Mississippi River, Mile Markers 839 to 840 St. Paul, MN

Title: Comment Submitted by Gus Gaspardo, Padelford Packet Boat Co. Inc.
Comment:
Padelford Packet Boat Co. Inc owns and operates a fleet of three Subchapter K vessels on the Mississippi River in Saint Paul, MN at Mile 840 UMR. We are a small family business that normally operates from April through October with a workforce of 60 seasonal employees and 10 full time employees. Our vessels range in size from 162 to 300 passengers, we carry 90,000 passengers annually on regularly scheduled sightseeing, dinner and lunch cruises as well as private charters.

We are highly concerned over the planned RedBull Flugtag event and the accompanying special local regulations proposed. Our company has suffered multiple high water events this spring and early summer leading to significant loss of revenue and cancellations. We simply can not afford to incur further cancellations and lost revenue due to this event. More importantly we are highly concerned in regards to the safety of spectators, vessels  and our licensed marine staff that may arise during the event due to extreme congestion on the waterway and a potential lack of law enforcement vessels. 
Thank you,
Capt. Gus Gaspardo
President
Padelford Packet Boat Co. Inc.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lee Nelson
Comment:
If memory correctly serves, the last time this event was held at this location the patrol vessels became completely overwhelmed by the spectator vessels. This resulted in approved transits through the area not being able to be accomplished due to safety concerns. The patrol vessels were not able to maintain a navigable channel through the spectator vessels and any hopes of transiting needed to be abandoned. And, I believe this took place even before the actual event began.

Many more patrol vessels than in the past will be needed to maintain order. Additionally, significant efforts will need to be made to keep the navigation channel clear prior to the event and to clear the channel immediately after the event.

It is not secret that commercial navigation and all the industries that depend on it have been very severely impacted by high water this year. Being in a northern climate, there will not be nearly enough days to catch-up before winter again sets in. However, we accept that we are but one of a vast number of legitimate beneficiaries of the river. And, we understand that entertainment is an appropriate activity on the river. Though a seven-hour closure seems a bit much, it is the control of the situation before, during, and after the scheduled event that is paramount.

Safety is our greatest concern. Without adequate controls, the effect of the spectator vessels can get out of hand. We are trusting that the USCG; law enforcement; and the event sponsor will ensure that enough patrol vessels are in place to appropriately manage the situation. Additionally, we are willing to work with the aforementioned entities to do what we reasonably can to help create a successful event.

Title: Comment Submitted by Diane Ward
Comment:
Re: USCG-2019-0460 which is the Coast Guard announcement of 2 public meetings to receive comments regarding the safe
navigation and mooring of LNG carriers through the San Juan Harbor San Juan PR.

The timing of these meetings, both of which are to be conducted on 7/26/19, should be reconsidered in light of the extreme unrest and mass protests, and in some cases, violence, occurring in San Juan at the current time as the people of Puerto Rico are calling for the resignation of their governor. Based on current events, these meetings should be rescheduled, or additional meetings should be scheduled for a later date when the people can be more focused on the LNG carrier safety issues and not on the performance of their governor. Some people who would normally attend may not turn out, not wanting to encounter the protesting groups in their travel to the meeting location, the Sheraton Puerto Rico Hotel and Casino, 200 Convention Boulevard, San Juan. 

Although the opportunity to input on regulations.gov until August 4th is provided on this electronic forum, no information in terms of supporting documents are attached to this meeting notice. The documents detailing the proposed adjustment to the current safety zone established under 33 CFR165.754, Safety Zone: San Juan Harbor,San Juan, PRare not provided online. Providing the documents electronically would be allow people concerned about the unrest and violence to stay safely in their homes, read the documents, and still provide input. The information is currently planned to be given out at the meeting, which the people may not be able to attend due to the unrest, therefore eliminating the possibility of any input. Providing the information electronically also allows the elderly, and people with busy schedules, to input.

Right now, cruise ships are not docking in San Juan as a result of the unrest, which is being reported on quite extensively in the media. Thousands of people are turning out into the streets and highways. The protests have been ongoing and daily and could be expected to continue through the 26th, if the governor doesn't resign. Also the issue of their governance is acting as a red herring in distracting the people's attention from the important issues concerning LNG. 

The issue of LNG in the San Juan Harbor does not only affect the people of San Juan. Other harbor users, including the tourists who travel on the cruise ships which visit Puerto Rico, are affected by LNG carriers and their navigation and mooring in San Juan Harbor. These tourists are not likely to be in San Juan at the current time due to the fact that the cruise ships are not docking there due to the unrest. Any of these tourists who might be interested in attending these meetings will not be able to attend, and also cannot get the information to comment online, since the information is not posted here. A vehicle to allow these people, and other people who are currently on the mainland of the USA, either natives of San Juan who travel back and forth, or US mainland based residents who may occasionally cruise to or vacation in San Juan and other ports of call, also cannot get the information, since they cannot be expected to all be in San Juan on July 26th. 

Therefore, I respectfully request that the meeting scheduled for 7/26/19 be postponed and held at a later date, or conducted as scheduled, with additional sessions held later at a less volatile time. Also, I request that the information concerning the safety zone changes, and the other documents mentioned in the Federal Register 34323 Vol. 84, No. 138 published on Thursday, July 18, 2019, as described, be posted in this docket. This includes: The Letter of Intent and Waterway Suitability Assessment from New Fortress Energy to construct and operate the required infrastructure for offloading and transferring liquefied natural gas at the Army Terminal Turning Basin in San Juan, Puerto Rico received on Dec. 12, 2017 by the U.S. Coast Guard, the Coast Guard's recommendations, and the September 26, 2018 Coast Guard Sector San Juan determination of suitability for the proposed operation in the Port of San Juan that was made. 

Thank you for your consideration of my comments. I have cruised in the past, and would like to see the safety of cruise ships and other waterborne vessels in the harbor assured for all travelers, and for those people on land near the harbor or docks, which are very busy tourist areas.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mary Ann Lucking, CORALations
Comment:
Re: USCG-2019-0460 US Coast Guard announces two public meetings to receive comments regarding the safe navigation and mooring of LNG carriers through the San Juan Harbor, San Juan PR.

CORALations is an award-winning coral conservation organization, founded and based in Puerto Rico.  

Summary
We are writing to request that additional hearings be announced and deadline extended for public comment, consistent with the advanced notice and publication requirements of the Administrative Procedures Act for reasons described below.   We ask Coast Guard to circulate official notice to the media, with focussed attention to effectively inform affected stakeholders. We ask that all related documents be posted online for public access and analysis as soon as possible.   

For the Record: 

The notice makes reference to The operation of LNG gas carriers and add the new facility within the San Juan Harbor, San Juan, PR.  It is not clear to us what add the new facility means. 

This notice was posted only 8 days prior to announced public hearings, and to our knowledge, only in the Federal Registry. While it may be possible for the Coast Guard to argue expedition on homeland security and navigational safety issues, this would not apply to addition a new LNG facility. 

We argue that meaningful public participation cannot be obtained anywhere with only 8 days prior notice. Nowhere would that be more true than Puerto Rico today.  The island is at an historic crossroad as FBI continues arrests of local government officials, and the governor was unseated by relentless, yet non-violent street demonstrations.  Local agencies involved in these critical determinations are currently in organizational chaos. A significant extension is only reasonable. 

We recognize minimal due diligence on the part of the Coast Guard to meet social justice obligations of public transparency and meaningful participation would include dissemination of this notice to the media, with focussed outreach to all impacted interests. This would include, but not be limited to:  local communities and industries found on the harbor, environmental organizations, interests that protect local historic and cultural patrimony of the old city, local tourism, the cruise ship industry, Isla Grande Airport, and commercial cargo shipping interests from the States as well as the Lesser Antilles. 

This very online form style prototype edition of the daily Federal Register on Federal Register.gov,1 displays prominently: 
This document has a comment period that ends in 70 days. (10/04/2019)   The description verbiage however, indicates deadline is on or before August 4th, 2019.  This can confuse the general public, and could result in meaningful comments not being recognized for the record. 

If the amendments add a new facility then likely a determination of consistency under the Federal Coastal Zone Management Act may be required. 

A new facility or mooring or transit would require Section 7 compliance to the Endangered Species Act, as the waters of the bay are listed critical habitat for the acroporid corals, that at least pre-Maria were found near the harbors entrance. 

This Harbor is surrounded by historic structures listed and/or eligible for listing in the National Registration of Historic Places. It is possible that official notice must be given to the National (NHPO) and local State Historic Preservation Offices (SHPO).

Information concerning the proposed safety zone changes, and the other documents referenced in the Federal Register 34323 Vol. 84, No. 138 were not posted, making it impossible for the public to provide meaningful analysis and comment.  We therefor ask that this also be rectified by posting for review any and all relevant documents in the federal record as well as those documents referenced specifically in notice:  

1) The proposed safety zone adjustment these hearings are being called for regarding the operation of LNG gas carriers and add the new facility within the San Juan Harbor, San Juan, PR. 

2) The Letter of Intent and Waterway Suitability Assessment from New Fortress Energy to construct and operate the required infrastructure for offloading and transferring liquefied natural gas at the Army Terminal Turning Basin in San Juan, Puerto Rico received on Dec. 12, 2017 by the U.S. Coast Guard.

3) The official response and recommendations from the Coast Guard to the Dec 12th letter from NFE. 

4) The Coast Guard Sector San Juan determination of suitability for the proposed operation in the Port of San Juan, September 26, 2018.

References
1.  [https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2019/07/18/2019-15267/public-hearings-on-liquefied-gas-carriers-transiting-through-san-juan-harbor-san-juan-pr]

Sincerely, 

Mary Ann Lucking
Director
CORALations
PO BOX 750
Culebra, PR . 00775
787-556-6234

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
C.	Re: The proposed adjustment to the current safety zone established under 33 CFR 165.754, Safety Zone: San Juan Harbor, San Juan, PR.

1.	What information in the LOI, WSA, and other submittals to the USCG form the basis for the proposed adjustment?  Is all or any portion of that information available to the public?  Is the information required to be made available prior to an adjustment, for the adjustment to be valid and not subject to future challenge?  

2.	What are the specifics of the proposed adjustment?

3.	What type of increase in the size, type or frequency of vessels being used by NFE or others, would require either a new WSA determination, or an additional adjustment? 

D.	Re: The Coast Guard Sector San Juan and New Fortress Energy hosting public meetings on July 26, 2019 for the general public to provide comments regarding the proposed adjustment to the current safety zone established under 33 CFR 165.754, Safety Zone: San Juan Harbor, San Juan, PR.

1.	Is the public hearing required by law or regulation, for LNG to be delivered to SJH for:
(i) NFE's truck facility: and/or,
(ii) deliveries of LNG for San Juan 5&6?

2.	What information is required by law or regulation to be made available to the public in advance of the hearing on the proposed adjustment?

3.	Is it customary that, like here, the proposed adjustment has not been made available to the public in advance of a hearing to make comment on the proposed adjustment?

4.	Is it customary that, like here, the bases (studies, reports, analysis, and other submittals) for the proposed adjustment are not made available to the public in advance of a hearing to make comment on the proposed adjustment?

5.	If the public hearing is not required by law or regulation, what is the point of having the hearing without making public the content of the proposed adjustment, and the rationale and need for or the proposed adjustment?

E.	Re: PREPA proposed a land-based LNG terminal in San Juan to replace the New 
Fortress Energy ship-based LNG terminal in the latest Integrated Resource Plan submitted to the Puerto Rico Energy Bureau.  The land-based LNG terminal would provide natural gas to PREPA San Juan 5 & 6 units as well as to the PREPA Palo Seco complex via a to be constructed land-based pipeline.

1.  Did the Dec 2017 LOI submittal or the Sept 2018 WSA approval contemplate the ships delivering LNG to a land-based terminal, or the volumes increasing to serve Palo Seco?

2.  Will the proposed adjustment allow additional or larger LNG ships than that described by NFE to deliver larger LNG volumes to the proposed land-based LNG terminal?

3.  Will a separate letter of intent and waterway suitability assessment be required for ships to deliver cargoes into 
SJH for a land-based LNG terminal?

4.  Is the answer to 3 above different if only San Juan 5 & 6 use LNG from ships versus if volumes of approximately the same amount, are later desired or required for Palo Seco?

F.  The evaluations necessary to assess the safety and security concerns for a proposed LNG project require a diverse and varied expertise that is not only privately held by consultants and industry professionals but also contained within numerous governmental entities at the federal, Puerto Rico and local levels  as well as that contained within the expertise and experience of NGOs.  In that regard, which such parties were invited and, then participated, in the WSA for San Juan Harbor relative to the NFE project?

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Note that the neither the proposed adjustment to the regulation or the underlying basis for the USCG determination or approval is posted on the relevant docket USCG20190460 using the Federal eRulemaking Portal at https://www.regulations.gov. 
 
A.	Re: U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) receipt on December 12, 2017 of Letter of Intent (LOI) and Waterway Suitability Assessment (WSA) from New Fortress Energy (NFE) to construct and operate the required infrastructure for offloading and transferring of liquefied natural gas at the Army Terminal Turning Basin in San Juan Harbor (SJH) in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

1.	What assumptions as to number of cargoes, size of ships, cargo capacity of ships, and frequency, were used when USCG approved the WSA?   Where is this information made available to the public for review?

2.	Did the submitted LOI and WSA only consider shipping and infrastructure for: 
(i)	NFE's small, low-volume truck loading facility to provide LNG to on-island industrial users; and/or,
(ii)	large quantities of LNG to be vaporized and natural gas provided to Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (PREPA) San Juan 5 & 6 power generation units? [Note that after the Dec 2017 submittal by NFE, on July 30, 2018 PREPA issued the RFP 81412 for the supply of LNG and delivery of natural gas to San Juan 5 & 6 (PREPA RFP).  Therefore, it is not apparent that there was enough time to identify, analyze and incorporate PREPA RFP requirements not known in Dec 2017 in the Sept 2018 USCG WSA approval.  In addition, another reason PREPA RFP requirements may not have been considered in the Sept 2018 USCG WSA approval is that the PREPA selection of NFE for the supply of LNG and delivery of natural gas to San Juan 5 & 6 was made in November 2018, after the Sept 2018 USCG WSA approval.] 

3.	To the extent that the December 12, 2017 submitted LOI and WSA did not include construction and operation of infrastructure for LNG to be vaporized and natural gas provided to PREPA San Juan 5 & 6 power generation units, is it now included and if so when was it added?  When were the PREPA RFP requirements added to the WSA relative to the USCG WSA approval?

4.	Is all or any portion of the information in the LOI, WSA, and other submittals to the USCG that form the basis for the determination on September 26, 2018 that the Port of San Juan is suitable for the proposed operation, required to be made available to the public in advance of the WSA determination or this hearing?  Or customarily is it made available, even if not required by regulation?  The WSA process  when involving LNG terminal and shipping operations  is conducted in conjunction with the review process of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), which allows substantial review opportunities by the public and significant information being provided.  In the absence of FERC oversight relative to the New Fortress Energy project  there appears to be no sharing of project related information nor information regarding safety and security considerations and assessments that should be precedent to the requesting of comments.

5.	Besides this hearing and the 2018 WSA approval, does the USCG plan on having additional approvals or hearings relative to this project or other projects that might propose to transport, store and use LNG in San Juan Harbor, for issues such as hazard studies or exclusion zones?  Will the hazard studies and information forming the basis of security and safety zones be released to the public, in whole or in part, prior to a final determination of any changes to 33 CFR 165.754.  Equally important  why is this information apparently not available now prior to the Comment Deadline?

6.	How are allowable ship sizes, ship LNG cargo capacities, delivery frequencies, and mooring durations determined with respect to safety and hazard analyses?

7.	Was there an evaluation of how frequency of LNG deliveries would impact other shipping traffic in SJH and thus require adjustments to the activities of 3rd parties?  Without such information  a traffic impact assessment in a manner of speaking  how would one have any basis to provide a meaningful comment to the hearing proposed for 33 CFR 165.754?

B.	For the purposes of considering a WSA or an adjustment to the existing harbor regulations, does it matter whether the LNG is delivered in:
(i) containers that are offloaded onto shore, versus 
(ii) delivered in on-board tanks and pumped from the vessel into onshore storage facilities, versus 
(iii) regasified on a vessel moored in the harbor, with the gas piped onto shore to be used in power plants?

Title: Comment Submitted by Ruth Santiago, El Puente de Wiilliamsburg, Inc. Latino Climate Action Network
Organization Name: El Puente de Wiilliamsburg, Inc. Latino Climate Action Network
Comment:
Please see full comment attached.

There are many questions with respect to the proposed LNG zone that remain unanswered. The lack of access to information about the proposed LNG zone impedes meaningful public participation in the administrative proceeding and the due process that the USCG must afford the citizenry, particularly residents who live within the potential impact zone of the proposed LNG operation.  The public requires access to the file, including the Letter of Intent, Water Suitability Assessment and Report, and other documents. 

Is there a separate proposal for a safety zone for the LNG carriers/ships while they are moored?
What is the proposed size of the LNG carriers/ships entering the bay?
Will there be a limitation on the size of the LNG carriers/vessels that will be entering the bay?
What is the proposed number and frequency per year of LNG carriers/ships in San Juan Bay?
Will there be a limit on the number of LNG carriers/ships in the Bay?
How much time will the LNG carriers/ships take to unload the LNG? Will unloading time vary for truck deliveries and supplies for the PREPA San Juan units?
How long will the LNG carriers/ships be permitted to be moored in the docks/wharfs?
Is the safety zone contemplated for LNG shipments to feed/supply trucking operations, the PREPA San Juan 5 & 6 units, both, other projects, or any shipment of LNG into San Juan Bay?
What is the estimated total yearly maximum volume of LNG to be brought in through San Juan Bay for the trucking project?
What is the estimated total yearly maximum volume of LNG to be brought in through San Juan Bay for the PREPA units?
What is the estimated total yearly maximum volume of LNG to be brought in through San Juan Bay for any other uses?
Will the LNG be transported in ISO containers or in bulk tanks or any other method?
Will there ever be more than one LNG carrier in San Juan Bay?
Will there be ship to ship transfers of LNG in San Juan Bay?
What precautions would be required for the LNG carriers/ships in the Bay?
Will additional safety and/or emergency plans, equipment or facilities be required for LNG shipments into San Juan Bay?
How and where will the LNG for the San Juan 5 & 6 units be revaporized?
What is the population-how many people live and/or work within a thirty-mile radius of the wharfs where the LNG Floating Storage Unit (FSU) would be moored?
What notice, if any was provided to the communities within the potential impact zone of the LNG project?
What is the cost of the different aspects of the NFE LNG shipping project, wharf work, truck loading, supply infrastructure for PREPA supply and total cost?
What contracts have been entered into for the NFE LNG shipping project and the former government administration including contracts relating to the port and for supply of LNG to the PREPA plants?
What permits are required for each aspect of the LNG shipping project and the status of each?
Why does New Fortress Energy allege that Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) authorization is not required for the importation of LNG into San Juan Bay? Are there any documents to substantiate this NFEs position?
Has the United States Army Corp of Engineers (USACE) issued any permits for any aspects of the LNG shipping project? If so, are they available to the public?
Are there any environmental assessments or impact statements for the NFE LNG shipping projects? If so, are they available to the public?
Has the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued any permits for any aspect of the LNG shipping projects? If so, are they available to the public?
Has there been consultation on the NFE LNG projects with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Marine Fisheries Service (USFWS, NOAA/NMFS)? If so, is the documentation available to the public?
Has there been consultation with the Puerto Rico agencies on the NFE LNG projects? If so, please provide the documentation.
What is the casualty history in San Juan Bay?
What is the status of the San Juan Harbor Improvement project?
What are the limitations of the Army Terminal?
Would more frequent LNG shipments be required because of the limitations of the Army Terminal?
What has the modeling for upset conditions for the LNG shipping demonstrated?
What do the simulation studies indicate about the proposed LNG shipments?
What other kinds of zones-exclusion, security, etc. are contemplated for the LNG shipment projects?

The establishment of an LNG safety zone in San Juan Harbor has far-reaching implications for the Puerto Rico electric system,  and would create incentives to perpetuate central station, fossil fuel generation that negatively impacts public health and the environment, drains the Puerto Rican economy and lacks resiliency.  El Puente/ELAC respectfully requests that the Coast Guard allow access to the information requested, deny the proposed rule amendment and the establishment of an LNG zone in San Juan Harbor.

Title: Comment Submitted by Donald Mitchel
Comment:
Dear Sirs,  Virus commonly found in Algae has been shown by work done at John Hopkin to have jumped species to humans. This virus cause cognitive problems. Ships confined to the Great Lakes spread algae. Ships coming into the Great Lakes can contain algae. John Hopkins article report this agal virus is also in ocean algae. The EPA when establishing protocols for the types of  BWMS that are approved, needs to address the high risk of significant human health problems created ballast water.       
     Spreading algae, that an algal virus is known to thrive in, and is known to have jumped species becoming a human pathogen should be considered by an agency who mission is to protect the environment, completely unacceptable.                          Mosquitos carry many human pathogens and their larva thrives in algae. Theses work done by Elizabeth Kathleen McCraven published by the university of New Orleans as far back as 2009 states mosquito larva is often found in ballast water. The need to prevent bacteria, virus, and other invasive species from being spread is essential if our waters are to be protected for future generations. Some ballast water problems are multiple issue and may be addressed better at land based facilities. With shipping traffic expected to grow exponential in harmony with increase trade and population,  failure to act with strong standards for BWMS  will continue to destroy our water resources. We can not afford to take a wait and see position about whether a viruss is capable of causing human health problems. When considering the testing protocols fo BWMS it should be imperative that BWMS need to render all VIRUS and bacteria non viable with a goal for the future of a zero particle count. An invasive pathogenic virus introduced now by ballast water is even capable of laying dormant in sediment With the possibility of finding a host years later. Once an invasive is introduced it is usually to late to fix the problem.

Title: Comment Submitted by John Cullen

Emphasizing peer-reviewed supporting documentation, I show that the MPN + Motility type-approval testing methods and protocols are suitable for BWMS that render organisms in ballast water nonviable. Title: Comment Submitted by Donald Mitchel
Comment:
Dear Sirs,
  When considering the protocols, and testing procedures that BWMS must meet, to protect human, wildlife and agricultural health against the risk posed by the vast universe of unknown bacteria, virus, fungus, etc., in ballast water, waiting to act for onboard BWMS development to meet all goals, is not an acceptable reason to avoid action now. Evaluating and improvement of BWMS should be a continual work in progress with changes made as technology advances not according to a timetable review.
   Infrastructure projects of Land based facilities to test and develop new BWMS while cleaning ballast water for commercial use need to be built to facilitate continuous improvement. Ships should be required to install the best BWMS available now, in conjunction with development of land based BWMS facilities.    
   The expense for ships using land based BWMS facilities as an alternative to onboard BWMS, should be lower. Cost to maintain and operate BWMS equipment or the need to replace a system that in the future may prove inadequate, would be eliminated. Ships using land based BWMS could be free from installation cost, maintenance, inspection, and save space when multiple BWMS applications are needed for various issues. Ships both foreign and domestic using onboard BWMS should be periodically required to submit to inspection, to insure BWMS are being maintained in working order. Land based system would eliminate financial incentive for ships autonomous business interests, tempted to cut corners to save money.  Land based BWMS facilities would allow easier study and sampling by the EPA, Coast Guard, educational institutions, scientist and BWMS manufactures to continually improve protocols, standards and testing for onboard BWMS, as well as ships using the facilities. Ships with structural designs that will not support BWMS could be kept in service with land based BWMS facilities.
   Virus in the worlds waters not already moved, are believed to be regional in origin. With land based BWMS the study of new virus, bacteria, fungus, and invasive species could provide a wealth of information to protect human and wildlife health world wide. New Invasive and harmful pathogens could be detected earlier at land base facilities monitoring ballast water discharges. By using land based BWMS facilities there would not be interference or involvement with the internal operation of both domestic and foreign ships.  
    Algae, chemical spills, etc., possibly could be cleaned from our waters with the use of land based BWMS facilities. With oil spills, chemicals spills, discarded nuclear waste dumping, toxic waste dumping along with the known nuclear accident spilling into oceans, (which are infecting the worlds waters) all BWMS should be capable of detecting these problems, so they can be addressed. Homeland security should be involved with many of dangers ballast water poses when the protocols, standards and testing of BWMS are considered for both foreign and domestic flag ships that are discharging millions of gallons of ballast water into American waters.
     It has been reported, the issue of BWMS and the Great Lakes states, along with other states that have specific issues affecting sensitive waters, will be addressed by the EPA in the fall of 2020. The protections and use of BWMS that are needed to address the dangers of ballast water should not be subject to what is believed will be allowed in the final implementation of the legislation signed in Dec 2018. Compromised standards that do not completely protect our waters are unacceptable. BWMS protocols, regulations should be based solely on what is needed to insure protection of our waters.
    Each of the Great Lakes having unique eco systems and their own issues of pollution and invasive species, should be required to use BWMS on all ships traversing the Great Lakes, whether land based or onboard. The need to stop the spread of invasive species and pathogenic problems such as algae and mosquitoes from being spread through out the Great Lakes is essential to preserving these great natural resources for the future.  
    Most viral and bacterial pathogens in putrid water become more problematic when it is warm. Today we have beach closings as a results of red tides mixing with green algae, flesh eating bacteria, brain eating bacteria, mosquitoes carrying deadly disease etc.,  all in warming waters. Unknown virus and bacteria are being released by melting arctic ice and from waters all over the world, creating an exponentially greater risk in ballast water discharges. Compromised BWMS  standards will not protect  against the exponential growth of ship traffic. 
     BWMS facilities probably will never be the silver bullet to replace all on board BWMS, but in many instances it may be the only adequate solution, providing  the bonus of facilitating continuous research for the development of new BWMS with better testing methods to insure future BWMS will work.

Title: Comment Submitted by Wenjun Sun, Tsinghua University in Beijing, China
Comment:
Dear Captain Brady,

My name is Wenjun Sun and I am an Associate Professor at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China.  Professor Wenjun Liu and I, on behalf of Tsinghua Disinfection Research Center, had done extensive research and testing of ballast water treatment (BWT) systems in China since 2008.  Our center is one of the centers of excellence in China for studying disinfection science and technologies, including chlorine, ozone, UV, etc. for municipal water and ballast water treatment.   We have conducted full-scale testing of BWT systems.

We have gained significant experimental data over more than 10 years which prove that the most probable number (MPN) method is a very appropriate method for measuring viable organisms in ballast water after treatment with ballast water management systems (BWMS), particularly for UV based systems.   
I do not agree with the Draft Policy Letter statement that there are no "type-approval testing protocols for BWMS that render nonviable organisms in ballast water that are based on the best available science."  The MPN methodology is used regularly in IMO type-approval testing of BWMS.  That methodology is correct when nonviable means "permanently incapable of reproduction", because it provides more than enough time (weeks) for organisms to dark-repair and photo-repair (hours) (Hull et al. 2017).  Repair happens right away (Sancar and Sancar 1998, Sinha and Hader 2002), and both dark-repair and photo-repair happens toghether when the lights are on.  

Water treatment of ballast water is a new application compared to water treatment of drinking water and wastewater which has many decades of experience.  We can look at that experience and knowledge to help learn for ballast water treatment.  In China, as in the United States and all other countries that have water treatment regulations, culture methods like MPN are used to make sure the water is safe for people to drink and safe to go to the environment.  No method is described as used for organisms that are "permanently incapable of reproduction", so we need to think if they would be, and because the culture methods give time to repair, they do show this.  The same applies to ballast water organisms, culture methods like MPN give time for repair to happen and can be used to test systems that "render organisms nonviable permanently incapable of reproduction".  It is probably why culture methods are used for bacteria in ballast water (ETV 2010) even though those methods do not have "permanent inactivation" in their titles.  

The USCG should adopt IMO MPN methodology because it is available right now, it matches for  organisms that are permanently incapable of reproduction, and it is supported by the best available science.  

With respect,


Dr. Wenjun Sun, Associate Professor
School of Environment
Tsinghua University

Title: Comment Submitted by Cees van Slooten
Comment:
The present USCG method for measuring 10-50 m organisms is to count organisms following a vitality (life-dead) assay which determines the esterase activity of intact cells as proxy for vitality. 
It is noted that in the context of ballast water mediated invasions of organisms the ability to reproduce is more relevant than the vitality of the transferred organisms. 
Determining the ability to reproduce is commonly defined as "Viability testing"

CUC IL deems that 'Viability testing' is an appropriate way to evaluate ballast water treatment systems because it determines the ability of organisms to reproduce after being discharged into a new environment.

Viability testing is a widely accepted method to analyze the <10 m fraction using the Most-Probable-Number (MPN) technique, such as the EPA-accepted Colilert and Enterolert methods from IDEXX for E. coli and enterococci.

Internationally, MPN-based assays for the 10-50m fraction are widely accepted in the ballast water test community. 
As demonstrated by DNV GL and associated sublabs, there is ample scientific support for the reliability of aforementioned  MPN-based assays.

In conclusion, CUC IL endorses and supports the inclusion of an MPN-based assay for the 10-50 m fraction in the context of USCG Type Approval testing of ballast water management systems. 

With kind regards,
Cees van Slooten
CUC-IL Coordinator

Title: Comment Submitted by Karl Linden, University of Colorado Boulder
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment.  In this comment submitted via attachment, plus supporting documents, we reiterate the value and validity of the MPN method for determining performance of ballast water management systems (BWMS) that permanently render organisms incapable of reproduction and argue for its adoption by the USCG.  Eleven internationally known and well respected scientists and engineers have signed on to this opinion.

While the USCG claim to have no knowledge of an MPN method based on best available science, we cite 12 peer-reviewed scientific publications related to use of an MPN method for BWMS that have been published since 2015.  Many of these evaluate UV-based disinfection processes.  We also note that the MPN method is an accepted method for International Maritime Organization (IMO) type-approval testing.  We review evidence as to why culture-based methods implicitly include any repair or reactivation in their assessment, and determine permanent inactivation of relevant organisms for BWM for UV-based or oxidant based disinfectants. We also note that every major public health regulation world-wide accepts the use of culture-based methods, such as the MPN method for assessing protection of public health.

We conclude that 
	UV disinfection is a safe and effective means for permanently inactivating prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms with decades of research backing this fact.
	Culture methods such as MPN are accepted under US federal regulation for use in drinking water and wastewater compliance testing and public health monitoring, and other than some of the organisms in ballast water in the USA, are the standard for regulated methods around the world.
	The algae MPN-based method utilizes an extended period of light exposure that would incorporate any possibility of photo-repair and light-independent repair, and is conservative for determining viability of UV disinfected organisms.
	UV is effective and works at very low doses for organisms of concern in BWMS, thus it is an economical option for treatment and should be an available technology for the maritime industry.

Please see attached for the detailed comment and supporting attachments.

Title: Comment Submitted by Stephen Jones, 4Deep Inwater Imaging (4Deep)
Comment: 4Deep Inwater Imaging (4Deep), is a globally-recognized Nova Scotia based company that develops proprietary holographic microscopy technologies: Digital In-line Holographic Microscopic (DIHM)  Imaging, and related software for near real-time classification of organisms in water columns. (See, http://4-deep.com/about/company/.)  The final version of the Draft Policy Letter should take into account the potential for DIHM technology to open the window to a new, more precise level of investigation for harmful microorganisms that are present and transported globally within the ballast tanks of ships. Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Mr. Captain Sean T. Brady,

We are a US based, EPA registered FIFRA pesticide used for water treatment, biofilm removal and as a medical grade disinfectant, sanitizer, algaecide, fungicide and biocide. 

After reviewing the Ballast Water treatment programs, we propose the use of a newer product option, which utilizes nanotechnology to eradicate mollusks, pathogens, barnacles and other fouling agents within the ballast tanks. 

Our technology is implemented with ease, and simplicity whereas past and current product options require significant infrastructure, chemical generation equipment, multiple product programs, and gallons of liquid chemicals to be stored on ships where space and weight are commodities. The solution provided by our Company provides logistic advantages, reduced storage mass, and ease of use which is not currently utilized while enhancing ship and crew safety.

The currently proposed range of technologies using chlorine products, peracetic acid or hydrogen peroxide do not treat biofilm passively.  Chlorine and peracetic acids are not capable of preventing bio-adaptation which is critical in emergent and invasive species. Chlorine, peracetic acid and hydrogen peroxide are not stable in vacillating pH ranges. Chlorine is not stable beyond pH 7.8-8.0. These and other proposed chemical options can create toxic by-products making them a poor choice for aquatic ecosystems and environments.  

Chlorine dioxides used in ballast tank treatments are archaic technologies which use generated chlorine dioxide, sulfuric acid and other toxic chemicals to produce a chlorine dioxide product. Though they do remove biofilm, these outdated techniques require large volumes of liquid chemical to be stored and do not provide logistic advantages. 
 
Utilizing our technology removes the above barriers, and provides a stable chemical, and safer environment for the ship, crew and aquatic life. Our technology is a tablet or powder form which creates only Na (sodium) as a byproduct making it a safer solution for aquatic life. Currently EPA registered for water treatment and as a Medical Grade disinfectant, we can reduce the bioburden and pathogen load with up to 8-log reductions in less than 5 minutes while lowering the mass of chemicals storage on a ship and provide safer and simpler solutions for dry dock ballast treatments as well. 

The chemistry has a quick activation time to provide efficient results in seconds where sudden ejection of ballast tank contents could have resulted in catastrophic outcomes for the environment and aquatic life using other technologies. 
It is our recommendation our chemistry be utilized in dry dock ballast treatments and cleaning protocols to provide a superior method of pathogen eradication and safe residual biofilm reduction. 

We are proud to present better solutions to protect waters from invasive and emergent species and pathogens today and for a safer future. Our technology provides better and safer solutions even when ships are required to reduce ballast contents quickly. 

We look forward to hearing from you. We are fully engaged in utilizing US Coast Guard and EPA compliant solutions which are smarter, safer and provide superior logistic advantages to the current market solutions.  

Please contact us for additional technical data.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert La Barbera
Comment:
I am respectfully submitting a comment in OPPOSITION to NPRM USCG-2019-0508, Titled "Battle of the Bridges", to be held in Venice, Florida on September 28th, 2019 from 6:00 AM - 6:00 PM.  This comment is submitted within the comment period which ends September 3, 2019.
This event is being conducted by an entity that has a privately owned racing facility built to its specifications and paid for by public tax dollars.

*  The location is not good as it is a choke point along the ICW.  There are NO alternate routes.  There are numerous other safe locations this event could be held, specifically the publicly funded, yet private facility built for the Sarasota Scullers at the World Class Benderson Park, Sarasota Bay, Blackburn Bay, Lemon Bay and numerous other locations.

*  The length of time of the shutdown is excessive (twelve hours).

* The Day of the week is least conducive to a complete waterway shutdown.  This can be held during the week or at non-peak hours.

*The location of the proposed command center (launch) for this race is a major Boat Ramp paid for by boating taxpayers.  While this boat ramp is physically located within the City of Venice, it is owned and managed by Sarasota County.  Residents from all over Sarasota County utilize this facility and it is one of the largest and busiest.  Shutting down this ramp on a Saturday (arguably the busiest boating day of the week) will be a hindrance to the overall good of the boating community. In reality, however, the ramp is shut down to public access the day PRIOR for set up, translating into a TWO DAY Closure.
