Title: Comment Submitted by Jack Shrode
Comment:
I am respectfully submitting a comment in OPPOSITION to NPRM USCG-2019-0508, Titled "Battle of the Bridges", to be held in Venice, Florida on September 28th, 2019 from 6:00 AM - 6:00 PM.  This comment is submitted within the comment period which ends September 3, 2019.

The event last year was such a planning failure that it received very minimal participation and even fewer spectators.  It was such a bust that the event was shut down early, but boaters were still negatively impacted and were not notified of the early stoppage. It was NOT shut down early as a consolation to boaters; they simply had no participation in the race.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I do not support this action. It is not fair to the rest of the Venice boating community to have the ICW shut down and not accessible to other boaters that are not part of this event. A boat should not be forced to go into the Gulf because they've been denied access to the ICW. These are public waterways and if it isn't safe for the event to be ran in this public area as is, then the event should be taken elsewhere.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: As a Venice resident and boater, I am in opposition of closing the public boat launch for this event that should have never happened to begin with.  Who in their right mind would propose closing off the ICW for a sport.

Title: Comment Submitted by Dylan Lindemuth
Comment:
I name is Dylan I am the dockmaster at fishermans wharf marina located in Venice Florida. Im writing this today to hopefully bring to light how the battle of the regattas affects our business here. We have about 63 slips total, Most of which are filled with avid boaters.  Within those slips is A rental boat company with a fleet of six boats and also waves boat and social club with their fleet consisting of nine boats. We get lots of boat traffic here on the weekends especially with our fuel dock being conveniently placed on the ICW. Not to mention we have a restaurant on the property that gets a fair amount of customers from the water. As if the red tide wasnt enough to hurt our business last year then we also had one whole day where boaters couldnt come in or out at the marina because of this regatta. 
Im sure there is a time and place for this to take place, but just on our property alone we have 4 different Businesses, Ill greatly affected by this event. We are one of three marinas in the local area affected by this 

Please call for anything 941-893-7870

Title: Comment Submitted by Mike W.
Comment:
Please excuse my language but this is complete BS!

Whos palms are being greased by the rich parents of all these sculler kids!?

Why cant they use Benderson Park the facility that was built exclusively for them!?

They have already taken over the public park north of the Casey key fish house.

Closing a public ramp and public waterway for these privileged kids .....Id say unbelievable but hey, $$$$$$.

Anyway I can get on the scullers payroll???

EXTREMELY OPPOSED!!!!!!!

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This will be a major inconvenience for traffic and businesses. I am opposed to this event

Title: Comment Submitted by Mike B.
Comment: So explain this to me.  I am a registered boat owner in the state of Florida and live in Venice.  I patronize the local businesses and restaurants via boat quite often. Why would you grant permission to a row boat race that currently has a facility to practice and play in Benderson park?  Have you considered or are you considering the impact on the local boaters?  The economy of the local restaurants, gas stations, bait supply stores, etc.?  What about the safety concerns of those who would be forced to commute North or South via the Gulf of Mexico?  Its my understanding that my boat registration dollars go towards boat ramps and other needs of the intercostal waterway.  Do these vessels requesting the race pay ANY registration fees?  I think not. I hope you consider all the above before you punish the entire rest of the area who does support this closure.  Its fine to share the waterway.  This is not a case of sharing.  MIKE B.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I think this is a good rule even though inconvenient for boating.
It should be reviewed each year to assess whether it is of benefit to the Venice community.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I am strongly opposed to this proposed rule and shutdown. It is an unnecessarily long shutdown on a weekend day during a time of the year local waterfront restaurants, wait staff, marinas, bait shops, and their respective staff are struggling to make a paycheck. This private Sarasota club is not vested and unengaged in Venice boating and does not possess local knowledge of this area. There are No alternate routes and this will undoubtedly force inexperienced boaters into the Gulf. This is ridiculous and a safety factor that was overlooked.  Who will take ownership of any incidents?Boat owners pay registration fees that fund the boat ramp. These rowboats pay no vessel registrations. How can the decision makers give exclusive access to an outside entity that does not fund the ramp and take it away from those that do, regardless if its 12 hours or 12 minutes? The coast guard (probably in Miami) is charged with deciding whether to allow this event but the concern is they dont have a feel for the Local intimacies of our boaters, the uniqueness of the proposed Venue and its impact on the locals. The Local government agencies should not be supporting this. The boaters are very disappointed. Local government should be Building Bridges with the local boaters, not Battling Bridges.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Shutting down the ICW is going to directly and negatively impact the local professional and recreational boating community far more than seems to be recognized. Having it shut down on a weekend day is taking away work for local restaurants, marinas and deterring people from local activities that support our local economy in our slow season. Why are we shutting down the ICW when we have a massive built-out facility at Benderson Park to be able to accommodate these types of events without interrupting anyones weekend business or plans? Last year wasnt even close to being successful, I cant imagine this year could be any closer to a success if were going to continue to allow poor planning and execution to take place. Please reconsider the idea of shutting down the ICW.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I oppose. I work at a local business that will be negatively affected.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jim Cranston
Comment:
Dear Sirs:

The Battle of the Bridges event on September 28th, 2019, would stop boater related activities on the ICW from Stump Pass to the Venice outlet. This is very inconvenient to local businesses, marinas and recreational boaters. The following comments are germane:

1. Last years even had only a couple of entrants, and community interest was minimal...yet access was still denied.
2. When the rowing club has access to Benderson Park, which was built (at great cost) for just this purpose, why is the event not held there?
3. The negative effect on local businesses (i.e. boat fueling, boat rentals, boat fishing charters, etc.), local marina operations and recreational boaters far exceeds minimal commercial revenues from such a small venue.
4. The event organizers have displayed "bullying" behavior toward the local community at large, and seem to avoid local (boating) community involvement, as evidenced last year and again this year.

Please cancel this event and inform the organizers of the displeasure they have evoked.

Jim Cranston, CDR/USN(Ret)
860-884-1233

Title: Comment Submitted by B. Bozeman
Comment:
I am supportive of the Battle of the Bridges event.   This is a great event that brings exposure to our lovely community (outside locals) and fosters youth responsible and relationships.

This event is not any different than the annual parade, private runs/marathons, etc. that require street closures.  So for those against this event does that mean you don't support any event in Venice that could be impactful to businesses or locals?  This is a once a year event that has minimal impactful to a very select number of businesses.  Unlike other events Venice sponsors which impact dozens of businesses.

It is also unfair to state this event was "unsuccessful" when the comments are being made by people that do not have direct or first hand knowledge.  I encourage all those against to become involved and see what a great event and program it is.

Let's support our youth!

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I support closing the Venice Intracoastal Waterway for the Battle of the Bridges.  Battle of the Bridges provides a much needed boost to the local economy during the traditionally slowest economic time of the year.  The attendees stay at least 2-3 days in the community.  Hotels, restaurants and retail stores benefit from the many athletes, coaches, and family members who participate and/or attend this event.  Closing the waterway for a few hours benefits many more people than the few who claim a negative impact.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeff Koehler
Comment: I am writing in support of this request.   I am no longer associated with this organization but I do have extensive experience running regattas in other venues and the clubs do their best to be good stewards and minimize any negative impact.  I believe that the positives for Venice and the surrounding area as a result of this regatta, including bringing in many people from out of town, will far exceed any potential negative impact.  From a local perspective, youth sports -- and rowing in particular -- teach our young people to be better citizens throughout their lifetime.   Rowing demands a personal commitment beyond most other sports while also teaching respect of authority and a love of nature.  I believe our community should nurture youth sports, and that the request to limit waterway access in this area for 1 day out of an annual total of 104 weekend days is a very reasonable request.

Title: Comment Submitted by Denise Fisher
Comment:
I feel the water- way in Venice should be used by all. The Battle of the Bridges last year was wonderful. The old and young gathered along the grasses and walked among our local store.
 Its an asset for the community.

Title: Comment Submitted by Karen Mischak
Comment: I am in support of USCG-2019-0508, the Battle of the Bridges Regatta, Sat, Sept 28th. It is a great opportunity for the youth and adult rowers alike.

Title: Comment Submitted by Captain James Bostwick
Comment: This event directly effects many local bussiness negatively at a time when it needs every customer.. i personaly saw last year the small turnout for event.. this event should be held at lake where county funds were used for hosting such event. The waterway was never intented for such event nor does the local citzens  support it.. There is a long list of negative impacts by hosting this event at proposted area. Last year proved it was a bad idea not sure why would be considered again. PLEASE do not grant this and if you do . Take a look at its results..will be very similar as 2018 results. The area was set up for local  tax paying boaters not  such events.

Title: Comment Submitted by Timothy Howard
Comment:
I am against the exclusive use of the ICW for these types of events.  It's clear to me that this is a private club that has public provided facilities for their use.  The ICW in Venice is an arterial transportation provider for the use of all boaters, etc.  As a long time boater, I find closure of the ICW as an affront to my rights an do not wish these types of events to curtail my rights.  In a parallel sense, suppose I request the 12 hour closure of I-75 because my auto club wants to conduct a drag racing competition.
Seriously, the rowers have their stadium in which they can participate.  The idea that they want to curtail my rights and the rights of other tax payers is obnoxious to me.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This event directly impacts my small business. The event is scheduled for a weekend which is when we are the busiest. My business keeps a boat at Marine Max in Venice, so I am unable to do business due to this event. The economic impact is felt by my business and the people I hire. These employees live paycheck to paycheck and cannot afford to lose even a days pay. Please consider moving or partitioning this event so that commerce can continue in this area of the Intracoastal Waterway.

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Appell
Comment:
I was a volunteer for this event last year and was stationed at the finish line and got to see all the young adults cross. Talking with them they loved the venue of rowing in the intercoast with no onterference from transit boats and fear of being run over ar tipped over from boat wakes of inconsiderate captains driving larger boats. The event was over earlier than expected and a minor inconvenience.
Please help promote boating safety for this event by closing the water way.

Title: Comment Submitted by Clemens Reiss
Comment:
I was the US Rowing Chief Referee for the "Battle of the Bridges" regatta last year. The number one priority for US Rowing is safety. Because three bridges are part of this regatta course, it is very important that vessel traffic is controlled during the regatta. Danger of collision can be a serious matter because the boats rowers are using offer little protection.

Last years regatta ran well because only approved regatta support power boats were on the course. The regatta finished early and the waterway was reopened early.

I have been involved with other regattas on the intercostal waterway as a rower and an official where the regatta did not restrict vessel traffic. In every case, safety issues caused races to be stopped. Most boaters are very respectful of others using the waterway but unfortunately you never know when one boat will put others at unnecessary risk.

With the current concern over toxic flesh eating algae in the gulf which caused death to individuals with open wounds, the risk of swamping a rower are higher than ever.

While the economic concerns of businesses are valid, it is hoped that safety will remain the top priority.

Venice has a proud tradition of supporting sports and become the best in the state in multiple years. Rowing is a rapidly growing sport in Florida but this the only rowing regatta in Venice the entire year.

In closing, I would like thank the USCG for the important support it is giving to boater safety.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This is an outstanding event for the Venice Community.  As a boater I certainly can make the necessary arrangements to launch my boat and avoid this safety zone for a few hours.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I Spend a great deal of time on Venice waters and it is absolutely incomprehensible to me this is even being discussed.  I Wasnt going to comment on this at first for fear I was being Punkd.  It may sound cliche, but Cmon man !
In reading some of these out of touch emotional comments in support of this nonsense, those made by last years referee Clemens Reis jump out the most. The number one priority is safety.  Its very important vessel traffic is controlled.  Danger of collision can be serious. ...little protection.  Safety issues caused the race to be stopped.  Put others at unnecessary risk.  It gets really melodramatic here,flesh eating bacteria. Death to individuals.  Open wounds.
Wow!  What parent in their right mind would put their kid into such danger?  Man, its so dangerous, someone outta buy you your own private facility where crazy boaters, deadly flesh eating bacteria, and deplorables struggling to earn a buck wont cause such chaos.  
Oh wait........  That already happened. Cmon Venice,  youre better than this nonsense.  If US Rowing is so focused on safety take it to your lake.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
strongly oppose!

Use benderson park - a internationally known venue located nearby which is specifically designed for these type events.

Doing so would keep the public waterway open, and provide for a much greater degree of safety for the participants.

Title: Comment Submitted by R. D.
Comment: I oppose this.  It is not fair or reasonable to limit the public's access to boating, fishing, recreation.  The maintenance of both the ICW and the launch site are paid for by taxpayers' dollars.  Thus, open access should be maintained to the general public at all times.

Title: Comment Submitted by Cory Elliott
Comment: Hi i work at fishermans wharf marina for waves boat and social club. This event is going to mess up my pay check. My members will not be able to go out and i will not get tips or the hours i need to pay my bills.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I work along the intercoastal waterway and last year this event blocked off all access to marina/restaurant by water. Theres 4 different buisnesses on this land alone restraunt rental company boat club marina exc. All employees including myself are affected by this event and will not be compensated reimbursed for any loss in business/ tips. That being said there is a time and a place for everything and to block off the intercoastal waterway on a weekend day is a complete inconvience in my opinion.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rita Ferrandino
Comment: As a small business owner, parent and concerned community member, I strongly support the Battle of the Bridges proposal.  This event will bring new people to our community who will eat, shop and support our community.  The economic benefits far outweigh any small inconveniences.

Title: Comment Submitted by Douglas Worth
Comment: I am very much in opposition of this event. As an active boater who uses this waterway every weekend and pays expensive dockage I do not feel as though that it is right that a private entity should should take away my ability to enjoy a public Waterway. This organization has its own facilities which taxpayers paid for in Sarasota at Benderson Park. To shut down a heavily-traveled Waterway what could force boaters to navigate outside of the icw which could be dangerous if the weather is bad or their boats are not safely able to handle Heavy Seas is dangerous at best. To inconvenience the boating community to this extent for a  private group is not right. I can only hope that the Coast Guard does what's right for the boating community as a whole and denies the permit for this event sincerely Douglas worth

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I am not sure why you would want to shutdown the ICW and push small boats out onto the Gulf. Especially for such a low attended event. I am not sure the risk is worth the gain. I am an active boater and observed the event last year. I am not sure why the operators of the event were not required to adhere to basic boating safety recommendations and legal requirements (see attached photo). I think once was enough and the risk and cost of the event far outweighs what little gain there might be.

Title: Comment Submitted by James Anderson
Comment:
I am in support the waterway being closed / restricted for the event. I rowed the Sarasota 5000 regatta that used to be held further north on the Intracoastal waterway and powerboat traffic always made the situation dangerous for the smaller boats. Boats regularly had excessive wakes that can cause major issues for the small rowing shells. 
Restricting power boat traffic is absolutely critical to maintain safety for the rowers on the water.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeanette Leiter
Comment:
I support Battle of Bridges in Venice.  It is a great event for all.  Young and old enjoy seeing this event.  Closing water for one day is a small safferice for supporting Venice youth and Master rowers that will be coming from all over Florida and beyond to enter this event and enjoy the beutiful Venice area. 

Jeanette Leiter

Title: Comment Submitted by Seth K.
Comment: I support the Battle of the Bridges event in Venice.  The fact is that the event was a success last year!  The impact on boat traffic and local businesses was minimal.  I would suggest that given time for the event to grow, there would be a significant positive impact on businesses in the area.  Of note, the timing of the regatta is typically a very slow time of the year for Southwest Florida further negating any negative impacts.  Most important reason to move forward with the rule change:  precedent was sent last year with a very positive outcome.

Title: Comment Submitted by John [Last Name Unknown]
Comment:
Regarding the Battle of the Bridges rowing event USCG-2019-0508, I am opposed to this taking place. 

   As a resident of Venice for nearly 50 years, owner of multiple registered vessels in Sarasota County, and tax paying citizen, this event needs to be relocated to a different venue, preferably their private World Class tax-payer funded Benderson Park.
 
   Here are just a few reasons and questions for my opposition:
 
   Why have boaters not been a part of this planning?  The below e-mail thread speaks volumes. 
 
Battle of the Bridges 2019
John Holic <JHolic@Venicegov.com>
Hi Danielle,
December 3, 6, or 10 would work for an afternoon meeting.  It can be just us and meet at a neutral place or anyone else that you wish to meet with and we can use City Hall. Shirley Gibson schedules our special events, Roger Clark is in planning and is very familiar with what can and cant be done as is City Engineer Kathleen Weeden.
Let me know and where, when and with whom and Ill set it up.
John
John Holic
Mayor, City of Venice
 
From: Danielle
Sent: Sunday, November 18, 2018 9:51 PM
To: John Holic
Subject: Battle of the Bridges 2019
Good afternoon Major Holic.
 
I was wondering if in the next few weeks you might have 30 minutes for me to talk about the Battle of the Bridges rowing regatta.
 
It is a rowing event we at Sarasota Scullers hosted last year in Venice. We are looking at next years event and before we more forward we wanted to get input from you and the City. I would like to keep the meeting small if possible. 
 
A late afternoon appointment would be best for me so I can come after school.
 
Look forward to seeing you soon,
Danielle
 
http://battleofthebridgesregatta.com/

   Why is there no wiggle room for compromise on any of this?  Lets be realistic, a twelve-hour COMPLETE SHUTDOWN of the Main and only Navigable thoroughfare?  Why cant there be some concessions on the part of the race organizers?  Why cant vessels be escorted and allowed to slowly and safely pass through at designated times?  
 
   Im not opposed to this group, just this plan.   The below link to an ABC 7 Sarasota You Tube video from last years event, specifically the interview with "Julie towards the end, highlights the unfortunate, but real disconnect between this small rowboat group and the larger boating community.
 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GeUJYkVFJlI
 
   Venice Train Station boat ramp is closed for the day of the event and a significant part of the day prior for set-up.  Last year the floating docks were installed around 11:00 am the day before; the group declaring Docks in on their Facebook page. This ramp is used in the evening hours for sunset cruises, dinner at waterfront restaurants (Old Salty Dog, Marker 4, Pops, Crows Nest, etc.), evening fishing, etc.  They are losing money by this event!  To classify this shutdown as just a few hours as previous commenters have mentioned is not factual.  As Denise Fisher stated in her comment (Public Submission ID: USCG-2019-0508-0027) I feel the water- way in Venice should be used by all.  And by all, I would hope when she truly means All, especially the ones who pay extra taxes to access and maintain said waterway.  If thats what she means, I agree.
 
   Many boaters have smaller vessels that are not safe to enter the Gulf of Mexico in anything less than stellar conditions. Doesnt the USCG advocate for safe boating?    Why has this been overlooked?
 
    Marine Max marina at the south bridge on the ICW accommodates hundreds of vessels and Fishermans Wharf to the north has in excess of sixty.  Additionally, Country Club Estates on the Island and Harbor Lights Cooperative, LLC. would add an additional forty vessels.  That is a LOT of boats in a very small  area, not including boats that are launched at the Train Depot.
 
  It has recently been stated by the race organizer that all the permits have ALREADY been approved by the City and USCG.  That is FACTUALLY NOT TRUE.  These marinas believe they have no choice but to acquiesce and go along and accept whatever Concessions the race organizer feels appropriate.  Fishermans Wharf was actually asked to produce sales receipts to prove their losses.  Please have a rep from any government agency supporting this race call the businesses and ask.  It will be an eye opener!  Marine Max 941 485-3388, Fishermans Wharf 941 893-7870.  Businesses are FLAT OUT being Bullied into believing everything is already approved, just like last year!  Local businesses are losing money with this proposed event!
 
   Again, this event needs to be relocated to an area that will not impact registered boaters safe voyages.   Compromises have not been explored- but should.  Let both sides win.  Please be an ambassador and build positive relationships with local boaters.  

   Endeavour to BUILD BRIDGES with the local boaters, rather than BATTLE THEM.

Title: Comment Submitted by Amanda Duff
Comment:
I am writing in FULL SUPPORT of the Battle of the Bridges regatta in Venice (docket number USCG-2019-0508). This event provides an incredible opportunity to not only provide visibility to and help grow the sport of rowing, but also to bring volumes of people to the Venice area who would not otherwise be here to patronize our local businesses. Given that this event occurs in September, which is our slowest time of year, this event has the potential to help many local businesses. 

Kudos to Venice for hosting this event!

Title: Comment Submitted by Daniel Gerdes
Comment: This event is a great way to show off the diverse population we have in Venice and Sarasota.  It will bring athletes, their parents and coaches to the Venice from all over the state.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Why are businesses, boaters, and sponsors being told by the organizer that the permits are issued already and they have no choice but to shut down for the day???  The simple fact that this proposed rule is out for public comment validates the uscg has NOT issued any permits. The city of Venice will not issue their permits until the uscg issues their permit and it is obvious that the small business impact has not been explored and has been grossly underestimated.  If I were a sponsor that already ponied up money for this Id be asking the organizers plain and simple, do you have the necessary permits and can I get a copy. If they answer truthfully, they will learn no permits have been issued and I would be requesting a refund. Integrity and character are still important, arent they?   If I were a sponsor considering this, Id ask the same question and then run in the other direction. If I were an out of town team or participant, I would not put deposits on this event, entry fees , travel expenses, hotels etc.   Simple question:  does this group have the permits , yes or no?  They organizers are big Facebook posters, maybe they can post copies of all permits there for all to see.  Anyone left to believe that they have the permits should call the city of Venice and the USCG. Some already have and the answer is NO!  Integrity, character , honesty- those things still matter, to some!

Title: Comment Submitted by Dawn Beller, Sarasota Scullers Youth Rowing Program
Comment:
This regatta has the potential to have a powerful impact connecting our community with the rowing community we share with our neighbors at Nathan Benderson Park. It is a win-win situation for all involved. The support of The Coast Guard for this yearly event is much appreciated by the Sarasota Scullers Youth Rowing Program, which is hosting this regatta, along with the City of Venice. 
Thank you for your continued support.
Dawn Beiler
SSYRP Board Member

Title: Comment Submitted by Chelsea [Last Name Unknown]
Comment: I work at the Salty Dog Restaurant located  at Marine Max and I am extremely opposed to this   I am a single mother of two young children and simply cannot afford to lose a single dollar let alone a full days pay. All of my coworkers from waitresses, hostesses, bartenders and cooks feel the same way. Please do not allow this at the service industrys slowest time of the year. Saturday is our busiest day. Please take this to your private rowboat park.

Title: Comment Submitted by Greg Wood
Comment:
I strongly SUPPORT the Battle of the Bridges Regatta and the temporary closure of this waterway. A large number of participants, spectators and supporters, from around the state will come to this event, boosting the local economy.  Many will even eat at the restaurants that are opposing this minor closure of the waterway.  

Events like this happen around the USA to promote sporting events, youth development, and to help stimulate the local economy.  This closure is minor in comparison to events held in other heavy traffic waterways. 

Support your local non-profits and community. Support the measure.

Title: Comment Submitted by Nathan C.
Comment: I support the Battle of the Bridges and the closure of the water way.  This event provides a nice break to the eco system for the day. And introduces people to areas water who may not have had the opportunity or reason to venture to Venice. I am a boater myself and it is not a big deal to go the other way.

Title: Comment Submitted by Michael Penn
Comment:
As a 40 year resident of Sarasota County, I am in full SUPPORT of closing this waterway for a day. This race impacts positively in an economic sense to help make Sarasota a rowing capital of the world. Thus it helped to make Sarasota the site of the World Championships for rowing and promises to do again. 

Thousands of youth have gone on to college because they were members of this rowing club. Many have become outstanding professionals, who have learned to excel in life because of this highly demanding rowing program. 

The national exposure from this race and others helps to put Sarasota on the map and support local businesses. 

As a boater and local resident, I highly recommend closing this waterway for one measly day.

Title: Comment Submitted by Christine Johns
Comment: I support use of the Intracoastal Waterway for Battle of the Bridges for many reasons: It gives local athletes the ability to support their local community by hosting an event in Venice, Rowing is a sport that is rising in popularity and has the potential to draw thousands of dollars of revenue into the community, it gives rowing clubs within and outside of the State the opportunity to visit our great City of Venice and to see all it has to offers, Events such as this do nothing but support the local economy due to the influx of people participating in and spectating the event. I fish, I boat, I support local business, I own a local business. I can see NO reason why the entire community of Venice wouldn't be 100% behind an event such as this. Those businesses that feel they would be hurt should come to the event and have a booth to sponsor their business during the event time. What a great way for your business to show support as well as gain business. Let's keep this event happening in our community!

Title: Comment Submitted by Manny [Last Name Unknown]
Comment: Closing this section of waterway for any extended period of time is a horrible idea. Not only will it have a negative impact on local restaurants and charter captains.  It will affect non commercial boaters as well, no one will be able to leave marine max or mark four. Also closing the largest boat ramp in the area with no alternative is absurd.  Not to mention the only way to  Bypass this section of waterway to head North or South will only be from the gulf. Now that doesn't sound so bad, until you consider you're either leaving the Venice inlet to go to stump pass or vice versa. That's a considerable distance of open water.  Truth be told there are many boaters out there that don't have the knowledge to navigate open waters if the weather turns for the worst.  So you can see how this affects this area in a very negative manner. We would not close I 75  to host a Drag Racing event that would be ridiculous, but that is exactly what we're doing with this stretch of waterway.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rosemary McMullin
Comment: As a resident and business owner in sarasota county, I fully support the closure of the waterways in order to accommodate Battle of the Bridges. This event is positive for our community and gives the youth in the area a chance to display their skills utilizing strength and teamwork on the water.

Title: Comment Submitted by Angela Anonymous
Comment: This is a great event.  Attended this last year and would highly recommend it continues.  Great publicity towards the community brining needed business to our area this time of year. Creating events during slower seasonal times of the year helps local businesses through the struggle of off season.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ben C
Comment: I strongly support this event. The Battle of Bridges is a rowing regatta which provides the opportunity to promote Venice. Rowing clubs from all over the states, rowers from young to old, attend this event and what a great way to get the city of Venice's name out there.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: They need to go to Sarasota where they have a place specifically for that!!!!!!!!

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I think its ridiculous that we have a multi million dollar rowing park  that we are all as taxpayers paying for  and that this event is going to cause the closure of the intercoastal waterway to fisherman and other boaters, and cut off an entire marina and restaurant and boat ramp for a day.  Did the organizers of this event plan to reimburse the marina and the restaurant for the loss of income for the day? Im sure not.  Use the million dollar lake in the north end of the county for rowing and stay out of the ICW

Title: Comment Submitted by Greg [Last Name Unknown]
Comment:
It is ludicrous to close an entire section of the intracoastal waterway for any purpose,  the intracoastal waterway is for the use of all boaters not for a single group.  Closing it for any amount of time (especially a whole day during a weekend) will have a negative impact on many people.  This section of the intracoastal contains a major marina that houses hundreds of peoples boats that they will be unable to use on top of the marina losing revenue from the restaurant and fuel dock,  there is also a heavily used public boat ramp that will be unusable on a saturday.  There is a designated area for these races that millions of dollars was spent to build, utilize this area for your regatta and prevent negatively affecting many others for a small group.


https://www.escape-to-sarasota.com/benderson-park.html

Just in case you are unaware- I have provided the link to the multi-million dollar rowing park located just up the road.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ruth Rower
Comment:
I am IN FAVOR of closing the Intracoastal waterway for this event.  

This is an excellent opportunity to support the youth who are running this event as well as those who are racing.  This waterway presents another way that Venice shows what a great community we are.

This race is a 5K race.  The course at Nathan Benderson Park is a 2K course.  The timing of this race provides an excellent starting point for the Head Race (or 5K) season.

Last year it was great fun to see the number of people enjoying the race on both sides of the intracoastal - some were sitting on their own lawns and some were sitting/standing on the sidewalk.

I realize this could cause an inconvenience for some but I think there are many times when we give up convenience to support good causes.  I believe our youth are a good cause.

Thank you for doing this for all of the racers - both youth and adults!

Title: Comment Submitted by Suzette Trainor
Comment: As a novice rower I am so looking forward to this event not only because its people friendly for all to come out and watch but it brings attention to such an awesome sport for anyone who may want to try it. There will be some awesome rowers out there on the water and itd be a lot of fun cheering us all on! Please be gracious to those who are willing to let us enjoy this part of the water for a short period of time and then its back to being open to all! Sharing is always a good trait to have.

Title: Comment Submitted by William Eisnor
Comment: This event is very important to the economy of the area.  It was popular its first time last year.  Athletes come from all over the country to enter this race and they will be spending a great deal of money here.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ray Giannini
Comment:
I have been involved with the sport of rowing as a parent, rower and a coach for almost 20 years. The sport of rowing has become an important part of youth athletics in our 3 county area and to have an event that can showcase the sport for local youth and parents to see plays an important part in the health of the sport in our area. As adults we often go off about getting our kids off the sofa and away from video games, well this sport is the very opportunity parents are looking for. This sport is one that requires effort and dedication by its athletes and the sport provides our youth rowers with camaraderie as well as a sense of being part of a team and working for the good of the team, not just themselves. 

We shouldn't overlook all of the other sports in our area that have facilities (fields & stadiums) on public lands, in our parks and our schools. These dedicated facilities are underutilized and off limits to the very residents of the counties where they are located, even though their tax dollars paid for these facilities and continue to pay for their upkeep.   All the Sarasota Scullers are asking is that a small portion of the Intercoastal Waterway be closed for a 10 to 12 hour time span. That leaves another 364 days and 12 hours for full utilization of the Intercoastal by our boating community. 

The concerns of those who feel their businesses are in jeopardy and that the revenues will be negatively impacted should consider what happens at youth rowing events. As teams from surrounding communities around the State of Florida come into the Venice area for the regatta an amazing thing happens, parents very often travel with their team and spend money in those areas. They make it a day or two where they frequent restaurants, local beaches, shops and department stores to get the things they forgot to bring like lawn chairs, water snacks etc.   Another consideration that has not been mentioned is that by noon time the regatta will already be half over. 

Let's try to work together to not only allow the regatta go off as planned but let's try to work together to see if we can't come up with some creative ideas to make the event more than just a regatta. Let's not gripe about it, but somehow look for somebody or something that can make it more like a local event. That might include those very businesses that feel the regatta will not help their business. Maybe those restaurants and stores could have a booth set-up to sell their food or maybe help create a goodie-bag for the rowers that could include a coupon or menu from their restaurant or information about their businesses. All I'm saying is let's do this for our kids, let's showcase our wonderful area and let's get creative to include resources beyond just the rowers and their families. In closing, many years ago the cities of Boston and Cambridge MA fought to prevent having a regatta called the Head of the Charles Regatta on the Charles River in the Fall. Well somehow it happened and today it is the largest single regatta in the USA and the world with thousands of rowers and upwards of 500,000 spectators annually! I'm not saying that's what we are going for, but just imagine what we can do if we work together. Let' support our kids and have a little fun in the process!

Title: Comment Submitted by Diane Byard
Comment:
I SUPPORT THE CLOSURE of the Intercoastal waterway for the Battle of the Bridges rowing event USCG-2019-0508.
Rowing is a premier attraction for Sarasota County.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rachel [Last Name Unknown]
Comment: I strongly support this event and the closing of the waterway for it. Events such as this serve to help the communities involved by bringing visitors to the area and to support our local youth. These young rowers work out early most every morning on the inter coastal and this event helps to support them.

Title: Comment Submitted by Tamara Currey
Comment: I fully support this Regatta, the battle of the bridges. It is a very short period of time that the Intracoastal will be closed and the financial and greater impact to this community will be of much larger benefit. It is not fair to compare this to NBP, it is a completely different venue. Two of the largest regattas in the country in Boston and Chattanooga attract thousands of athletes and sponsors. Totally stimulating the community and economy for a short amount of time. Last year was the first year, which I participated in as a Master Rower. It was fantastic, run very well and an incredible memory. We need to do it as an annual event during one of our slowest times of the year.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joseph O. Dobson
Comment:
I feel the use of the waterway for a rowing regatta is an excellent use of this resource in the following ways:
1. Promoting healthy ecologically friendly exercise by athletes from all ages starting with youth and extending to senior rowers in their seventies. 
2. Playing a significant role in a consolidated Venice weekend activities scheduled for the weekend. 
3. Positive regional economic impact with many visiting teams staying in local hotel and eating in local restaurants the evening. Score the race.
4. Increase awareness of the benefit of the Intracoastal Waterway as a recreational resource. 
5.  Increase appreciation of USCGs role in waterway safety and control.  
6. Significantly increase the actual traffic in the waterway during the regatta period, with hundreds of athletes on the waterway in place of the very small number of boaters who may be transiting during a very quiet and hot time of the year. 
 Respectfully submitted,
Joseph O Dobson.

Title: Comment Submitted by James Cassata
Comment:
I am totally against this being approved by the USCG for a considerable number of reasons.

First and foremost, there is a multi million dollar rowing facility at Benderson Park specifically for this purpose. Having the contest there proposes no inconvenience to anyone.
To the contrary, having this on the intra coastal negatively affects many such as:

The intra coastal is akin to a public highway much like Interstate 75. Would the Interstate be closed between two exits by special permit for a bike race or marathon during the peak hours of the day?

The negative affect to recreational and commercial boaters would be incalculable both financially and physically.

The potential hazard of forcing all craft to engage the Gulf to continue on a journey north or south would have yet to be known perils facing uncertain sea conditions and inclement weather with no viable flight to safety. We all know many recreational boaters can be less than prudent in their opinion of their seamanship nor the capabilities of their vessel.

A negative effect would prevail for local businesses that rely on dockside patrons, even those not directly between the bridges because it would halt and discourage any travel that day.

The waterway is right to everyone 24/7 not just a select few.

I am certain that a committee came up with this brilliant idea without caring about the impact to hundreds of citizens. Imagine if you will a cruiser navigating from ,say, Pine Island Sound traveling north for a weekend getaway without knowledge of the shutdown. They need to retreat to Stump Pass ( difficult to navigate) or stay at anchor for several hours before being able to proceed on their way. What do they do for rest, bathroom facilities ( if no head onboard), food , water, medical emergency etc.

This is a selfish and short sited plan all for the purpose of a fun competition ( to them) with no regard for others.

I am certain that you will get positive comments motivated by those not seeing a total picture or not caring.

I repeat, it isn't like  they don't have  a perfect option to formulate a fun competition....BENDERSON.

PLEASE don't bend to the will of a few myopic individuals to the potential massive inconvenience of hundreds if not thousands.

Title: Comment Submitted by Cheryl Burke
Comment: I am in favor of the Battle Of The Bridges. As a Sarasota County resident and business owner, this brings great exposure and business to the area at a very slow time of year. People come from all over and stay at hotels, shop in our stores,eat in restaurants and enjoy what our area has to offer. Businesses should try to think outside the box to find ways to attract these rowers, friends and family to frequent their business. How fortunate we are to live in this beautiful area and be able to share it with others.

Title: Comment Submitted by Colin Cornhill
Comment:
Rowing is a sport which provides a healthy community activity for a diverse range of participants.  Visible race events help to promote the sport to the community and help to make connections between rowing participants and the wider community.

The region around the venue of this race has become known as a rowing hub nationally and internationally.  The ongoing success of this event will do much to promote the region as a great destination for visitors and for those who want to make it their home.

The proposed thoughtful management of this resource for one day is a great contribution to healthy community development.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Opposed.  The ICW is for everyones use at all times, not one group.

Title: Comment Submitted by Nikki Navta
Comment:
I FULLY SUPPORT this Regatta, the battle of the bridges. It is a very short period of time that the Intracoastal will be closed to non-rowers. 
While it is an amazing venue, Nathan Benderson Park provides rowers with a completely different experience. A yearly rowing event quite often can start off relatively small, and then as word of mouth spreads and crews add the event to their regular racing schedule, the event can grow quite large. Two of the largest regattas in the country in Boston, MA and Chattanooga, TN attract thousands of athletes and significant sponsorship. 
My primary rowing club is in Pittsburgh, PA. I started guest rowing at SCRC a couple of years ago, and had no idea how lovely the area is. But rowing attracted me to Sarasota, and now a bunch more of my teammates have (at my urging) traveled to Sarasota to row with SCRC and race at NBP. In fact, one of my teammates recently purchased a retirement home in Sarasota.
That's just one example of how the financial impact to the community could be of much larger benefit.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jennifer Krajcir
Comment:
There are several local boaters who will be impacted by the shutdown of the inter coastal on sept 28th for a sculling race.

The biggest issue is this closes our waterway and public ramp down to boaters for the day while scullers have a beautiful multimillion dollar, internationally acclaimed facility and lake dedicated to this activity just 30 mins up the road.

Thank you for allowing the public to comment.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joseph R. Mastandrea
Comment:
I am writing in reference to Docket# USCG-2019-0508. I strongly feel that the proposed "Battle of the Bridges" on Sept 28th,2019 presents a grave SAFETY PROBLEM to all local boaters. 

 In light of another missing boat this week with 2 Firefighters missing on the open seas, the Coast Guard is proposing to FORCE boaters who travel in the ICW from Shamrock Park to include Fisherman's Wharf Marina, to go out into the Gulf of Mexico to get to there desired destination.

There are quite a few weekend boaters who will not know about this shutdown. A number of boaters in smaller crafts will be forced to use Stump Pass.What if there are high winds and bad sea's in the Gulf on that day? Will the Coast Guard assume responsibility for mishaps? Will the City of Venice do the same if there are bad sea's and another lost boat and crew?

On a financial note, local business within the area of the shutdown will not be able to serve their customers on a SATURDAY in the  area's of shutdown .I am a FREEDOM BOAT CLUB MEMBER and I will not be able to use MARINE MAX'S Harbor to go out boating. There are 400 BOATS in that marina as well.No one will be able to use the public ramp at the Train Station on a Saturday as well. 

The Sarasota Scullers have the Benderson Park Rowing Facility built for them, why not use that location and not cause the closing of the ICW ?

In summary, This is a Safety Issue as well as a financial disaster to local business, as well as use of PUBLIC WATERWAYS for exclusive private use.

Sincerely,

Joseph R Mastandrea

Title: Comment Submitted by Roger Navarro
Comment: Many comments touch on Sarasota and Nathan Benderson. This regatta is about Venice and helping put it on the map. It's also about showing off and marketing that our waters are safe to be in and welcoming (red tide has impacted this perception). If you have attended any of the regattas throughout Florida - or anywhere else in the country - you would know that if you're welcoming and offer a safe waterway, thousands of people will come. They will experience the city, it's people, stay at hotels, buy food at grocery stores - or more often, restaurants - and see your business. Visitors won't see any of Venice if they're staying near UTC and spending time and money there, near Nathan Benderson. Saying 'go do this thing in Sarasota because it's nicer than here' is like saying, 'go spend time and money at UTC and the restaurants and hotels around there, not here in Venice.' I don't understand how people don't see this net value. Businesses pay hundreds/thousands of dollars on marketing; this event will bringing people from all over - far and near - to businesses in our area in ways other marketing never will. The business upside doesn't even touch on the obvious benefit of supporting our local youth - and youth from all over. You have a unique thing here in Venice - this part of the intercostal is curved and just the right length to test rowers in very different ways than a straight course does. Nathan Benderson is like drag racing, whereas Venice's Battle of the Bridges 'head race' is more like motocross; both skills are needed for our growing rowers to compete and win nationally and internationally.

Title: Comment Submitted by Frank Goody
Comment:
I am commenting on Docket # USCG-2019-0508: I believe it could be dangerous to force boaters to use the Gulf of Mexico to try to get to their destination. Some of the boaters will not be familiar with other passes. Stump pass is not the best pass for someone to try to navigate for the first time. Also, closing the ICW for 12 hours may benefit a VERY, SELECT FEW BUSINESS
OWNERS at the expense of other business owners, commercial boats, and the boating public.  Some charter boats may miss a day of work because of this. As a former charter boat Captain (USCG 100 TON MASTERS LISC.), and current offshore fisherman, we loose too many days to weather and Red Tide to give up another day for an ELITIST SPORT that already has a venue paid for by TAXPAYERS!
Why do the rowers need no boat traffic??? I see rowers in lemon bay with boat traffic and there seems to be no problem!
This sets a bad precedent; what other sports should we halt boat traffic for, bicycling (close the drawbridges), kayaking, stand up  paddle boarding, windsurfing, swimming??
If the need a curved course I can design it for them at BENDERSON PARK

Title: Comment Submitted by Harry Krimmel
Comment:
Please note that the rowers have a multi million facility for their exclusive use.

I am a resident of Venice and I use the Venice Boat Ramp exclusively. This Regulation will have a very negative impact on the 
safety aspect of all boaters from Tampa to Charlotte Harbor, including local boaters like my myself. God forbid there be a storm in the Gulf with boats seeking to use the ICW instead. My thoughts are that the USCG should endeavor to make boaters safe, and not be the cause of possible catastrophe. ( Why would you (USCG) increase the chances of putting boaters in peril ?) Please continue to help us be safe and do not close the Venice Boat Ramp or the ICW.

Title: Comment Submitted by Paul Bina
Comment: I live in Venice, FL and watched it last year.  My family enjoyed it very much.  Let them row!

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeremy Domanich
Comment:
I am respectfully submitting a comment in OPPOSITION to NPRM USCG-2019-0508, Titled "Battle of the Bridges", to be held in Venice, Florida on September 28th, 2019 from 6:00 AM - 6:00 PM. This comment is submitted within the comment period which ends September 3, 2019. 

The closure of a federal waterway on a Saturday for 12 hours, with the boat ramp being closed the night before at 6pm is an excessive amount of time to commit to a youth race that will likely not provide a significant economic boost to the local economy. Instead, it will prevent any charter captain, recreational fisherman or recreational boater from enjoying their right to the waterway.  Not everybody in the area is retired and for those of us that are still working, we look forward all week to dropping the boat off the lift at the house, picking it up at the marina or launching at the public boat ramp.  None of these will be an option for us if the ICW closure is implemented.

There are numerous more viable options in Sarasota and Charlotte County including the mega million $ facility that was built to accommodate this event in Sarasota.  This facility struggles financially and would benefit from an event being held there. If Benderson is not viable for the event, there are large swaths of open water far from the ICW in Sarasota Bay and Gasparilla Sound that could accommodate this event, with virtually no impact on the 1000's of boaters, jet skiers and other water enthusiasts.  

Holding this event on a Federal Waterway (similar to I-75 for boaters) on a weekend is short sighted, selfish and the economic impact will not offset the immeasurable damage done to the local boating community, Marinas, bait stores, waterfront restaurants and the like.  

Finally, and maybe most importantly is the fact that if this closure occurs it will force all boaters to move out to the Gulf of Mexico if they wish to navigate north or south of Venice.  Not all boats and not all captains are capable of operating a vessel in rough water conditions and if this closure occurs, the safety of these boaters could be put in jeopardy depending on the weather conditions.  All for what? A few bucks?  This is not about the kids. The youth would have no idea if they were competing on a closed Federal Waterway or in the open flats of Sarasota Bay/Gasparilla Sound. 

It is time to seriously reconsider this events location, timing and closure of a Federal Waterway to benefit a select few of the areas wealthy families and friends, while harming vast numbers of people who rely on the use of the waterway for business and pleasure.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I am in SUPPORT of this regatta.  As a boater that regularly uses Marine Max, I can plan my Saturday accordingly in order to allow our local and visiting athletes a venue that is different. I hope visiting athletes, spectators, families will certainly enjoy our small town of Venice.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I am in OPPOSITION to USCG 2019-0508 and request this Temporary Rule be denied and REMANDED back to USCG Legal in Miami for consideration of deficiencies in the following areas:
II. Background, Purpose, and Legal Basis:46 USC 70034, specifically subsections B (3) (4) (5)(6)(7) All of these subsections deal with public and business input.  Emphasis on subsection (7) which reads, advisory committees consisting of all interested segments of the public when the establishment of such committees is considered necessary because the issues involved are highly complex or controversial.   80+ comments on the Federal Registry in week 3 of 4 is unprecedented and proof this is highly controversial.
IV. Regulatory Analyses:Section IV(A)- Executive Order 12866  United States requires benefit-cost analysis for any new regulation that is economically significant, which is defined as having an annual effect or adversely affect[ing] in a material way the economy, a sector of the economy, productivity, competition, jobs or creating an inconsistency with other law or any of several other conditions.  Furthermore agencies are required to engage in prior consultation with both private and public stakeholders before drafting notices of proposed rulemaking and ensuring they have at least 60 days for public comment.  Of 80+ comments received a significant number deal with negative economic impact on businesses.  For this reason alone, this permit should be denied.
 Executive Order 13563 Section 2(B) To the extent feasible and permitted by law each agency shall afford the public a meaningful opportunity to comment through the Internet on any proposed regulation, with a comment period that should generally be at least 60 days. At the very least THIS comment period should be extended to the full 60 days required to fully evaluate the economic impact and due process.
    Exec. Ord 13563 Sec. 4 - Flexible Approaches:Certainly a schedule could be established allowing vessel traffic to transit the race course with an escort hourly or between race heats.  A Reasonable compromise would be if a total of six or more vessels are awaiting transit at either end of the course they be allowed to pass hourly with an escort at Slow Speed/Minimum Wake. By now race organizers know how many entries have been received.  This data could be used to shorten the closure of the ICW to a more reasonable time period.  12 hours is unreasonable, especially considering the failure of last years entries and lack of spectators.
Section IV(B) Impact on Small Entities.  The Regulatory Flexibility Act of 1980, 5 SC 601-612, specifically 605 (B) has been applied incorrectly.  It requires Federal agencies to consider the potential impact of regulations on small entities during rulemaking. The term small entities comprise small businesses, not-for-profit organizations that are independently owned and operated and are not dominant in their fields, and governmental jurisdictions with populations of less than 50,000. According to the latest (2018) US Census, the City of Venice has a population of just 23,376. https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/venicecityflorida,FL/PST045218

The Coast Guard certifies under 5 U.S.C. 605(b) that this proposed rule would not have a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities.  This is erroneous and validated by the public comment section.   To date no less than 21 comments have been received on the negative business impacts.  Many comments involve multiple businesses.  This is unprecedented and an oversight that mandates the denial of this Permit.

Section IV (F) Environment
The NEPA and EPP are flawed.  As can be read in ATTACHMENT A, the agency representative does not appear to like boats and the written words speak for themselves.  A new EPP must be submitted by an entity other than Mote, preferably with one appointed by the USCG, ACOE or FWC.  

Just as in last years event there will again be dozens of mooring balls and lane markers affixed to the sea-bed with heavy weights and ropes tied to buoys (see attachment B & C) that will pose an obvious danger to marine life, especially manatees and sea turtles that are still hatching on area beaches. This year is the highest hatch rate for turtle nests according to Mote Marine:
https://mote.org/media/uploads/files/2019_Weekly_Summary_for_Week_34.pdf
Manatees are thriving along this specific stretch of the ICW and seen daily.  Their numbers are growing to a point they have been downgraded to Threatened.

In addition to the weighted buoys and ropes affixed to the bottom, the temporary floating dockage that will be erected into the ICW the day prior to the event will also have a negative impact on sea life. These numerous obstacles placed in the path of marine life for 12 to 24 hours will certainly be detrimental to their well being.  An unbiased EPP should be re-submitted and reconsidered by Legal prior to issuance of any permit.
USCG 2019-0508 should be DENIED

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeanette Leiter
Comment: This is a great opportunity for Venice residents to show how they support there local children and promote a great sport.  Resident that are opposing do not understand that Benderson was built for sprint racing only.  There is two types of racing in the rowing world.  Sprints and Head racing.  Benderson was not built for Head racing.  So even though it is a multi million dollar facility, you can not race a head race there. One day and not even a full day is a minor time frame to allow our children to have a race that they train for all year round to do the best they can be.  I think everyone should read The boys in the Boat.

Title: Comment Submitted by Patrick E. McCarthy
Comment:
RE: Docket Number USCG-2019-0508 

To whom to may concern,
	
	Please find below my comments on the proposed event Battle of the Bridges to be held on the ICW in the city of Venice Florida.
 
	Section II of the supplementary information leaves the impression that this event WILL happen. By what authority can this private entity close a 3.5 miles section of the Intracoastal Waterway? This section of waterway is an extremely busy section, especially on weekends, providing the only safe passage between the Venice Inlet & Stump Pass. The event closes this passage for 12 hours. 

	Under section IV part A, Provisions need to be made to provide reasonable, timely and safe passage of recreational & commercial vessels. 

	Part B, many businesses will be adversely affected by this event, Two large Marinas, several boat rental businesses & boat clubs will be SHUT DOWN for the day. Charter boats that utilize this waterway will be SHUT DOWN for the day. 

	Part C is most concerning given that if the impact of last years event is being used to justify this years closure one must document the fact that we were in the middle of the worst RED TIDE event in 15+ years last year. I do not believe a true analyses of the vessel traffic has been done, therefore the true impact this event will have on the recreational boating public is unknown. 

	Given the deceptive unethical manner in which last years event planning was kept from the recreational boating public, along with the shortening of the comment period from 30 to 15 days by the USCG, I feel a reexamination of this whole event is in order. 

	Given the fact that a public information request last year to the City of Venice on this matter was answered with in 2 days with full documentation & my PIR to the USCG (2018-CGFO-02757) still to this day has not been answered how can I not feel that this whole thing does not pass the sniff test.

	In conclusion, as a life time Florida resident & recreational boater I am personally adamantly opposed to this proposed rule that will allow the closure of the ICW for a period of 12 hours (6am to 6pm) on a Saturday. 

Respectfully Submitted,
Patrick E. McCarthy

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I submit this comment in extreme opposition to USCG 2019-0508, The Battle of the Bridges.  
Please review last years USCG Battle of the Bridges After Action Report -16751 Authored by Z.R. Gray, BMC.  Please pay particular attention to Section 8, Sponsor Contact.  Read the very last sentence carefully, because it is true.  You were played.  
Please also review section 10 (d) as well.  Please tell the boating taxpayers why a boat crew was run to fatigue. I ask, did this row boat race compromise the ability of the USCG to respond to other marine emergencies.  SEMPER PARATUS, remember.  Multiple crews should be assigned to this event simply because of the travel and event time alone.  CG crews should not be placed in situations where underway times exceed five hours.  
I also ask, WHY are taxpayers paying for USCG personnel for extended periods of time  for a private club when the Club Sponsor is paying for local police vessels.  The event sponsor should PAY for all USCG Assets and personnel should this incomprehensible permit be approved.
Any Closure of the waterway will cause inexperienced, under equipped boaters into the open Gulf of Mexico.  Somebody is GOING TO inherit that liability.  Is the City of Venice, Sarasota Scullers, or US Rowing going to step up and write checks.  It says right on the permit in Section 2 that USCG is not responsible for the safety of transient craft in the area or the safety of real and personal property in the area.  The responsibility rests solely with the sponsor of this event.  Digest that. Just based on the costs of rescue assets (see attachment A), the costs for a marine rescue CAUSED BY THIS EVENT will far exceed the insurance policy submitted, and rather quickly.
To all of the cheerleaders saying that rowing is great for the kids, etc.  You are correct.  Rowing is a great character builder. This sport is fantastic for our youth. No question. Having this event on a Federal Highway and shutting down a boater funded boat ramp for two days is simply wrong.  If Benderson is not designed for a Head-Race thats your oversight not the boaters. What other races are not compatible with Benderson.  For those saying its only a couple hours, you are simply wrong.  For those on TV https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GeUJYkVFJlI saying the boaters should just suck it up-your words validate your ignorance of the boating community.  To those saying this will put Venice on the map, come on.  Have you tried getting into a restaurant, even in the off season here.  To those grand standing that this event was a huge success last year, please.

The event sponsor misled all businesses last year and again this year.  One only has to read the article in the Gondoliar Sun from last year, Jan 29 2018 to see where the sponsor stated the necessary permits were already obtained.
https://www.yoursun.com/venice/newsarchives/opinion-split-on-regatta-on-intracoastal/article_6d64c2ee-85fc-5caf-bee7-c7cfd1ff03dd.html?fbclid=IwAR3isGxEWN1Z__fZDvNk-Gvj4DXekW9Cc8_jwECinpQjxVjnW4R0w54LuAU

Read the paragraph that states the following: There was some chatter among the boaters about trying to fight the use of the waterway, but with the city having signed off on it, the regatta now has all the necessary permissions, including Coast Guard approval, event coordinator  ... said.  That was not only false, but a flat out misrepresentation designed to force businesses and the public to believe everything was approved.  This tactic continued this year as well.

   The boaters tried very hard to work with the event sponsor for both last year and this year.  They were ignored.  The boaters wanted to work with the sponsor to seek a compromise.  To US Rowing, this could have been pulled off with some reasonable compromise and a clearer vision, not fogged by ego.  This is where the controversy originated and should it fail, it will be for no other reason.  Help was offered, several times, but refused.  Not one boater was asked to attend a single planning meeting.  Despite knowing how controversial this was last year alone, not one person planning this event had the foresight to invite anyone opposed to see what the concerns were and seek a middle ground.  Not One.  That is your mistake.  
USCG, the boaters were NOT included in planning this event, this year or last.  Your job is to keep boaters safe, not pander to people that only want it their way.  This is not Burger King.  You had the wool pulled over your eyes last year, please do not let it happen again.

Title: Safety Zone for Fireworks Displays; Patapsco River, Inner Harbor, Baltimore, MD
Topics: Harbors,Marine Safety,Navigation (Water),Reporting and Recordkeeping Requirements,Security Measures,Waterways
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Bryson Amaral
Comment:
Bryson J. AMARAL, August 9, 2019

Dear United States Coast Guard, Department of Homeland Security:
I am writing regarding your proposal for a safety zone for fireworks displays; Patapsco River, Inner Harbor, Baltimore, MD on 21 September 2019 for a private fireworks event and 10 November 2019 (with an alternate date of 11 November 2019) for a public event. 
The proposed rule and following action is a necessary one to ensure the safety of life in the harbor of Baltimore, MD. This safety zone will restrict persons and sea faring vessel from entering the prescribed area for 2 hours on each date respectively. This NPRM has been analyzed under Homeland Security Directive 023-01 and Environmental Planning 5090.1 (series) and the studies have found that these actions of a safety zone for four (4) hours in total in a small area of the inner harbor will have minimal impact on the human environment. The directive also states that during the times prescribed within the proposed rule, in and around the port and on the barges thee will be proper signage FireworksDangerStay Away. 
However as a 15 year Army veteran with two deployments to the Middle East in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom, I would like to hear more in-depth from the respective proposing agency concerning the issues that may need to be addressed to ensure the safety of all those in and around the surrounding area:
	Type of security surrounding the inner harbor and the buffer zone on the ground and sea as well as the number of roving patrols on both the land and sea.
	The scope of responsibility from Serpico Pyrotechnics, LLC and The Baltimore Office of Promotion and The Arts of Baltimore, MD respectively. 
	The policing up of the refuse by product of fireworks and excess fallout on water surface if any or a contingency plan to minimize the fallout
	Compensation aspects for security for participating law enforcement and federal agencies to include special duty pay for off duty law enforcement personnel
	The possibility of public intoxication from wedding guests who may wander into safety zone as well as intoxication the public event which may host up to tens of thousands of persons
	Posted signs of repercussions with proposed rule number to be used as a deterrent  to trespassing personnel during proposed times
	Proximity to and sufficient number of first responders (fire and rescue services) both on land and sea
	Lighting for posted signs on land and road blocks or caution signs on surface streets surrounding the harbor for increased traffic warn drivers and pedestrians about the scheduled fireworks displays who may become distracted by the night sky being filled with bright lights and sounds

The existing regulation that this amendment adds to is 33 CFR part 165, title 33Navigation and Navigable waters, part 165 regulated navigation area and limited access area. This amendment is considered to be routine and frequent.  I feel that the language of this proposed rule is clear and concise and accomplishes it goal of notifying the public of its intention and covers all mandated regulation rules. I fully support this amendment and its goals, as I have researched other similar amendment surrounding the same topic of safety zones for firework displays and have found no negative comments after the events in which the USCG has provided security in accordance with its mission to protect Americans and to ensure our maritime safety. Thank you for the opportunity to exercise my right to comment on this proposed rule. Please add my name to your mailing list so I may stay abreast of this project.

Sincerely,
Bryson J. Amaral

Title: Safety Zone for Fireworks Display; Patapsco River, Inner Harbor, Baltimore, MD

Title: Waterway Suitability Assessment for Operations of Liquefied Hazardous Gas Terminal; Nederland, TX
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Michaela Kerin
Comment:
A federal regulation requires owners or operators planning to build a new facility handling liquefied hazardous gas (LHG) (Proposed Rule) or planning construction that will result in the modification, specifically the expansion of marine terminal operations in an existing LHG-handling facility where the construction, expansion, or modification would result in an increase in the size and/or frequency of LHG marine traffic on the waterway associated with the proposed facility (Proposed Rule) are required to submit a Letter of Intent (LOI) to the Captain of the Port of the zone (COTP) in which the change will occur. 
Earlier this year, Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals located in Nederland, Texas submitted a letter of intent (LOI) with proposed plans to increase the use of an existing dock that is involved in the handling of liquified-hazardous gas (specifically propane and butane). This expansion would lead to an increase in the LNG marine traffic on the Sabine-Neches Waterway which would impact the public. 
This expansion would be monumental considering the dramatic proposed shift from 120 liquified propane and butane ship visits per year to 432 in addition to the 120 liquified ethane ship visits. Marine traffic in the Nederland area would not be minorly impacted, but recreated altogether. However, it is possible for recreational boaters and LHG vessels to safely coexist in the affected environment so long as necessary precautionary measures are taken. This would include the consideration of an alternative approach by Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals. This approach, which is similar to the proposal of the Cove Point Expansion Project in 2006 regarding LNG vessel traffic in the Chesapeake Bay, would likely minimize the potential negative impacts on other marine traffic in the Nederland area by encouraging the Coast Guard to instate an announcement program in which the company notifies the people (specifically those interested/involved in the marine affairs of the area), in advance, of the scheduled transit of an LHG vessel. Additionally, Sunoco could attempt to craft a transit schedule with LHG boat carriers that would utilize transit times that are least likely to impact recreational boaters (i.e. Sunday-Thursday, early mornings, late evenings). 
As is considered in all environmentally-steered proposals, we must address the environmental impacts of an expansion of this sort. Research suggests that propane, butane and ethane, the LHGs that are handled by Sunoco in Nederland, TX, are non-toxic, non-caustic and will not create an environmental hazard (Propane 101) if released as a liquid (even in extreme amounts), which is the form that would be onboard the boats that transit the Nederland Port thereby alleviating some of  the environmental concerns related to the increased traffic. 
Because the increased handling of liquefied hazardous gas in the Nederland area would be relatively effortless for recreational boaters to circumvent, would not introduce any additional environmental hazards and would serve as a method of capitalizing the success of Sunoco, the expansion of this American energy company should be allowed in this case.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This is a great rule as it necessary to protect swimmers, participant vessels, spectators, and the general public during the event and these actions provide a safety zone. Since a race will be occurring regardless, it is important that the safety of the contestants and viewers be protected. Also, by protecting the participants, other vessels in the water would also be protected so they do not accidentally hit them. Moreover, the safety zone would last only 30 minutes and if persons or vessels desire to enter the safety zone during that time, they are not permanently excluded, they can contact the Captain of the Port Charleston by telephone at (843) 740-7050, or a designated representative via VHF radio on channel 16, to request authorization. Furthermore, the impact on entities is de minimis and would even protect small entities from liability since swimmers would be within a safe zone and thus, small entities would not be able to crash into them and avoid potential lawsuits.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I fully support this proposed rule establishing a safety zone for the Swim Around Charleston. It's an important function of our government and Coast Guard to provide safety to both participants and spectators during events such as this. Prohibiting people from entering the zone during the event will ensure that only those partaking in the event, hosting the event, and monitoring the event will be allowed. This will help ensure the safety of everyone involved.

Title: Comment Submitted by Chase Rich
Comment: I think that the proposed rule is a good idea to ensure the safety of people who may want to watch the rocket launch event. People could easily be hurt by being to close to the launch site, and this rule will help ensure that people are far enough away to enjoy the spectacle and stay safe. I support the proposed rule.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jennifer Davis
Comment: How intensely has the environmental impact statement been analyzed? The "accidental discharge of the ignition system, dangerous projectiles, and falling hot embers or other debris" will still be in the water after the 7 hours and will travel further that the 1500 yards. The safety zone of 1500 yards and only 7 hours is a very immediate response, with no concern for long-term environmental impact. The EIS should include more than just the direct impact on the people in the immediate area.

Title: Comment Submitted by Geoff Fitzpatrick
Comment: I think this is a well thought out rule that would protect people from getting injured in the event of any mishaps from these rocket launches. Depending on the height and distance of the rocket, has there been analysis on the possible problematic trajectories that would coincide with the 1500yd radius? I am also concerned with the EIS in this case because I am not sure whether the analysis is supposed to cover only the rule and event itself, or the worst case scenario of a rocket exploding.
