Topics: Bridges
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Railways carry toxic commodities in large volumes that have the potential to create catastrophic situations.  These bridges should not be considered for remote operations for the safety of the general public and environment.   

Due to the nature of the hazardous materials transported in large volumes by railways they should not allow bridges to be remotely operated.  The Paulsboro NJ bridge operated remotely with a failure message that was not taken seriously contributed to 23,000 gallons of toxic vinyl chloride being release into the Mantia Creek.   A bridge tender should have been onsite and in communication with the supporting maintenance workers for the locking mechanism to prevent the incident.

Title: Comment Submitted by Barb Miller
Comment: These bridges need to have a tender there when trains go over the water ways.  Who is checking these trains that they are not leaking hazardous materials in our the water?   There is not substitution for a live person.  Change how the bridge operates but the railway should have to have someone at that location when the trains cross the river. They should also be able to operate the bridge from that location when needed.  Once the operator is gone there is no one to hold accountable.  Boaters will get the same  "not my problem" from the tender on the other side of the world as they do from everything else that has been sent to china.    Our children drink this water. The railroad is not going to tell on themselves.

Title: Proposed Termination of U.S. Coast Guard Medium Frequency (MF) Broadcast of Navigational Telex (NAVTEX) and Shift to Satellite
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment Submitted by Jim Glenn, Jr.
Comment:
Please, do not terminate NAVTEX transmissions via MF radio.  I do use NAVTEX on a regular basis.  Having it only on a satellite system will be more expensive and possibly not as reliable.  The available NAVTEX receivers are lower priced than satellite systems and are dedicated receivers that will download and save the transmissions.  My NAVTEX receiver is on continuously whenever I am onboard, underway or not.  NAVTEX is a reliable, low cost, effective system on MF.  Keep it going!

Feel free to contact me if you want more information.

Best regards,

Jim Glenn, Jr

Title: Comment Submitted by John Franklin
Comment: The proposed withdrawal of Navtex transmissions on MF is a retrograde step for most small craft users who will now be required to purchase expensive new satellite display equipment and suitable antennas and spend additional sums on installation. . MF Navtex is a free  and valuable information service giving especially navigational notices and warnings not available elsewhere. The MF equipment which most small boat users already have installed is cheap and reliable. Discontinuation of this service is to effectively withdraw a vital safety service.

Title: Comment Submitted by Peter Behling
Comment: As a professional mariner i find the loss of another means of receiving safety and weather information a bad idea.  this is just like when you all decided getting rid of Loran c made sense.  with ever increasing solar disruptions and people deciding the like jamming sat signals for no good reason i think this is a bad idea in the Post El faro world

Title: Comment Submitted by William Midgette
Comment: I use NAVTEX frequently when sailing from Chesapeake Bay to Newport and Charleston and while I have satellite communications onboard it is a backup to NAVTEX. Loss of NAVTEX broadcasts will reduce the level of comfort that I have when offshore by having a redundant system to receive weather data. It also reduces the utility of having an operable SSB system onboard, and as a retired naval officer, I am dismayed that the USCG is getting away from the use of HF broadcasts and feel that it should be continued as a viable and reliable long range communications system. The United States Navy in recent years has renewed interest in use of the HF spectrum for a number of reasons, I think the USCG should continue the support for MF-HF broadcasts.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I am a professional ship inspector in the US. I have boarded thousands of vessels in my career for the purposes of navigational audits. NAVTEX is still widely used and despite the fact that ECDIS units have this functionality, the actual radio broadcasts are still widely received, printed, and passed amongst watch standers. NAVTEX broadcasts are often the only record of significant navigation information and warnings for coastwise tugs and ATBs. NAVTEX provides the Mariner with a passive watch for alerts that may be missed on traditional VHF broadcasts. I strongly urge whomever is assuming that this system is not in use to reconsider termination. The termination of systems such as this may have unintended consequences in the marine sphere. A good example of this is the decommissioning of LORAN C leaving a sole reliance upon GPS which is rapidly becoming subject to spoofing and signal corruption.

Title: Comment Submitted by Roland Stockham
Comment:
As a recreational boat user I can say with confidence that most recreational boat are not able to fit satellite systems. This is partly due to cost constrain but also because the platform is not stable enough and weight aloft would be to high. This also applies to commercial work delivering small boats.

Navtext is a significant source of information that is important for coastal and near coastal sailing and it's loss would be a significant reduction in safety.

As an addition to moving this information to satellite could it also be available on the SSB service alongside weathfax

Title: Comment Submitted by Charles Starke
Comment:
I use Navtex daily on s/v Dawnpiper. I do not have satellite or GMDSS communications and find that Navtex gives me the necessary weather and safety alerts, and weather forecasts that I need.
Thank you 
Charles L Starke MD FACP 
USCG MASTER

Title: Comment Submitted by Sam Milton
Comment:
I am unopposed to the termination of NAVTEX broadcast over MF frequencies.  MF is extremely prone to noise and fading, and the SITOR-B code used for NAVTEX is archaic and doesn't provide adequate throughput or error correction.  However, I am opposed to only providing navigational warning data by satellite.  INMARSAT receivers may be inexpensive, but having a terrestrial radio backup is still not a bad idea and provides an inexpensive option for recreational boaters like me.  I would suggest that, in addition to the INMARSAT broadcasts, USCG starts providing the navigational warnings included in NAVTEX on the existing HF Marine channels, such as the existing HF-SITOR high seas weather broadcasts.  It could use the existing NAVTEX coding to allow localization, using the receiver message filtering using the current coverage areas (e.g., G - New Orleans (Gulf), A- Miami (South Atlantic/Florida, E - Charleston (Middle Atlantic), etc.)  

The best option, however, would be to modernize both NAVTEX and HF-SITOR to a state-of-the-art HF digital mode, like those developed by radio amateurs over the past 15-20 years, such as MFSK16, Olivia, or MT63. These all provide an asynchronous mode (allowing broadcast vs. handshaking/connection) very robust noise interference, and forward error correction that is superior to SITOR/AMTOR. The existing NAVTEX message format could continue to be used, but the broadcast of data over HF using one of the new modes would allow much wider dissemination from fewer transmitters and more reliable reception.

It is important to recognize that satellite broadcast has drawbacks such as cost, vulnerability to outages due to satellite failure or solar storms, and equipment complexity for which HF can provide complementary capabilities and redundancy.  In addition, the newer HF digital modes allow for much more reliability and functionality than in the past.

Title: Comment Submitted by Edwin Kelly
Comment:
My wife and I are US citizens who cruise extensively on our documented vessel, Angel Louise. Additionally I serve as President of the SEVEN SEAS CRUISING ASSOCIATION, a voluntary association of cruisers and live-aboard explorers on seagoing vessels. We speak for and on behalf of over 10,000 people who are either paying members of SSCA, or participants in our social media. Our members cruise the oceans and coasts of the USA and the world.
We, like many folks on modest smaller seagoing vessels use and rely on NAVTEX at critical times while at sea. It is a vital link to weather info, and vital to life & safety when other means fail. Many of our members do not yet utilize or have reliable satellite communications when voyaging and continue to use older tested technology in NAVTEX for critical weather information essential to life and safety while cruising at sea. As the technology and method works well and is in place, do not abandon it. As the old Texan used to say, If it aint broke, dont fix it. We add, dont throw it away either.  

I cannot allow my Email & phone to be clogged by spammers who harvest data from your published listings.
 My email (in non machine readable format follows, which includes spaces that must be removed): 
Atty Ed Kelly @ gmail.com
USA Telephone: (five one five) 257 - thirtytwo hundred

Title: Comment Submitted by John Stevenso
Comment: I've used NAVTEX on my cruising sailboat for over 15 years and it has been the most reliable source of weather data and forecasts on board.  I also have a HF radio to receive FAX and other weather data.  It was especially important when cruising transatlantic and in Europe.  Moving to satellite transmission could be an improvement in the service.  The only shortcoming of NAVTEX was the limited reception when on the high seas.  Since NAVTEX is an international system, what are the other responsible agencies doing?  Are there any existing devices that will work with the new system, or do those devices need to be created?  I am no longer cruiser my boat off-shore, but it I were it would be important to me that one device work in US waters and the waters of Europe and Asia as well.  I assume, no matter what system is implemented there will be a multi-year period that both systems (new and old) will be operational.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ralph Caruso
Comment:
I am a recreational sailor, but I have sailed my boat across the Atlantic, all around NW Europe, and all along the East Coast of the USA.  I have a radio receiver that allows me to tune to the NAVTEX frequencies, and then transfer the reports to my computer.  It is not foolproof, but it allows me to keep a record of these reports, which are not easily available away from the coast.  The US has much better weather forecast distribution than other countries, but it is not easily provided to mariners in a format that can be recorded, if they are not close to the shore.  

NAVTEX provides a record of reports that can be reviewed later, compared to one another to discern trends in weather, and to ensure that significant details are not missed.  It should not be terminated.  Providing the service by satellite will make it even harder for recreational boaters to receive this information, because satellite receivers are very expensive and difficult  (in some cases impossible) to install,  and their installation would be unjustifiable for  only this one application.  If the Coast Guard were to transition NAVTEX to a different SSB frequency, that would ameliorate some of the problems, but existing users who have already purchased and installed  dedicated NAVTEX receivers would see those efforts completely lost.  Users would also incur a cost for a subscription to this service from a satellite, and that cost to users is not discussed in the proposal. 

The Coast Guard also needs to think about the experience of shutting down LORAN, which turned out to be, in my estimate, a serious mistake.  The GPS system is wonderful, but it is not foolproof, and there is a need for both diversity and redundancy in the transmission of safety information.  Satellite-based systems are wonderful, but they are susceptible to solar storms, which can knock then all out at the same time, and there is no way to protect them from this damage.

Finally, the argument that parts for NAVTEX transmitters are expensive and hard to find sounds very much like a red herring.  The greatest expenses of NAVTEX and LORAN transmitter facilities are (1) the capital expense of initially setting up the site, and (2) operational staffing costs.  In this day of really cheap electronics, it is hard to believe that it is getting too expensive to replace radio transmitters.  Maybe the Coast Guard can look at all of the various MF transmitters that are installed on ships, and figure out some way to adapt them to the NAVTEX sites.

Title: Comment Submitted by Asger Milborg
Comment:
We are a Danish producer and supplier of NAVTEX transmitters and our NAVTEX solutions are constantly updated with new technology to fulfil future requirements like NAVDAT and Local Language. Our systems are modern and reliable and used worldwide. In general, our NAVTEX solutions are relatively cheap and very easy to upgrade for extra transmitters and sites and supply of spare parts and repairs are guaranteed for the lifetime of the systems. 
We therefore find the argument that The equipment is antiquated and essential replacement parts are difficult to find and expensive, placing overall operation of MF NATEX at risk not true at all. NAVTEX is still a vital and important part of maritime safety for many years to come.

We will be happy to expand our views on this and you are welcome to contact me.
Best Regards 
Asger Milborg

www.danphone.com

Title: Comment Submitted by Captain Morgan McManus, SUNY Maritime College
Comment:
Good Day
As a professional mariner and educator I respectively disagree with terminating MF. Navtex.
MF Navtex is still widely used and is a useful  tool.
It seems counter intuitive to discontinue a system that provides a level of redundancy for safety information and weather broadcasts for ships at sea.
With cybersecurity on the minds of the Maritime industry  I see no harm in having a system that works via radio frequency and not via satellites.
 
 
Respectfully,
Captain Morgan McManus
Master, T.S Empire State
718-409-5561
www.sunymaritime.edu
mmcmanus@sunymaritime.edu

Title: Comment Submitted by Antonio Garca
Comment:
This is a public comment on the possibility of terminating the MF NAVTEX broadcast submitted to the online docket 
USCG-2019- 0702 via http://www.regulations.gov, on or before Nov. 12, 2019.

Proposed termination of Coast Guard medium frequency broadcast of Navigational Telex (NAVTEX) and shift to satellite

Cease broadcasting over MF will provoke that information contained in NAVTEX broadcasts must turn to be received via 
IMO recognized satellite services, and these equipments INMARSAT fitted on board many ships may be not connectable to 
ECDIS equipment on many ships, which use MF NAVTEX , entering MSI in ECDIS data base automatically (not  time  
consuming manual mode), by mean of a connection to external equipment ECDIS, thereby allowing the NAVTEX can be used 
in conjunction with Integrated Bridge System.

The ECDIS data output connector in the NAVTEX sends received messages to the ECDIS when the data format complies 
by opened message text and can be output to the connected external equipment  ECDIS.

If NAVTEX are to be broadcast via IMO INMARSAT recognized satellite services, this equipment must be prepared to 
connect to external equipment ECDIS, and may need to be reprogrammed or a new refit placement.

Title: Comment Submitted by Wayne Walker
Comment:
Dear Sirs;

NavTex is still in use by a very large fleet of fishing boats, pleasure boats, and other commercial vessels all over the world via MF Radio.

Please do not Terminate the NavTex Broadcasts of information via MF radio.

There are still many users not equipped to receive via Satellite transmissions. 

To terminate the MF broadcasts would deprive many, many users of it's functionality.


Wayne Walker
Master S/V Apollo, 37' Cutter rigged Hunter
Currently Cruising the South Pacific

Title: Comment Submitted by Walter Paul
Comment:
Gentlemen,

My limited experience with Navtex is that is isn't a significant information source on the east coast of the US.  But that's not the case in other areas such as the Mediterranean with the many mountains chains channeling weather.  And, that may be the same on the NW US coast and Alaska as well.  

Navtex has several advantages that HF weather reports lack.  The broadcasts are localized (200 miles) which in mountainous areas, can be very important.  And that kind of data is what the mariner needs.

It is too bad that the US maritime community hadn't caught on to the significant transmission data that could be available and is available elsewhere.  Probably the main reason it didn't catch on here was because the data provided was lacking and often of limited value.  While the data input is not your doing, it needed someone to do a quality job with the input and it didn't get it.

It must be embarrassing to transmit abysmal data rather than meaningful weather.  However, this proposed correction of terminating the broadcasts doesn't correct the fundamental and underlying issue which should be addressed.

Walter Paul

Title: Comment Submitted by John Schroeder
Comment:
I oppose the elimination of Navtex broadcasting of weather and the other aids to navigation and vessel  safety as currently available.  I have used Navtex for the last 20 years as a commercial fisherman and cruiser from Adak to the Salish Sea. It helps me make good decisions for myself and my crew.  Please do not eliminate this service to mariners.

Thank You,   John Schroeder, SV Hoku Iki, Anacortes WA

Title: Comment Submitted by Knut Kaehler
Comment: As I have on my sailing yacht a MF Navtex receiver and no satelite equipment, I won't be able to receive navtexinformation any more.

Title: Comment Submitted by William McCarthy
Comment: Please do not terminate NAVTEX broadcasting until a time at which the information conveyed is replicated in a reliable, affordable, and widely used means.

Title: Comment Submitted by Captain Christopher S. Hendrickson
Comment:
As a licensed mariner and Master of M/V Charleston Express (IMO# 9243162) I implore you to please not do away with NAVTEX. The internet may be useful and available for vessels at sea, but good seamanship is built on having back up plans and equipment when one inevitably fails. NAVTEX makes sense as a backup for coastal information and a cross check on other information gained by radio or satellite. Please do not take vital navigational safety services out of availability just to save a buck. 

Captain C.S. Hendrickson

Title: Comment Submitted by Gregory Mengell
Comment: PPLS DO NOT DO THIS. NOT ALL VESSELS ARE EQUIPPED TO HAVE SATELLITE RECEPTION. LET ALONE SMALL MARINERS AND HIGH SEAS FISHERMEN.. WHY RUIN ANOTHER GOOD SERVICE??

Title: Comment Submitted by Wesley Heerssen
Comment:
As the 2nd Mate and Navigation Officer aboard a 50,000 GT US flagged trans-Atlantic car carrier, I recognize the limitations of NAV-TEX and the great value that a satellite based system could have toward improving GMDSS capabilities for vessels on my route. I do believe that a satellite based system should be required equipment once such an international system is in place.

However, I also recognize the inherent risk to reducing the safety of navigation by eliminating coastal radio broadcast systems such as NAV-TEX. I was not a proponent of eliminating LORAN-C in the 1990's either. These are costly systems to maintain and operate, but they have at least one quality which satellite based systems cannot replace and it is signal strength.

Satellite signals, such as with GPS can be hijacked by stronger signals, potentially sent by competing foreign satellites, aircraft, submarines, other vessels, land stations, etc. A signal strong enough to hijack a satellite signal can still be too weak to be easily identified and traced by radio signal detection equipment. For example, a passenger on a cruise ship might do so using a cel phone or laptop and transmitter, and that would only take a very weak signal. In order to hijack the old loran system, and I would argue the same for today's NAV-TEX, the hijacker's signal would need to be strong enough that it might be detected.

In an age of information warfare, it seems to me that a good national defense requires that funding be provided for powerful land station-based radio navigation and navigation information communication systems as well as satellite based system. I believe both are important, and are worth funding.

One last point. I recommend that the US Coast Guard be split up. Navigation and Vessel-related services should fall under the Department of Transportation. Conversely, the national defense, drug interdiction, etc should fall under Department of Homeland Security. While maritime transportation is vital to the national economy, and the economy is key to a good national defense, management of transportation systems and defense are two different skill sets with different priorities. They should be able to coordinate security efforts, but individually, they would be more effective and efficient post-divorce, so-to-speak.  I don't believe funding for navigational equipment, aids to navigation, etc. should be robbed in order to fund warships, drug interdiction, or anti-terrorism activities, etc (and vice-versa). ALL are important, but a US Coast Guard that can drain funds in one pocket (security) only to reach into the other (marine inspection, mariner licensing, aids to navigation, etc) will result in diminished capabilities all around.

The US Coast Guard remains the most important and appreciated of the US Armed Services to me personally. Their long history of wearing multiple hats toward the protection of mariners & shipping, trade, commerce, and the homeland is amazing, and I thank them for their commitment to honorable service.

Title: Comment Submitted by David Reid
Comment:
Dear Coastguard,
The loss of such a valuable service as the NAVTEX would have a great impact on many small vessels who safely navigate the coastal waters and rely on NAVTEX for weather information.
The cost of an off the shelf commercial MF transmitter is not so high these days and possibly cheaper than trying to maintain the old tube equipment that I imagine is in use today.
 One of the key successes of the NAVTEX system was its wide coverage and easy of reception/ decoding by 'casual' users.
A NAVTEX receiver can be as simple as a MF radio and a connection to a mobile phone. I've used such a setup myself and it is cheap, reliable and extremely useful.

If you do decide to shut down the service, then it is only logical to have a parallel phasing-out of the existing system and phasing-in of the satellite system. Over a period of years you can slowly switch the MF off.
This will give hundreds ( or even thousands..) of MF users time to acquire new receivers and get them installed and tested, before the old systems is switched off.

It is perfectly understandable that you need to minimize costs and that old equipment is more expensive/difficult to repair...but please consider that often older equipment was in fact designed to be repaired and most modern equipment is desigend to be thrown-away instead of repaired,
(This greatly increases the costs of long term ownership).

I shall be sad to see a wonderful service that I have used for many years disappear. I hope you will reconsider.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bill Miller
Comment: Like many thousands of owners of small commercial and private vessels I do not have satellite communications on board. The loss of NAVTEX vy MF radio would degrade safety to an unacceptabe level for those unable to afford sattelite services

Title: Comment Submitted by Daan Roest
Comment:
As a professional mariner I think your proposal to end the NAVTEX transmissions are ill-founded. Instead of terminating the service, it will be better to modernize it.

In parts of the world like Europe, there is a reliable NAVTEX coverage available. All boats, including small recreational boats, can receive the messages. The equipment which is required is small and not too expensive. Inmarsat-C equipment is quite bulky and for some boats hard to install.

The problem with Inmarsat-C transmission is that it covers a very large area. This makes it difficult to analyse which messages are important for a certain area where someone is. By making specified NAVTEX area's you can send messages which are only relevant for that area. Anyone can understand those messages and directly know that these are important for them. 

I think it will be better to just use NAVTAX for coastal purposes only. Limited the service area to about 24 nm from the coastline. Specify the limits of the area's and make sure that you cover the whole coast. Send meteo and safety messages which are relevant to that area. 

In the mean time consult with IMO and other nations if an alternative system can be set up. I am thinking of a digital NAVTEX system which works via satellite and can be integrated in ECDIS and other electronic chart systems. That will be a better alternative then switching to Inmarsat-C. 

Daan Roest
Master Mariner
The Netherlands

Title: Comment Submitted by Kevin Mayley
Comment:
USCG-2019- 0702

The proposal to drop the broadcasting of MF NAVTEX messages and moving them to Satellite.

Whilst many commercial ships may have satellite communications systems, most small craft do not.  

There are those of us who use a MF/HF receiver and a laptop or smart phone to decode these vitally important messages.

One of the descriptions in USCG-2019- 0702 was that MF Navtex was a cheap to use system, surely if the existing equipment is becoming old and obsolete it is the time to replace them with modern cheaper versions. 

However cost should not over ride safety.

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Castle
Comment:
A very short comment.
Navtex is a system used by all either as a primary source or emergency backup. Yes, sat broadcast makes financial sense, but when it failes or you can't afford it, what will be the result?

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
My reaction on hearing of this proposal is : Do not do this.

It is typical of the "decisions" made by desk bound types, that put mariners lives at risk every hour of every day.

I view this as just another step in the long road since the 1990s close down of the 500 Kc/s CW distress systemand supporting Coast Station system that reduces the level of Safety at Life at Sea. Every step puts the lives at sea at greater risk.Specifically the reliance on unreliable satellite systems has severly degraded SOLAS in that ships near by do not hear Distress or other related traffic.. Point of fact GMDSS coverage is unreliable due to both patchy signal and inability to "point" under high-wind/storm conditions. Under such condition when sat-coms drop out is exactly   MF NAVTEX comes into it's own. This service should be extended not disbanded as both the U.S Coast Guard and the U.S Goverment should be pushing for expansion not abandoning it.

Title: Comment Submitted by Stephen H. Smyk
Comment: PLEASE UPGRADE TO SATILLITE!

Title: Comment Submitted by Eric Simmons
Comment:
Good day,

I am retired USCG and now a member of the USCG Auxiliary.  In total, I have almost 30 years of experience at land and sea with radio communications, both as a Professional and as an Amateur.

I realize, like anything else, that it costs money to maintain a system.  It's troublesome to figure out if there is any return on investment when it comes to determining if the system is of value to those that use it.

We are one good solar-flare away from losing satellite connectivity.  The USCG already divested itself from LORAN-C, which was a HUGE mistake, instead of investing in e-LORAN.  LORAN is far less susceptible to interference than satellite.  It would make for a great back-up to GPS in the event of natural or man-made interference or failure.  Likewise, terrestrial communications, especially on MF/HF, has been a proven communications medium for decades. Having an alternate means of communications to satellite is key to overall communications success.

I do not concur that parts are hard to find.  There are still companies that produce MF transmitters.  I think it would be very short-sighted of the USCG to abandon MF NAVTEX in favor of satellite.  If anything, I would recommend investing in its replacement, NAVDAT like the Europeans will be using.  In both cases, equipment for end-users is much less expensive compare to satellite-related equipment.

So, I am not in favor of shutting down NAVTEX.  Too many mariners that do not fall under the  GMDSS umbrella still use it and the non-satellite components of that system.  Furthermore, terrestrial communications aren't affected nearly as bad as satellite services can as discussed before.  Please don't let NAVTEX suffer the same fate of LORAN.

Title: Comment Submitted by Paul Zecchino
Comment:
Please continue the Medium Frequency NAVTEX service on 518 KHz. Please do not discontinue it. We rely on it, in particular during hurricane season. Thank you for your consideration.

                                                        Respectfully submitted,
                                                        Paul Vincent Zecchino



PV Zecchino
7245 Manasota Key Road
Englewood, FL, 34223-9306

Title: Comment Submitted by Brandon Lynch
Comment:
Please keep Natex , MFHF.  It is a vital back up to marine navigation, and weather forecasting, marine safety, and lifesaving.
Several lives have been saved. On board the GREEN Lake on December 31st 2018. First initial contact was made by MFHF by the Sincerity ACE. Green Lake immediately proceeded to location and saved the live of 7 persons.

Not all ship are equipped with satellite communications.


Additionally solely relying on Satellite communications would be poor seamanship..  We are already seeing GPS spoofs etc from Iran and other unstable countries. 


Docket ID: USCG-2019-0702Agency: Coast Guard (USCG)Parent Agency: Department of Homeland Security (DHS)

We have seen a significant reduction in quality of service in recent years to coast guard VHF-FM coverage, NOAA WX broadcast coverage, and elimination of USCG 2182 Khz watchstanding, please don't continue this reduction by eliminating NAVTEX. 

Thank you.

Matthew Musslewhite
USCG Licenesed Master, FCC Licensed radio operator/technician

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Please do not shut down the NAVTEX transmissions! They are a very useful and reliable backup safety feature. They increase my situational awareness greatly, and provide rock solid backup in case sat comms fail for any reason. Good seamanship demands multiple fail safes and sources of information to verify location and safe navigation. Dont delete a safeguard for no good reason. I am an actively sailing US Merchant Marine officer and I greatly appreciate NAVTEX.

Title: Comment Submitted by Todd Johnston
Comment: As an ocean tug captain, I strongly advise not to eliminate the NAVTEX system broadcast. Satellite broadcast sounds great, but the reliability is sketchy at best. I count on that radio broadcast message to keep myself and my crew alive; it's that simple.

Regarding satellite equipment, besides it being very expensive, I am also concerned about its potential sensitivity towards Solar activity and international conflicts.

Kind regards,
Tamas Godany
