Comment: As a vessel operator in Alaska, my experience has been that the satellite communication network is not reliable enough to be the sole source of information that is of critical importance to mariners.  Therefore, I strongly urge the USCG to NOT suspend the MF NAVTEX transmissions.

Title: Comment Submitted by Haley Golz
Comment: As a sea kayaker I opposed the termination of NAVTEX as a means to deliver weather and hazard information. Small paddle craft rely on handheld VHF marine band radios to check weather updates and receive hazard statements when paddling in remote environments.

Title: Comment Submitted by Zach Stewart
Comment: Please do not cease broadcast of weather alerts and forecast information over marine band VHF radio!  I operate a sea kayak outfitter and tour company on Lake Superior.  My guides and I rely heavily on marine band VHF weather broadcasts to keep thousands of people safe each season on the Great Lakes.  Safe operations for many outfitters on the Great Lakes would be compromised if we can't receive forecast information on the VHF.  We do not have satellite capability in our sea kayaks.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bryan Hawkins
Organization Name: City of Homer Port and Harbor
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this. 

I would like to confirm that this only affects the shipboard weather Fax machines and not the recorded (voice) area weather forecasts, or the Tsunami alert system.

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Monjure
Comment: The U.S. Coast Guard should continue with MF NAVTEX service.  It would be very unwise to rely on only one system for these coastal weather and navigational warnings.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mark Topley
Comment:
Dear Derrick Croinex, Chief, Spectrum Management and Telecommunications, U.S. Coast Guard (Commandant CG-672),


I am a "recreational mariner" who often operates outside of Sea Area A1 which is covered under USCG Rescue 21 facilities out to 20 nm offshore. I regularly travel from South Florida to the Northern & Central Bahamas which is located in Sea Area A2. As of Aug 2013, the United States has no Sea Area A2 service.  The US Coast Guard ceased 2 MHz infrastructure effective 1 August 2013 and the MF 2182 kHz International Distress frequency is no longer "watched" by USCG "watch standers". Most other countries still "watch" 2182 kHz except the USA! 

As you know, NAVTEX is an international automated medium frequency (518 kHz) direct-printing service for delivery of navigational and meteorological warnings and forecasts, as well as urgent marine safety information to ships. It was developed to provide a low-cost, simple, and automated means of receiving this information aboard ships at sea within approximately 200 nautical miles of shore. It basically provides marine navigation and weather information for Sea Area A2 operators. 

When I am outside of Sea Area A1 and 60 nm off the Florida coast, my only reliable delivery of navigational and meteorological warnings and forecasts, as well as urgent marine safety information to ships is from my 518 kHz NAVTEX receiver which sends me information 6 times a day along with any immediate Notices To Mariners. NOAA weather on VHF is out of range.

Please do not terminate this service! It provides a low cost important source of marine information and I can not afford a "satellite" NAVTEX service! Please keep us "recreational" mariners in mind who are not required to be GMDSS-regulated with satellite services. The MARCOMMS - INMARSAT C SAFETYNET is cost prohibitive to me at this time.

Thank you for your consideration in this matter.

Title: Comment Submitted by Michael St. Angelo
Comment: If Navetx is discontinuted I should be replaced with a weather reporting service which not dependent on satellite communications. Diverse communication is necessary in the event of issues with satellite systems.

Title: Comment Submitted by David J. Ring, Jr.
Comment:
Smaller vessels not equipped with Satellite communications equipment use NAVTEX to copy navigational warnings and other communications included in USCG  broadcasts.  Also in the time of satellite failure or interoperability having a system based on terrestrial radio broadcast to fall back upon is important, not only for pleasure vessels, but also for fishing vessels and merchant ships in local trade.  While EMP, or "Electro-Magnetic Pulse" generated by a hostile power against the United States or our neighbors, can easily destroy satellites, EMP does little to impact signals in the 400 to 600 kHz radio spectrum where NAVTEX is broadcast.

In this commenter's opinion, it is a minimal cost to provide an excellent service to mariners and navies.

Sincerely,

David J. Ring, Jr.
United States Merchant Marine
Radio Officer, Chief (Retired)

Title: Comment Submitted by John [Last Name Unknown]
Comment:
I am extremely opposed to this as it increases reliance on satellite services that may become inoperable, and if the occasion arises, would be of much greater cost to repair, and danger to mariners while offline. Medium Wave frequencies experience excellent propagation at times and receiving equipment is much simpler. 

Im addition to the above, shutting this service off would be of a great hindrance to the experimentation and scientific study  of medium wave propagation

Title: Comment Submitted by Christopher Hays
Comment:
As a long time amateur radio operator and commercial broadcast engineer (now retired), I am concerned that we continue marching to new technology without considering the fragility of the newer technology and the robustness of the older technology. Satellite links can become unreliable in severe weather conditions, and major solar events.  Additionally, the complex technology used can fail.  If it fails at a critical life safety moment, the results can be very serious.  

Terrestrial radio systems make excellent back up for satellite systems, and should not be abandoned.  A good communications receiver, a modem, and any laptop computer configured with appropriate software is all that is required on the ship. MF transmission systems can be upgraded to newer technology if older transmitter's maintenance becomes difficult.

Chris Hays
La Canada, CA
AB6QK

Title: Comment Submitted by M. Sanderson
Comment: As the operator of a recreational sailing vessel transiting the waters between the East Ciast of North America and the Caribbean I utilize a  Navtex along HF transceiver for weather forecasting during offshore passages. I do not have satellite communication devices onboard as they are cost prohibitive. The Navtex onboard my vessel  provides a reliable cost effective passive way in which to receive  and review reliable weather forecasts. I am concerned that if support for Navtex is abandoned this will compromise the ability for operators of small vessels like me to access reliable weather forecasts offshore and overall safety at sea.

Title: Comment Submitted by David Gurney
Comment: The current NAVTEX systems has been working well   and is well proven.   Owners have invested money and appreciate  having this resource.  Any new  navigational system should only compliment the current system  NOT replace.!

Title: Comment Submitted by The Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS) Task Force and The Radio Technical Commission For Maritime Services (RTCM)
Comment:
COMBINED COMMENTS OF THE GLOBAL MARITIME DISTRESS AND SAFETY SYSTEM (GMDSS) TASK FORCE AND THE RADIO TECHNICAL COMMISSION FOR MARITIME SERVICES (RTCM)
...
Included herein are the main points of our submission. The attached file includes the complete comments that were approved by a Working Group consisting of designated representatives of both organizations. 
...

  1. U.S. Withdrawal from Existing GMDSS Services. Recognizing the stated budgetary reasons for the proposed change, and the fact that no decision has yet been made, the Working Group never the less finds it unfortunate that the U.S. as one of the most prominent members of the IMO and also one of the best able to meet its financial obligations, finds it necessary to withdraw from part of the International NAVTEX Service, and terminating U.S. participation diminishes the whole service. This was clearly the case when the U.S. earlier withdrew from providing the International MF-DSC GMDSS coastal services that provided Ocean Area A2 GMDSS coverage, again due to a budgetary shortfall.

 2. Recommend Extending Response Period. The Working Group also feels that the 60 days provided for comment is inadequate to reach many components of the maritime community. SOLAS ships already watch satellite broadcasts of Maritime Safety Information (MSI) but the smaller non-SOLAS vessels that use NAVTEX voluntarily are hard to reach in such a short time through the print media which need a longer lead time to reach their far flung clients.  Therefore a comment period of 120 days is recommended. The Working Group is also of the opinion that any shift to satellite broadcasting of coastal MSI should not commence before the U.S. sponsored Iridium system begins IMO approved MSI broadcasting via its SafetyCAST system. 

 3. Increased Cost to Government of Satellite MSI Broadcasting. While the option of satellite broadcasting may be technically feasible, it would also come at a significant and at present indeterminate recurring cost to both the Coast Guard and the National Weather Service (NWS).  The NWS has not considered any additional expenditure.  The volume of U.S. coastal NAVTEX broadcasts is believed to greatly exceed the volume of U.S. high seas SafetyNET broadcasting via Inmarsat. Further adding to this cost is the need to duplicate all of the Inmarsat broadcasts on the other new IMO recognized satellite system, Iridiums SafetyCAST. 

 4. Increased Cost to Vessels to Receive Satellite MSI Broadcasts. Vessels receiving MSI via satellite broadcasts are not charged for the service but must pay for acquiring the necessary equipment This is not considered a problem for SOLAS class vessels which are already equipped to receive both NAVTEX and Inmarsat SafetyNET broadcasts but smaller voluntary vessels will need to acquire equipment to receive the satellite broadcasts. For comparison purposes the current cost of a basic NAVTEX receiver is around $750. The estimated cost of Inmarsat-C terminals ranges from $2500 to $6500 plus installation and any annual fees involved. The cost of a new GMDSS certified Iridium terminal is unknown but is probably in excess of $3000 plus installation and an annual fee. It has also been determined that a new GMDSS certified Iridium terminal would be required to receive SafetyCAST broadcasts rather than existing non-GMDSS terminals. These voluntary craft are the most vulnerable and it would be a shame if they decided to opt-out of receiving satellite Maritime Safety Information (MSI) due to the cost.

 5. Alternatives to Satellite Broadcasting of MSI. The Working Group has also briefly looked at several alternatives to terminating NAVTEX broadcasting that should be considered but most would require extensive study to determine feasibility and many would appear to be more costly than rehabilitating the NAVTEX system. Instead, we feel that a rigorous cost benefit analysis emphasizing the cost to users should be undertaken.

 6. Cost Benefit Analysis Recommended. It does not appear that a cost benefit analysis of the proposed coastal MSI broadcasting options has been conducted and it is strongly suggested that this be undertaken before making a final decision. Any cost benefit analysis should compare the cost of refurbishing and running the existing USCG NAVTEX infrastructure compared with the cost of implementing and running an alternative solution, which should include not only the cost of broadcasting the information over both SafetyNET and SafetyCAST, but also the cost to mariners and especially recreational boaters, of having to purchase new equipment to replace their existing NAVTEX terminals and pay for an annual service plan.

This comment was approved in scope and general approach by the GMDSS Task Force at its meeting on 19 September 2019 and the RTCM at its Board Meeting on 16 September 2019 and refined with final editing by the Working Group of designated representatives of both organizations on 8 October 2019.

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Rustchak
Comment:
I sail as Master of an oceangoing articulated tug and barge, which operates in waters from Canada to Texas and the Bahamas.  We frequently operate in Sea Area A2. I find NAVTEX an invaluable resource which is far superior to reliance on VHF or MF voice broadcasts for weather and marine safety information.   I cannot see that the relatively minimal cost of upgrading radio transmitters is justified. Much valuable information is currently transmitted in a simple fashion via NAVTEX and received by thousands of vessels equipped for reception. 
I am strongly opposed to the discontinuance of this service.

Title: Comment Submitted by Pete Devaris
Comment:
This proposal grossly underestimates the financial and negative safety impacts that termination of NAVTEX will have on all types of vessels; from ocean going tugs to sea kayaks. The greatest impacts will be to the smaller, more vunerable vessels.  Recreational vessels collectively are the largest users of this information and nearly NONE of these vessels currently have a GMDSS satellite terminal onboard. 

I find NAVTEX an invaluable resource which is far superior to reliance on VHF or MF voice broadcasts for weather and marine safety information. Much valuable information is currently transmitted in a simple fashion via NAVTEX and received by thousands of vessels equipped for reception. 

While there is no question that IMO satellite services can provide more reliable international delivery of navigational, meteorological warnings, forecasts, and urgent maritime safety information, it is NOT a substitute for NAVTEX. The USGC should be upgrading NAVTEX while also enabling IMO Satellite services. Do both.

I believe this proposal speaks to general dilapidated infrastructure of the entire marine system. We routinely go months, sometimes years, with broken weather bouys, navigational aids, transmitters, etc.; all within some of the most dangerous and busiest waters in our country. Please do not let this cost saving measure further degrade the safety of the fleet.

As a licensed Captain operating in Alaskan waters, I am strongly opposed to the discontinuance of this service.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bryan Elliott
Comment: I use this service weekly.  It is a valuable tool for the areas I boat.  There is no cell service.  Eliminating this service would place people at risk who boat.  This is a mistake.

Title: Comment Submitted by John Chenis
Comment:
U.S.C.G.


     I was employed for more than thirty years as an Electronic Engineer at a company whose main purpose was to manufacture and sell weather data equipment. The products included Wefax and Navtex receivers.  One of my duties included an assignment to evaluate Navtex active antennas. 

     Upon my return from the assignment, I continued to evaluate both active and passive antennas.  Navtex Text (not limited to) includes weather data, weather alerts, whale locations and navigational problems, such as buoys out of location and/or non- operational.  The mariners on board ships and boats depend on important Navtex messages.  Discontinuing Navtex transmissions would place these seafaring individuals at risk.  

     Through the elimination of the Navtex transmission, the mariners would be forced into acquiring new equipment. This would include the cost of installation for a receiver and antennae in order to receive this data by satellite. The cost to receive this data transmission would be extremely expensive per minute. 

 In my opinion, the Navtex data should continue for the health and welfare of these Marines. 

Sincerely,

Title: Comment Submitted by Richard Hudson
Comment:
For a small vessel, NAVTEX is simple to install and operate.  In my experience of using both NAVTEX and satellite receivers,  a NAVTEX receiver, due to its simplicity, is more likely to be functional, especially in bad weather, than a satellite receiver.  

Many times, in rough weather, it was such a relief to be able to simply scroll thru the display on the NAVTEX to see the latest forecast.  That is much easier than booting up a computer to look at email from the Iridium satellite receiver on my yacht.   NAVTEX has been far more reliable for me than the satellite equipment that I have used.

NAVTEX is a very reliable, easy-to-use and inexpensive way of receiving weather and safety information.  Discontinuing it would be a loss for the small vessel operators that use it.

Title: Comment Submitted by Gordon Taylor, Chelsea Sunset
Comment: I have been involved with or in commercial fishing for over 50 years and had several smallish boats. None of them have had satellite radios. There are thousands of boats in Alaska that use vhf marine radios now. It would be a huge push to totally change format of comunication for the commercial and recreational fleets.

Title: Comment Submitted by Dag Hanssen
Comment:
Do not shut down the Navtex system.
It is a great safety tool for us recreational boaters with no access to Satellite or SSB radio forecasts.
In The Bahamas weather information is hard to come by in remote areas, we NEED the Navtex system.
Thx
Dag Hanssen 
Fort Lauderdale, FL
954-465-4116
csy33@comcast.net

Title: Comment Submitted by Naomi Demmert
Comment: I believe that if we switch the systems to a subscription based system in which mariners will have to pay for to have access to the vital information that is shared on these systems, we will see an increase in maritime distress calls. We will lose more ships, and especially small boats. Although commercial vessels may be able to make the cost work, I believe most recreational vessels will not. I believe in the long run, with out this information system being easy to use and free, the Coast Guard will spend more money and resources on increased rescue calls than they will on upgrading the system already in place. I believe upgrading the free system will better preserve the lives and safety everyone who uses vessels and spends time on the ocean.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ammie Parker
Comment:
Strongly disagree with adding additional regulations to mariners.  The current system is working that provides
a basic service to the fleet.  Adding more restrictions opens the door to less personnel having access and thus, could result in 
more mariners without access to weather reports and more SAR cases.  The ends don't justify the means.  Newer is not always
better.

Title: Comment Submitted by Michael Charavell
Comment:
It doesn't make sense to discontinue use of a system when there seems to be no real benefit to the marine community.

MF NAVTEX system may seem like an un-necessary cost to maintain in the face of current Inmarsat and up coming Iridium GMDSS availability. However the safety would be greatly reduced for voluntarily equipped private, and commercial vessels. There are thousands of NAVTEX equipped vessels and many more look at the service every day. The average NAVTEX receiver can be had for under $1000 while a GMDSS access point can often exceed $5000 making it a cost many mariners would not expend.

It seems to be poor judgement to reduce the safety of the oceans by going exclusively to satellite.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I agree with concerns over cyber security, solar flares, and location based spotty service, however any type of system will work great until it doesn't. If the MF NAVTEX system is old and rundown it could break just as easy as any of the previously mentioned concerns. I say we move forward with a new more advanced satellite system. After all many people were against shutting down Loran-C and now look how far we've come. New technology isn't bad and some people are just afraid of change and learning how to use the new tech.

Title: Comment Submitted by Leslie Lincoln
Organization Name: US Merchant Marine, Radio Electronics Officer
Comment:
NAVTEX is proven, trusted and relied upon as a world-wide passive receive radio system for Search & Rescue, Military Exercise, Navigational and Weather warnings.  Having used NAVTEX for the last 21 years, and relying upon it daily aboard ship; I can testify to its critical value.  I strongly urge decision makers to keep the system operational.   

NAVTEX is our primary warning re: localized military operations during busy coastal transits.  NAVTEX broadcasts have repeatedly enabled Captains to alter course to avoid confusion and areas of Military bombing and other exercises.

NAVTEX Weather forecasting reaches well beyond 100 nautical miles and is clear and timely.  Receiving updated weather warnings in this time of climate anomalies and change is at the heart of marine safety.  

Weather Warnings and Forecasts are especially important as new low pressure systems pick up speed and now travel more than the previous 20 knots as per two decades ago.  Now hurricane and storm force lows (the large systems) can travel at 30 to 40 to 55 knots.  Add storm movement speed to the internal storm winds and see that the mariners at sea must safely respond and navigate around increasingly unstable and fast moving weather situations.   Thus timely weather forecasting is more important than ever before and we should only be adding safety precautions that work with proven systems; not consider reducing available means for vulnerable vessels at sea to receive safety broadcasts.

With these increasing weather dangers and anomalies, this is NOT a good time to eliminate a functioning, well-used Marine Weather Forecast system already installed aboard thousands of vessels.  

Also, please consider that NAVTEX SAR (Search and Rescue) messages which actually trigger alarms aboard vessel, these NAVTEX SAR messages directly alert mariners to save life at sea; the original intent of this appreciated NAVTEX system.  Unfortunately incoming EGC Satellite C SAR messages- such as relayed EPIRB Distress messages, do not always trigger alerts and can be missed or overlooked on a busy bridge.  Whereas SAR alerts on the NAVTEX are easily checked to see if any distress is near the ships area.   These potentially Life Saving messages, such as man-overboard, capsized or submerged vessels should NOT disappear into a quagmire of Satellite messages; many of which are not received by numerous local fishing, recreational, cruising or non-satellite equipped vessels.

Pls do NOT reduce the availability of mariners safety information on a well-established and functioning system.  We rely on the NAVTEX broadcasts daily.  May you decide for the improved Safety of Life at Sea to keep this working, valued NAVTEX system intact.

Respectfully submitted,
Ms. Leslie Lincoln, Radio Electronics Officer aboard MATSON TACOMA (Washington to Alaska Run).  
 -21 yrs in the US Merchant Marine with the American Radio Association (GMDSS Operator-Maintainer +)  
 -As well as 20 more years as an Offshore Sailor and Commercial Fisherman

Title: Comment Submitted by John Lorentzen
Comment: Have fished commercially for salmon outside Cordova AK for decades.  This VHF broadcast is vital to prevent the loss of life.

Title: Comment Submitted by Dave Anderson
Comment:
I had a long and persuasive (and pretty boring) response to post.

I reread it again and said to heck with it.

If the U.S. Coast Guard cannot see that doing away with a tried and reliable system that is in use domestically and internationally by many thousands of commercial and recreational users is not a good idea, then nothing I can say will change their minds.

If mariner safety is not important to them then they are in the wrong jobs.

I can come up with reasons not to shut down NAVTEX until the antarctic completely melts, but the short answer is -

DON'T KILL NAVTEX.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lloyd Roach
Comment: As a holder of a GMDSS Operator/Maintainers License and a Commercial Radiotelegraph ticket, I am astounded that the leadership of the USCG would consider abandoning an excellent and reliable low-cost system that saves lives for the purpose of saving money. In the notice that was authored by Mr. Derrick J. Croinex, he stated that, "...the equipment is antiquated and essential replacement parts are difficult and hard to find and expensive."   As a former licensee of a number of commercial medium wave radio stations, I say this excuse is baloney!  Why should the Coast Guard risk lives because of their ineptitude in keeping their equipment properly maintained and updated?  This is a disgrace.  Keep the 518 KHz NAVTEX Broadcasts operational. Everyone else in the world seems to know how to do this, why not the USGG?  Lloyd Bankson Roach -lloyd@bedfordcountyspeaks.com

Title: Comment Submitted by Gerald Harris
Comment:
Background to the comment:  For a user, NAVTEX is a moderately inexpensive way to receive a limited amount of weather information. The Garmin inreach system is about the same cost, provides nearly equivalent weather information but doesnt provide safety and other notices that may be included in NAVTEX.  Sirius provides weather info, but at a somewhat increased cost. Again, no safety info, Inmarsat and other sat access systems are too expensive for casual use.

USCG has a finite budget and resources. The use of those resources and budget for NAVTEX needs to be risk assessed against comparable demands with a focus on safety of USCG personnel and the marine community, in particular potential death, injury and property damage as well as operating cost. If USCG has a need to communicate more information to achieve its safety and injury avoidance objectives than the low cost commercial solutions permit, that should be included in the risk assessment.  A proper, complete risk assessment done by experts that doesnt prejudge any particular outcome compared to other similarly risk assessed demands on USCG resources and budget is the best way to make the decision. In this process, the various risk assessments are compared against each other in a risk matrix format, where the risk matrix ranks the options on probability of occurrence on one axis and severity of consequence on another axis. Ideally, any publication of the final determination from USCG on NAVTEX would include the results and details of both the risk assessment and the linked risk matrix outcome.

Title: Comment Submitted by Elizabeth Hooge
Comment:
My husband & I have been inland & nearshore mariners in southcentral & southeast Alaska for nearly 30 yrs. The proposal to eliminate medium-frequency Navtex broadcasts in favor of private satellite subscription services is a terrible idea.

The proposal doesn't sufficiently address the initial cost of purchasing eqpt & the ongoing monthly/annual costs of satellite subscription. At this time, there is only one extremely expensive company authorized, with a 2nd "soon to come" (cost, reliability, simplicity all yet unknown). Perhaps large vessels can afford these costs, but in Alaska thousands of mariners in small craft rely upon timely, consistent, dependable broadcasts of weather & safety info - at reasonable cost. Navtex is a fairly inexpensive and reliable - due to its simplicity & track record - method to receive that info. VHF broadcasts by USCG and by NOAA-NWS aren't reliably received over large portions of Alaskan inland & nearshore waters due to geography/topography & recent reductions in service. To eliminate one reliable method of receiving life-saving info is to derelict the USCG's duty to distribute that information in a manner that actually works for US citizens, not to mention our international treaty obligations.

USCG itself warns that internet-based methods to receive Navtex & other weather/safety info aren't fully reliable, warning it can't influence the reliability of internet delivery. One wonders why USCG believes that private-satellite-based methods will be more reliable, because certainly the USCG won't be able to influence *that* - as opposed to their own proven ability to maintain & broadcast Navtex via terrestrial MF radio bases. There is inconsistency in that logic. If one follows this logic, then VHF broadcasts by USCG & NOAA-NWS to nearshore mariners also should be turned over to satellite services, because surely those terrestrial VHF transmitters are costly to maintain? And yet we certainly hope/assume that this concept would never be considered due to the reliability & track record & low cost & ease to the end-user of receiving VHF. These same arguments apply to MF Navtex as well.

We also wonder why the US is proposing to go a different route than all other GMDSS/SOLAS nations, which aren't changing their delivery method for GMDSS data. If terrestrial broadcast still works well for them, why would the US change our method of cooperation & contribution, in a direction that requires costly eqpt & subscriptions? We should not renege on our international obligations; other nations rely on our cooperation, & our own citizens do the same when navigating foreign waters. This is an example of the US "going it alone" when the safer (and more efficient for mariners) path is to continue to cooperate with other nations.

Additionally, this is an example of our federal gov't privatizing an important service to US citizens rather than investing in the -yes, costly- infrastructure required to maintain the service. The result will be that those with plenty of money will have no problem still receiving the Navtex service. The rest of us - well, too bad, we'll have to do without - & our lives and property will be at greater risk than before. Meanwhile, Inmarsat & Iridium are both privately owned companies that will profit from this USCG divestment of responsibility. The profit motive has no place in crucial life-saving services, & the federal gov't certainly should not abdicate its responsibility to citizens so that profit-driven companies can serve only the wealthy.

Meanwhile, whether MF Navtex broadcasts are eliminated or not, we have suggestions either to mitigate the loss or improve the penetration of Navtex data to end-users: Please make GMDSS info available on simple bookmark-able websites that can be accessed via simple low-bandwidth internet-receiving equipment (so, not solely via links on another web page; they need to be simple text, accessible directly with a fixed URL). This type of eqpt, unlike dedicated satellite receivers & services, is less expensive and thus more accessible for small craft operators. These simple-bookmarked Navtex websites should be updated *just* as frequently as the MF radio broadcasts, *and* they should include inland waters of Alaska due to the inconsistency of VHF to reach many inland areas throughout the coast of Alaska - unlike the lower 48 states where VHF can reliably be received from nearly all navigable waters. Regardless of the reliability of internet & regardless of USCG inability to influence that reliability, many mariners do nonetheless receive weather & safety information via internet, especially in Alaska where VHF reception is uncertain as already noted. If USCG considers satellite reliable enough to become the sole means of distributing Navtex, then surely in order to reach as many mariners as possible, Navtex should also be distributed via internet, in a method as easily accessible as possible, & covering as much geography as possible.

Title: Comment Submitted by Dominic Maionchi
Comment: Please do not terminate.  There are many that rely on NAVTEX.

Title: Comment Submitted by Kelly Anderson, The American Radio Association (ARA)
Comment:
The American Radio Association (ARA) respectfully submits its comments in response to USCG Docket No. USCG 2019-0702, proposing possible termination of MF NAVTEX broadcasts after first assuring the information contained in NAVTEX broadcasts is available via International Maritime Organization (IMO) recognized satellite services. 

American Radio Association was established in 1938.  Our members sail aboard U.S. Flag vessels as Master Radio Electronic Officers and as Electronic Officers on MARAD Ready Reserve Fleet ships and Military Sealift Command ships engaged in the national defense.  As professional communicators ARA members have been supporting safety and distress communications from the days of Morse Code to the present Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS).  Shipboard Radio Officers have been at the forefront of communications technology every step of the way.  ARA Master Radio Electronics Officers continue to maintain responsibility for ship-to-shore communications, retaining expertise across a spectrum of high seas communication and navigation systems as well as other shipboard electronics.  ARA is therefore in a unique position to provide an in depth understanding of both emerging satellite systems and the enduring value of NAVTEX for safety of life at sea.

NAVTEX is proven, trusted and relied upon as a world-wide passive receive radio system for Search & Rescue (SAR); Military Exercise; Navigational and Weather warnings. It provides a low-cost, simple, and automated means of receiving information aboard ships and smaller vessels at sea within approximately 250 nautical miles of shore. On its international automated medium frequency MF (518 kHz) NAVTEXs narrow-band direct-printing service is location selectable.  Mariners select appropriate shore-side broadcast station codes to receive marine safety and timely weather warnings specific for their sea location. Additionally, NAVTEXs high frequency, HF 4209.5 kHz broadcasts offer coverage out several thousand nautical miles; thus NAVTEX Maritime Safety Information (MSI) messages touch well beyond coastal waters, reaching well out to sea for offshore fishermen, tugs and barge operators, recreational vessels and offshore sailors around the world. 

This world-wide coverage and easy reception reaches thousands of mariners who rely on it daily.   Such terrestrial radio wave propagation is robust, proven over decades and does not require any subscription fees once the receiving unit is purchased and installed.  Proposing to eliminate NAVTEX is not in the best interest of protecting the global mariners safety net.  NAVTEX terrestrial broadcast for the mariner is akin to an at-sea pubic emergency broadcast service which critically reaches all users as needed.  Removing this service would be like asking the public to no longer count on receiving emergency broadcasts on their own radios, rather require them to set up much more sophisticated and costly equipment for such critical survival information.  Recognizing the considerable investment by thousands of marine users who have bought, installed, learned to use and depend upon NAVTEX is just one significant reason for continuing its use for the safety of life at sea.

A strong Coast Guard communications and safety system requires that funding be provided for powerful land station-based radio communication systems as well as satellite based system. Both are important and worth supporting. 

ARA recommends investing in MF/HF maintenance, repair and upgraded services so that the USCG can be a leader in maritime safety in the years ahead.  We already understand that the equipment for marine end-users is much less expensive compare to satellite-based equipment and NAVTEX is proven to save lives.  After decades of use, mariners can still say it is the most reliable source of weather data and forecasts on board.   Discontinuation of the NAVTEX service would be a withdrawal of a vital safety service. 

ARA strongly recommends NOT to discontinue NAVTEX broadcasts, which would reduce the availability of safety information on a well-established and functioning system.  We rely on the NAVTEX broadcasts daily.   Ending these vital broadcasts in favor of a subscription-based satellite transmission system is not the best option.  We must remember that satellite systems are vulnerable, thus the prudent navigator will rely on a variety of survival communication equipment.  We need to vigilantly guard the safety of our fleet of mariners at sea.  Any new navigational system should only compliment the current system not replace what is proven to work well.  


	Respectfully Submitted,

	Kelly A. Anderson, President
	American Radio Association, AFL-CIO

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Brown
Comment:
I keep abreast of Navtex Bulletins while on land and use them for demonstration and educational purposes.
In a professional way the change to satellite would not affect me but in scienctific and educational way it would.
I support whatever decision you come up with regarding eliminating the MF Navtex service.

Title: Comment Submitted by Paul Newland
Comment:
RE:  Docket No. USCG-2019-0702, Document Number: 2019-19675, Proposed Termination of U.S. Coast Guard Medium Frequency (MF) Broadcast of Navigational Telex (NAVTEX) and Shift to Satellite.

PART 1 OF 2, COMMENTS OF PAUL NEWLAND
THESE COMMENTS ARE ENTERED ONLINE AS TWO SUBMISSIONS BECAUSE OF THE 5000 CHARACTER LIMIT OF THIS ONLINE TEXT ENTRY SYSTEM.

In the public notice as published in the Federal Register regarding Docket USCG-2019-0702, (the Document), in the section titled Public Participation and Request for Comments, it states: We encourage you to submit comments (or related material) on the possible termination of the U.S. Coast Guard's broadcast of MF NAVTEX.  I am not an off-shore mariner, however I accept the invitation provided in the Document to offer my comments on issues and items raised in the Document.   Please consider this an amicus submission, rather than a user submission.

Im trained as an electrical engineer, and in one of my professional endeavors I wrote software to run on a microcontroller that implemented an ASCII<-->SITOR-B code converter, SITOR-B being the data transmission format use for NAVTEX, onto which NAVTEX headers are layered.  I then placed that ASCII<-->SITOR-B code converter, with the help of technician staff at the respective radio stations, into service at several USA based shore stations to broadcast traffic lists via MF and HF radio to ships at sea using SITOR-B mode.  It was a very simple, low-cost system on the transmit side; yet it was also effective.

I agree with RTCM/GMDSS-Task-Force filed comments regarding the need for a cost/benefit analysis before discontinuing USCG NAVTEX transmissions.  It would seem to me that one datum fundamental to the issue of whether USCG should continue or terminate NAVTEX transmissions (not considering possible international treaty obligations) is the USCGs annual cost for NAVTEX transmissions per active NAVTEX recipient.  For example, if it costs USCG $3 million dollars a year to keep USCG NAVTEX transmissions operational and there are only 500 NAVTEX recipients for whom the proposed satellite services alternative is not viable, that would be a cost to USCG of $6000 per NAVTEX recipient.  If the cost per user was actually that high, then termination of USCG NAVTEX transmissions (not considering possible international treaty obligations) could very well be justified.  But *that* is not the rational or reasoning presented in the Document for discontinuing USCG NAVTEX transmissions, nor are data on that issue presented by USCG in the Document.

In the Discussion section of the Document, in paragraph one, the attributes (I presume from the perspective of the USCG) of the NAVTEX system are stated as: NAVTEX provides a low-cost, automated means of receiving this information aboard ships at sea out to approximately 100 nautical miles off shore.  Other commenters on the Document have affirmed the low cost of shipboard NAVTEX decoding devices, and a few others have pointed out that a modest laptop running free software and a modest SSB MF receiver are all that are needed to receive NAVTEX messages (although these ad-hoc receiving systems are not GMDSS compliant, they appear to be useful nonetheless to some NAVTEX users who are not mandated to be GMDSS compliant).  From both the USCG and users comments, it appears to be agreed that the NAVTEX system is low cost.

In the Discussion section of the Document, in paragraph two, there is a sentence that states: The current MF NAVTEX equipment is in dire need of replacement.   I assume that this assessment of dire need of replacement was not delivered by USCG NAVTEX operators or maintainers to their respective managers only within the last few months; I assume its not a recent revelation.  Was it unforeseen years ago by USCG management that at some point in the future that the USCGs NAVTEX transmission infrastructure would need to be updated to some extent? The Document doesnt describe the sequence of events that led to this current situation of dire need of replacement.

END OF PART 1 OF 2

Title: Comment Submitted by Paul Newland (2nd Comment)
Comment:
RE:  Docket No. USCG-2019-0702, Document Number: 2019-19675, Proposed Termination of U.S. Coast Guard Medium Frequency (MF) Broadcast of Navigational Telex (NAVTEX) and Shift to Satellite.

PART 2 OF 2, COMMENTS OF PAUL NEWLAND
THESE COMMENTS ARE ENTERED ONLINE AS TWO SUBMISSIONS BECAUSE OF THE 5000 CHARACTER LIMIT OF THIS ONLINE TEXT ENTRY SYSTEM.

In the Discussion section of the Document, in paragraph two, there is a sentence that states: The equipment is antiquated and essential replacement parts are difficult to find and expensive, placing overall operation of MF NATEX at risk.  Is there a USCG memo that has been released to the public that details the specifics of this difficult to find situation?  How difficult is difficult to find?   Does Canada face a similar problem with respect to their NAVTEX infrastructure?  Does Japan, UK, Australia, Germany, Spain, France or Norway?  I realize that these other countrys hardware and software systems may be different than that currently in use by USCG for NAVTEX transmissions, but if USCG current NAVTEX infrastructure is expensive to repair and maintain, then why not use the equipment that is being used in other countries, if those other countries dont face a similar problem? 

I freely admit that I dont understand all the issues that USCG faces with respect to costs to provide NAVTEX transmissions, and costs of maintaining or replacing the associated software and hardware to produce those transmissions.  The primary rational for USCGs proposal to terminate their NAVTEX service as stated in the Document is not a possible perceived high cost per NAVTEX user to produce NAVTEX transmissions, a cost that is borne by USCG, nor is lack of efficacy or utility of the NAVTEX messages delivered to mariners stated in the document as a reason for USCG to discontinue NAVTEX transmissions.  Instead, the stated reason in the Document for terminating USCG NAVTEX transmissions is because essential replacement parts are difficult to find and expensive  That seems to me to be a very weak reason for discontinuing a safety telecommunications service.

Finally, the Document does not address the issue of USCG possibly enhancing or replacing NAVTEX with NAVDAT (https://www.itu.int/dms_pub/itu-r/opb/rep/R-REP-M.2443-2019-PDF-E.pdf ).  In the 2017 Federal Radionavigation Plan ( https://rosap.ntl.bts.gov/view/dot/32801 ) on page 6-3, paragraph three, there is text that states: the USCG has established a Cooperative Research and Development Agreement to develop a prototype Navigational Data maritime broadcast (NAVDAT) system as an enhancement to the existing NAVTEX system.  Is that statement no longer operative?   If USCG is proposing to terminate NAVTEX transmissions in the near future what implications does that have for USCGs intentions with respect to deploying NAVDAT in the next few years?

Respectfully submitted,

Paul Newland

Title: Comment Submitted by Julie Sturtevant
Comment: Please do not make this change current service helps all stay safe and proposed changes will be restrictive and life endangering to those with limited resources unable to afford satellite services

Title: Comment Submitted by Jesse Dalton
Comment: Please do not terminate. There are many that rely on NAVTEX.

Title: Comment Submitted by Tim Rulon
Comment:
I am a retired civilian employee with the National Weather Service, NOAA. During the last 20 years of my employment I served as the Marine Dissemination Program Manager.  As such I have detailed knowledge of the inner workings of the U.S. GMDSS program.  For a variety of reasons, some of which are outlined below, I believe the USCG's proposal to shift broadcast of Maritime Safety Information (MSI) from NAVTEX to satellite  (Inmarsat-C SafetyNet) is not a viable option. Before any action is taken, the USCG should undertake a cost-benfit analysis fully taking into account the total economic picture and impact to mariners safety.

1) As an alternative to NAVTEX within GMDSS Sea Area A1, although the USCG conducts an MSI broadcast program, this program does not fully incorporate all the MSI relevant to this area, as an in-depth audit would reveal.

2) As an alternative to NAVTEX within Sea Area A1, reception of MSI via VHF requires labor-intensive human intervention 24x7 (as compared to the printed NAVTEX) which is not a viable option for vessels involved in maritime operations such as fishing. Audible data is also easily garbled, misinterpreted or errors made in transcription.

3) NOAA broadcast of weather related MSI via NOAA Weather Radio should not be considered as an option for receiving MSI as GMDSS VHF radios are not required to incorporate NOAA Weather Radio frequencies nor is NOAA Weather Radio a part of the GMDSS.

4) For reasons 1-3 above I believe the USCG was in error in declaring Sea Area A1 areas around the United States. Although the GMDSS carriage requirements for MSI could then be met by the addition of a NAVTEX receiver, the USCG's proposal would now require vessels strictly operating within Sea Area A1 to carry the much more expensive and complex Inmarsat-C transceiver.  Hence all U.S. coastal areas would then have to be defined as Sea Area A3.

5) The proposal by the USCG to terminate NAVTEX does not fully account for the tremendous number of non-GMDSS vessels operating along the coast which equip with NAVTEX voluntarily. A large percentage of these vessels are unlikely to be able to equip with Inmarsat-C given the additional acquisition and recurring costs, complexity, power, size, and weight of this equipment as compared to NAVTEX. 

6) As the largest provider of MSI via NAVTEX, the cost to NOAA in switching to satellite would likely be on the order of $500K or more annually. This cost could double or more with additional MSI providers such as a Iridium. I believe NOAA is unlikely to be able to deal with such a required increase in their capital budget.

7) SafetyNet is a 600 baud system. Does it even have the technical capacity to transmit 2 to 5 times (as a very rough ballpark) the existing level of transmissions? And then if further participants in the GMDSS were to do likewise?  What technical impact would this have on Iridium's proposed service? This all requires careful investigation and coordination internationally.

8) The U.S. NAVTEX services are a part of a larger international GMDSS NAVTEX service.  Consequently terminating U.S. NAVTEX affects and diminishes the whole.  

9) NAVTEX is used globally and transmitting equipment is available. There is no need to force a transition to a different technology at this time. I further believe that alternatives such as NAVDAT are too far on the horizon to be given serious consideration in the near term

Title: Comment Submitted by Randal Moseman, Best Shot Alaskan Adventures, LLC
Comment:
I regularly boat out of Southcentral Alaska in Prince William Sound, Resurrection Bay, and Kachemak Bay.  I am very often in areas that do not have any cell phone coverage and I do not have a satellite receiver to get NOAA weather reporting.  Receiving the NOAA reports on my VHF radio is the only way that I have to tell of impending storms that can and will endanger lives on my vessel.  The USCG rescue services are typically hours away from us when we are working.  Not being able to receive NOAA weather reports may very well cause the USCG more money in the end due to increased rescue services that may be required as cancellation of this service.

I feel that USCG needs to seriously review this proposal as cancellations of this service will potentially lead to increased rescue costs, and it receipt of the reporting is critical to our boating safety in Alaska.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ellen Hannan
Comment:
There are many of us who rely on USCG MF Broadcast of NAVTEX for safety everyday here in Southeast Alaska.  There are many small boats that will never be able to shift to satellite at present costs.  Please continue with the broadcasts as we know it.  It saves lives.

Ellen Hannan
Commercial Fisherman and year round boater
Craig, Alaska

Title: Comment Submitted by Rick Schikora
Comment:
I regularly (summer and shoulder seasons) boat out of Sitka in Southeast Alaska. I am very often in areas that do not have any cell phone coverage (five minutes north of Sitka, we lose cell and internet coverage).  I do not have a satellite receiver to get NOAA weather reporting. Receiving the NOAA reports on my VHF radio is the only way that I have to tell of impending storms that can endanger lives on my boat. Not often, but several times, we have had to return to port a day or two early to avoid weather.  The USCG rescue services are typically hours away from us when we are recreating - we do everything we can to avoid the need for their services. For boaters to not be able to receive NOAA weather reports via VHF radio from Biorka Island may very well cause increased rescue services.

I believe that USCG needs to seriously review this proposal as cancellations of this service could lead to increased rescue costs.  Receipt of good VHF weather reporting is critical to our boating safety in Alaska.

Title: Comment Submitted by James Gamble, Pacific Environment
Comment:
To: U.S. Coast Guard
From: Pacific Environment
Re: Proposed termination of U.S. Coast Guard Medium Frequency (MF) Broadcast of Navigational Telex (NAVTEX) and shift to satellite; Comments on Docket Number: USCG-2019-0702
Date: November 12, 2019

Pacific Environment is a non-governmental (NGO) organization with consultative status at the International Maritime Organization (IMO). As a key organizer among NGOs, we advocate for reducing shipping-related risks to the environment and coastal communities, and for protecting mariners and wildlife, especially in the Arctic. 

Pacific Environment is submitting comments regarding the possible termination of broadcasting Navigational Telex (NAVTEX) over Medium Frequency (MF). While the U.S. Coast Guard is first ensuring the information contained in NAVTEX broadcasts is available via IMO recognized satellite services, a segment of the maritime community will have an upfront cost of purchasing satellite equipment, and continuing operational user costs. 

NAVTEX is widely used in Alaska and around the globe as a safety tool for mariners. It is sensible to keep this system in place. If a change were to occur to satellite, a transition period that gives the maritime public time to purchase satellite receivers for onboard their vessels is critical. 

A valuable use of NAVTEX is in protecting endangered North Atlantic right whales. The Coast Guard issues NAVTEX messages alerting mariners to the location of North Atlantic right whales along the Atlantic seaboard. Consideration of how transition to satellite will affect specific communications from the Coast Guard in real time scenarios are important factors to consider. While satellite is an alternative reporting communications system, not all vessels are equipped with it. 

The Coast Guard states that NAVTEX is a low-cost automated means of receiving navigational and meteorological warnings and forecasts, as well as urgent maritime safety information. The Coast Guard believes the transition from terrestrial broadcast to satellite will allow for better, more cost-effective products in the future. Since this transition will be only in waters under U.S. responsibility, we think it prudent to have the costs come down first. A comparison of the cost of replacing MF NAVTEX with the cost of satellite, plus an identification of who bears the costs in each scenario should be available for the public to review. Vessels that do not have a Global Maritime Distress and Safety System satellite terminal onboard their vessels would be at a disadvantage without the use of a vital safety service such as NAVTEX. 

Thank you for your consideration, and the opportunity to comment.
 
James Gamble
Arctic Program Director

Title: Comment Submitted by Kathy Keleher
Comment: I would like this study to be expanded to include heavy waterway traffic times of the New River such as the Fort Lauderdale Boat Show,Winterfest and the seasonal business times of the marinas that this bridge will impact. Please extend your study to the end of December /January.

Title: Comment Submitted by Melody Renne, Seven Seas Yacht Sales, Inc.
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Evan McCarthy
Comment:
I am on the water most day. Every day, the FEC violates the regulations currently in place. The most frequent violation is the regulation requiring the bridge to be up in between trains. Daily, I am told by the tender that they can not raise the bridge as another train in close by. This is always not the case, the train will take another 25 to 40 minutes to reach the bridge. The FEC is trying to save lifts in my opinion. They could have certainly raised the bridge long enough for the waiting vessels to pass in the time available. I repeat, this happens daily.  They also lower the bridge too early. I often wait longer than 10 to 12 minutes with the bridge down with no train in sight. 

Another violation I see often is the 60 minutes in 120 minutes. When they keep the bridge closed between trains, again a daily event, they often exceed the 60 in 120 minutes. This is troublesome because the only repercussions from this will happen if a boater reports the violation. When I am stuck waiting for the bridge often, in between trains, the last thing I want to do is wait to see if the 120 minute rule is violated. I understand that unless a boater calls the violation in , it won't be held against the FEC. I believe this needs to change. Active monitoring and automatic violations needs to be in place so that the FEC will receive a violation every time they violate the regulations, NOT just when a boater calls in the violation. Also, the number and contact info on the bridge for the CG leads you to a confusing Menu and should be a more direct number to report violations.

As a boater, I believe the FEC's use of the New River bridge is far too detrimental to the Marine traffic and navigation of the New River.  In fact, when the Tri-Rail was built, further to the west, they were required to build the Flyover on 95 because the negative effects the trains would have on the Navigation of the New River. Now the FEC is allowed to block traffic throughout the day even further to the east. The FEC's use of the New River bridge is far too detrimental to the maritime traffic and New River navigation. I am disappointed to say the least that the Coast Guard has conceded it's power to the FEC. The benefit to the small number of train users does not warrant the current number of closings of the New RIver bridge. 

Thank you

Title: Comment Submitted by John Watson
Comment:
Mr. Barry Dragon
Director, Bridge Branch
U.S. Coast Guard Seventh District
909 SE First Ave.
Miami, FL 33131

RE: Federal Register Docket No. USCG-2019-0714: Proposed Drawbridge Operation Regulation; New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL


Dear Mr. Dragon,

I am pleased to submit these comments for the record pertaining to the above referenced Docket and the proposed fixed 120-minute time block.


I have ridden the Brightline train and regard it as a critically needed transportation alternative in South Florida.  A rule should provide flexibility and not create safety issues where trains are forced to halt movement due to a time restriction, blocking highway crossings and preventing first responders from accessing hospitals, fires, accident victims, and a host of emergency incidents

Please give consideration to the needs of surface transportation modes in finalizing your rule and write a flexible rule that offers a reasonable balance between both modes; predictability for boaters and flexibility for train traffic.

Sincerely,

John C. Watson

Title: Comment Submitted by John Snow
Comment: Commerce is much more important than pleasure boating. The bridge must be operated in such a manner as to not interfere with the movement of people and goods in a timely manner.

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: test

Title: Comment Submitted by George Paterson
Comment:
I am pleased to submit these comments for the record pertaining to the above
referenced Docket.

Freight trains have been transiting the New River for more than a century,
together with passenger rail running until 1968. Now with the return of
passenger trains on this corridor, operated by Virgin Trains USA, the marine
industry is seeking a new operating rule that could severely restrict the
ability of trains to maintain schedules important to their economic survival
and the regional economy.

As you consider an operating rule, I urge you to give appropriate
consideration to land-based commerce as prescribed in the Coast Guard Bridge
manual and consider the safety implications if trains are forced to halt
traffic waiting for an allowable bridge closure time.

Such stoppages will result in long periods of blocked highway crossings,
creating traffic jams and preventing first responders from accessing
hospitals, fires, accident victims, and a host of emergency incidents.

The FEC Railway corridor is part of the Florida's Strategic Intermodal
System, important to mobility and the State's economy. The rule should
facilitate the free flow of people and goods and flexibility for train
schedules while offering predictability for marine traffic.

Sincerely,

Title: Comment Submitted by Remy Gautier, Argentelle Catering & Special Events
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Mr. Barry Dragon

Director, Bridge Branch

U.S. Coast Guard Seventh District

909 SE First Ave.

Miami, FL 33131

 

RE: Federal Register Docket No. USCG-2019-0714: Proposed Drawbridge Operation Regulation; New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL

 

Dear Mr. Dragon,

 

I am pleased to submit these comments for the record pertaining to the above referenced Docket.

Freight trains have been transiting the New River for more than a century, together with passenger rail running until 1968.  Now with the return of passenger trains on this corridor, operated by Virgin Trains USA, the marine industry is seeking a new operating rule that could severely restrict the ability of trains to maintain schedules important to their economic survival and the regional economy.

As you consider an operating rule, I urge you to give appropriate consideration to land-based commerce as prescribed in the Coast Guard Bridge manual and consider the safety implications if trains are forced to halt traffic waiting for an allowable bridge closure time.

Such stoppages will result in long periods of blocked highway crossings, creating traffic jams and preventing first responders from accessing hospitals, fires, accident victims, and a host of emergency incidents. 

The FEC Railway corridor is part of the Floridas Strategic Intermodal System, important to mobility and the States economy. The rule should facilitate the free flow of people and goods and flexibility for train schedules while offering predictability for marine traffic.

Sincerely,

A citizen concerned with long-term passenger rail mobility in Florida.

Title: Comment Submitted by Aodan O'Fionnachta
Comment:
There is a time clock to advise boaters that the bridge will be going down in "X" minutes for a train(s).

Once the bridge is down, the clock does not tell you how long the bridge will be down for. This needs to change as you have boats doing circles in the river waiting for the bridge to go back up.

Sometimes, the wait times are so long, boats end up tying up at the dock. Other boats just idle causing pollution.

On a side note, as the southbound train pulls into the station, the train track arms go down at Broward Blvd. & SW 2nd St. and go back up again once the train stops in the station. Approx. 1-2 minutes later, the arms go back down again when the train leaves. The arms should not go down as the train pulls into the station.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lewis Horn
Comment: The bridge is critical to the movement of masses of people and goods via railway.  There is traffic gridlock in the entire area, and by using rail, traffic is greatly reduced.  The needs of the greater population should outweigh the occasional pleasure boat that needs to wait for a few minutes for the bridge.  Most people do not own big expensive boats, but they do buy products transported by the FEC rail and they do travel via Brightline.  I have never complained about the back up of cars that build up EVERYTIME a pleasure boat has to go through a draw bridge...I think this is something the USCG needs to address instead of the alleged rail problems.

Title: Comment Submitted by Patrick Leclerc, President, Trac Ecological
Comment:
New River is critical for our Marine Industry who employs over 160 thousand employees in Broward County alone. The closing of the bridge for up to 60 minutes for every 120 minutes will reduce the free flow of vessels on New River even more and could have a huge impact on our industry. 

Mega Yachts that have millions of dollars of work performed by contractors like myself at yards like LMC, Bradford Marine, Rosciolly and many more will now have to consider the marine traffic jam that this will cause when selecting a ship yard and could be of serious impact to our industry. I urge to consider our small business industry when considering these new rules.

Patrick Leclerc
President of Trac Ecological

Title: Comment Submitted by Janet Zimmerman
Comment:
I am writing to provide comments on the proposed test deviation for the regulation related to the Florida East Coast Railway (FEC) Railroad Drawbridge Operation on the New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL, published in the Federal Register Docket Number USCG-2019-0714.

The marine industry in Broward County is an $8.9 billion industry which supports over 111,000 workers in Broward County. Moving a 100+ foot vessel up the New River is not a recreational cruise but done for the purposes of commerce, vessel repair and vessel storage. Safe movement of these vessels are very tidally dependent. Tide, current and river congestion make the transport of these vessels up river challenging to begin with. To add to that equation the unknow of the length of down time or operation schedule for the New River railroad bridge creates a grave concern for safe navigation as vessels of levels of maneuverability and sizes from paddle boards to sailboats to motor boats to 100+ foot yachts under tow pile up at the bridge during a closure.

Palm Beach, Broward, and Dade County make up the 6th largest metropolitan area in the country. In order to reduce congestion, improve transportation options and support the free flow of commerce and goods on rail, roads and water we must insist on investments to improve on our citys infrastructure. The FEC bridge is only 4 over the water on the New River. Improving and raising the FEC New River rail bridge would allow marine traffic to flow and would also provide for a raised rail line through the urban core of Fort Lauderdale helping to alleviate traffic congestion on our roadways.

I request the USCG strongly consider and support the overarching principle of the laws and regulations governing bridges over navigable waters of the United States which is to keep them open to avoid unreasonable obstruction of the free navigation of the waterway.

Title: Comment Submitted by Bill Cosbie
Comment:
The waterway and vessels were here before the bridge. Otherwise they would not have built a bridge that opened. 

Trying to hold vessels for an hour in that small little river that acts as a wind tunnel through these large buildings is an insane and unsafe request, not only with pleasure boat operators but with commercial or large yacht vessel traffic which by the way is the largest single contributor to commerce in Fort Lauderdale.  The people that are making decisions clearly have no experience with this. They should try and hold of large vessel for that long a period of time in one spot. It will create a fatigue factor that will probably result in something bad happening.  
Further that bridge used to have a time clock that allows you five minutes of visual warning before the bridge dropped. That no longer exists and the bridge will start dropping with no visual or audio signal anymore, this has created an extremely dangerous environment that now results in people with small boats racing to beat it the bridge dropping for a train. 

Bill Cosbie
3000 ton USCG Master

Title: Comment Submitted by Brad Pickel, Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway Association
Comment:
Dear Director Dragon, 
The attached letter from the AIWA is in regard to your request for comments on the Drawbridge Operation Regulation; New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL. Thank you for including our comments in your discernment process.

Respectfully,
Brad Pickel, Executive Director
Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway Association

Title: Comment Submitted by Walter Zullig
Comment:
As a user of the Brightline high speed rail passenger service, I write to urge you to consider the needs of the passengers on the FEC Railroad, as well as the use of the bridge by FEC's freight trains.

Regarding the freight trains, the FEC generally operates on a scheduled basis. Thus there should be some time windows when a bridge opening would not disrupt their trains. The railroad transports important commodities to and from the Ft. Lauderdale and Miami areas and, as such, is an important contributor to the region's economy. Moreover, from the standpoint of public safety, it is most undesirable for a long freight train to have to wait while the bridge is being opened and closed as that would seriously delay vehicular traffic on the road crossings north and south of the bridge, including the heart of downtown Ft. Lauderdale.

FEC passenger trains had used the bridge until 1968 when the service stopped due to a railroad strike and never was resumed. Now throughout the nation citizens and governmental agencies are recognizing the horrible congestion of our highways, especially in areas such as southeast Florida. Rail passenger transportation is a big part of the solution to that congestion problem and the new privately-operated Brightline service on the FEC Railway is a big step in the right direction. On one of my recent trips the train was delayed 15 minutes because of having to wait for a boat. That type of delay is very undesirable and will discourage persons from using passenger rail service, the most environmentally friendly means of travel.

Accordingly, I urge you to work with the FEC and the maritime interests to develop reasonable windows during which the bridge will not have to be opened. In return, the mariners would be rather certain to have a clear shot getting through the bridge during other times.

I might add that I have been a passenger on vessels transiting thru the bridge and do understand their needs. But I emphasize that far more people are impacted when a passenger train is delayed or a freight train must stop in this area.

Title: Comment Submitted by Captain Zach Naughton
Comment:
I live up the river from the bridge and use the river for both work and pleasure.  I'm a professional captain and enjoy boating in my off time too.  It is extremely frustrating when there is a long closure of the bridge which totally impedes traffic flow.  I understand that trains must pass freely in order to maintain their schedule but it seems to me that holding the bridge down between two trains which are far apart is unnecessary.  I have experienced this very thing where traffic on the river backs up so that 2 or 3 trains can cross during one closure.  Miami destroyed their maritime industry by over taxation and legislation which didn't support the marine industry.  I moved to Ft. Lauderdale because I thought Broward and the New River were different.  As you know the marine industry in Ft. Lauderdale is worth billions of dollars per year to the local economy.  I believe mass transit options are important for the local population and I support the Brightline but I'm positive that the train does not provide billions of dollars in business for the South Florida economy.  Its a matter of priorities and compromise.  I believe the needs of the local maritime industry and unimpeded New River access should be more important than a train having to pause and wait 3 minutes for the railroad bridge to close on demand for their crossing of the river.    

Regards,

Capt. Zach Naughton

Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Robert Kornahrens, Advanced Roofing
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Rachel Kotkowski
Comment:
Fort Lauderdale draws thousands of residents and tourists alike each year due to the allure of the unique waterfront community and the attractions and activities that accompany it.  The "Venice of the Western Hemisphere" contributes millions to the economy of South Florida.  Business includes diving, chartering, yachting, fishing, tourism, et. al. in addition to housing the largest selection of boat and yacht sales in the western hemisphere, and all forms of maintenance which goes along with vessel ownership and operation.  This draws seasonal and permanent residents and sustains the booming real estate market in Fort Lauderdale.  

I understand the need for the movement of goods and persons via the railway, especially in a region with rapid population growth such as South Florida and I myself also become very frustrated with congested roadways, particularly at rush hour.  However, there needs to be a set of guidelines by which the maritime community can plan and operate.  The proposed regulation will certainly help.  Having the knowledge that the bridge will not cause a delay of more than 60 minutes certainly facilitates business planning. 

Perhaps other strategies could also aid in facilitating the needs of both communities.  From recent experience, the bridge remains down despite 20-minutes passing between trains in some instances.  Perhaps the threshold of opening the bridge between trains is impractically long.  Maybe after a well-designed risk analysis is conducted, a 10-minute threshold could be approved.   Additionally, accurately scheduled train times posted on a public interface would be very helpful.  The boating community may be able to begin adaptation if there is some sort of schedule to the delays i.e. if the bridge is always closed from 1700 to 1800, businesses can conform to this schedule and not waste time with unknown excessively long closures. 

We the residents of Fort Lauderdale are learning to adapt to the recent and rapid development and population growth in this former port-side vacation town.  I believe we can find a solution that assuages both the maritime and shoreside community if we consider creative ideas.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mark Crosley, Florida Inland Navigation District
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Kethleen Keleher, Winterfest, Inc.
Comment:
Mr. Barry Dragon Director, 
Bridge Branch, 
U.S. Coast Guard Seventh District 
909 SE First Ave. 
Miami, Florida 33131 

Dear Director Dragon: 

We are writing to provide comments on the proposed test deviation for the regulation related to the Florida East Coast Railway (FEC) Railroad Drawbridge Operation on the New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL, published in the Federal Register Docket Number USCG-2019-0714. The overarching principle of the laws and regulations governing bridges over navigable waters of the United States is to keep them open to avoid unreasonable obstruction of the free navigation of the waterway. Recognizing some vessels must rely on the tides to safely navigate the river. Ensuring that the bridge tender is doing his or her job, maintaining effective signage and lighting, and establishing the ability to communicate through multimedia outlets such as social media and/or reliable apps when problems arise also are all essential to avoid any undue obstruction to the use of the waterway. 

As a member of this community and employed by Wintefest, Inc., it is very important to keep an unobstructed and predictable use of the waterway. It is also important for the regulations to take into consideration changes in schedules to accommodate events which have a large economic impact on our area such as the 48th Annual Fort Lauderdale Boat Parade known as the Seminole Hard Rock Winterfest Boat Parade produced by the not-for-profit 501(c)4 Winterfest, Inc.

 As you can see, this community and events such as the Boat Parade rely heavily on unobstructed access to navigate the New River. This waterway is essential to the economic health of the Greater Fort Lauderdale area and for the safety of those who navigate on the river. We appreciate the opportunity to provide these comments and urge the Coast Guard to make every effort to make sure that there is no unreasonable obstruction of the free navigation of the New River in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida.

Title: Comment Submitted by Scott Rivelli
Comment:
Mr. Barry Dragon
Director, Bridge Branch
U.S. Coast Guard Seventh District
909 SE First Ave. 
Miami, FL 33131

RE: Federal Register Docket No. USCG-2019-0714: Proposed Drawbridge Operation Regulation; New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL

I am pleased to submit these comments for the record pertaining to the above referenced Docket and the proposed fixed 120-minute time block.

Just as the marine industry depends on reasonable access to the New River, the needs of land-based commerce require equitable access to ensure free flow of movement for goods and people.

In developing an operating rule, the Coast Guard must also maintain a reasonable balance between the competing needs of land and waterborne modes of transportation. commerce.  The proposed deviation lacks flexibility and unreasonably hinders land-based commerce.

An overly restrictive rule could create safety issues, forcing trains to halt movement, blocking highway crossings for long periods and preventing first responders from accessing hospitals, fires, accident victims, and other emergencies. 

Both Virgin Trains and FEC Railway are important to our regional economy.  The rule should accommodate the needs of all surface transportation modes, providing predictability for marine traffic by allowing for a designated fixed period in the open position, while providing for flexibility over several hours for regular train traffic.
Thank you for your consideration of my comments. 

Sincerely,
Scott Rivelli

Title: Comment Submitted by Martha [Last Name Unknonw]
Comment:
Mr. Barry Dragon
Director, Bridge Branch
U.S. Coast Guard Seventh District
909 SE First Ave.
Miami, FL 33131

RE: Federal Register Docket No. USCG-2019-0714: Proposed Drawbridge Operation Regulation; New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL

Dear Mr. Dragon,

Having been a Virgin Train supporter from the pre-construction days, it has come to my attention that the above stated Coast Guard Proposal Docket No. USCG-2019-0714 could potentially compromise both land commerce and the safety of South Floridians.   Logically thinking, the Coast Guards proposed fixed 120-minute time block for bridges in the up position along the New River could compromise the free flow of goods and people. But even more concerning is due to the lack of flexibility of the proposed 120- minute time block, trains could be forced to block highway crossing for long periods of time potentially preventing first responders, fire, and police from reaching victims and transporting them to safety.  Unnecessary to mention would be the public's frustration. 

Historically, the free flow of land commerce provided by FEC Railway has been an important part of our regional economy.  The growing influence of Virgin Trains providing a much needed mass transit system for South Floridas work force and tourism has already made a positive impact on the economy, will continue to do so, and will eventually have a positive impact on the entire state.  This has been accomplished in part by various stakeholders taking into consideration and accommodating economic, public, private, environmental, and political agendas.  USCG-2019-0714 could compromise this.

I am not an expert, but do believe in the positive impact Virgin Trains will continue to make on our region and state and would not want it compromised unnecessarily. I also highly respect and value the positive economic impact marine traffic has in bringing countless people from all over the world to this highly desirable boater mecca. It seems reasonable to respectfully ask the Coast Guard to reconsider the current proposal to perhaps a more balanced proposal in which the needs of both land and marine transportation are accommodated, thus protecting the economy and safety of our region.  For example; a predictable designated fixed period for bridges to be open accommodating marine transportation while allowing flexibility when needed over several hours to accommodate the somewhat less predictable regular train traffic.

This is simply a request to reconsider and possibly find a solution to accommodate everyones needs to foster the continued successful development and growth of of our beautiful region.

I appreciate your time in reading my comments.

Most Respectfully,
Martha
