Title: Comment Submitted by Jim Naugle
Comment:
I own and operate Lauderdale Boat Yard on the South fork of the New River on Marina Mile. All of my customers need to get through the FEC bridge in order to get to the Boat Yard. I get many customers from the Bahamas and the Florida Keys. About 60 families earn their living working on Boats at Lauderdale Boat Yard. The proposed schedule will make it difficult for customers to get to the yard. Waiting an hour for a train bridge to open is difficult in a narrow river with a lot of traffic and strong tidal flow. The Railroad needs to route more of the freight trains to the CSX tracks now that frequent passenger trains are using the Mexican owned FEC. Groupo Mexico has effectively built a wall through our downtown, preventing commerce on the river and the cross streets of Fort Lauderdale. International Maritime commerce has taken place on the New River since the 1790s, 100 years before Henry Flagler built the railroad through Fort Lauderdale. Please dont let the new owners from Mexico restrict this commerce.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jim Steel
Comment:
Miami, Florida. 33131

I am writing to provide comments on the proposed test deviation for the regulation related to the Florida East Coast Railway (FEC) Railroad Drawbridge Operation on the New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL published in the Federal Register Docket Number USCG-2019-0714.
The overreaching principle of the laws and regulations governing bridges over navigable waters of the United States is to keep them open so as to avoid unreasonable obstruction of the free navigation of the waterway.  Recognizing some vessels must rely on the tides for safely navigating the river.  Ensuring the bridge tender is doing his or her job, maintaining effective signage and lighting, and establishing the ability to communicate through multimedia outlets such as social media and/or reliable apps when problems arise also are all essential to avoiding any undue obstruction to the use of the waterway.
I own and operate Steel Marine Towing, a yacht towing company that tows large yachts up and down the New River for the past 14 years.  This has already had a major impact to my business.  We have experience numerous delays for up to an hour at times.  It becomes a matter of safety due to the size and draft of some of our customers.  This time schedule is a recipe for disaster. 
As you can see, a business like ours is heavily dependent on unobstructed access to navigate the New River.  This waterway is essential to the economic health of our industry and for the safety of those who navigate on the river.  We appreciate the opportunity to provide these comments and urge the Coast Guard to make every effort to make sure that there is no unreasonable obstruction of the free navigation of the New River in Fort Lauderdale, FL.

Jim Steel

Title: Comment Submitted by John P. Kelly, Bradford Marine
Comment:
September 19, 2019

Via Federal eRulemaking Portal at http://www.regulations.gov
Mr. Barry Dragon
Director, Bridge Branch,
U.S. Coast Guard Seventh District 909 SE First Ave.
Miami, Florida 33131
RE: Federal Register Docket No. USCG-2019-0714: Proposed Drawbridge Operation Regulation; New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL
Dear Director Dragon:
We are writing to provide comments on the proposed test deviation for the regulation related to the Florida East Coast Railway (FEC) Railroad Drawbridge Operation on the New River, Fort Lauderdale, FL, published in the Federal Register Docket Number USCG-2019-0714.
The overarching principle of the laws and regulations governing bridges over navigable waters of the United States is to keep them open so as to avoid unreasonable obstruction of the free navigation of the waterway. Recognizing some vessels must rely on the tides to safely navigate the river. Ensuring that the bridge tender is doing his or her job, maintaining effective signage and lighting, and establishing the ability to communicate through multimedia outlets such as social media and/or reliable apps when problems arise also are all essential to avoiding any undue obstruction to the use of the waterway.
As the new owners of Bradford Marine (3051 W. State Road 84, Fort Lauderdale, on the New River), which we acquired in January 2019, we are excited to continue contributing to the vibrant marine industry in Broward County, which is important both to mariners and the local economy.  Over the decades, Broward County and its cities and towns, have built the critical infrastructure necessary to support the continued growth in the number of large recreational vessels being sold.  Bradford Marine is part of that critical infrastructure, with a full-service repair and maintenance facility focused on vessels 70-160 feet in length, providing a full range of services, including (but not limited to) a 250 ton Synchrolift to lift boats out of the water for associated bottom work; propellers and shaft repair; metal repair (with a full welding capability); fiberglass repair; engine and hydraulic repair; carpentry and painting (including the re-painting of vessels up to 160 feet in length). In addition, Bradford Marine has 11,000 linear feet of covered dockage (long term and transient), for vessels in that same size range, and as a Hurricane Hole served many vessels that sought shelter at our facility during the recent passage of Hurricane Dorian. Since it started business in 1966, Bradford Marine has ensured that owners of large vessels have been able to receive the maintenance and repair services necessary to keep their vessels operational.
Bradford Marines viability as a provider of marine services is completely dependent on unobstructed and free navigation of the South Fork of the New River. Given the FEC RR Bridge sits approximately 4 feet above the waterway when closed, it does not allow passage of vessels when it is closed. In this area, the New River is subject to tidal currents, and vessels subject to long and unpredictable periods before the RR bridge opens, is a major deterrent in a vessels decision to bring their vessel to or yard or one of
 
Mr. Barry Dragon
Director, Bridge Branch, U.S. Coast Guard Seventh District
Page 2
the yards west of the FEC RR bridge for marine repair.   Bradford Marine certainly understands the need for the RR bridge to close at certain times for the transit of freight (and passengers), and vessels can certainly plan around a predictable schedule (which is not inconsistent with the railroads stated objective of maintaining a schedule).  It is the railroads lack of adherence to a schedule, and therefore the unpredictable nature of when a vessel can transit up or down the South Fork of the New River, that creates the major problem for Bradford Marine and our colleagues providing similar services on the New River.
As you can see, a business like ours is heavily dependent on unobstructed access to navigate the New River. This waterway is essential to the economic health of our industry and for the safety of those who navigate on the river. We appreciate the opportunity to provide these comments and urge the Coast Guard to make every effort to make sure that there is no unreasonable obstruction of the free navigation of the New River in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida.
I am very happy to discuss Bradford Marines concerns in person if that would be helpful.
Sincerely,
 
John P Kelly
John Kelly
Chief Executive Officer  Bradford Marine

Title: Comment Submitted by Garrett Norton, Farrell and Norton Naval Architects
Comment:
Department of Homeland Security USCG-2019-0751

To whom it may concern,

The 2010 Coast Guard Re-Authorization Act  mandated the USCG to come up with an Alternate Safety Compliance Plan for the existing fishing fleet. All boats over 50 feet in length, built before July 1, 2012 that are 25 year or older, the majority of existing fishing vessels, were to be required to be in compliance with these new regulations by January 1st 2020, which is now just a couple of months away. The new regulations were required to be mandatory not voluntary and they were required to be in place by 2017, giving the existing vessels 3 years to come into compliance. (see attachment 1)

As they have done on the West Coast, it is my understanding that the new regulations were intended to bring the existing vessels into an alternate inspection  program similar to the load line regulations. (see attachment 2)

I attended a meeting in Gloucester, in the fall of 2016, regarding the Alternate Safety Compliance Program were Jack Kemerer spoke. I voiced my support for the need for regulatory oversight of the existing fishing fleet, specifically with the maintenance, watertight integrity and stability. I also voice my concerns regarding the cost of the program to the smaller fishing operations, and suggested that a fund be set up to help with bringing the vessels into compliance. Shortly after this meeting I received a  notice stating that the Coast Guard had suspended development Alternate Safety Compliance program. (see attachment 3)

In January of 2017 the Coast Guard issued the Voluntary Safety Initiatives and Good Marine Practices, making the Alternate Safety Compliance Program voluntary instead of mandatory as required by CGAA Section 604(e)(1). We at Farrell and Norton Naval Architects are complying with this document, putting a five year expiration date on all of our stability booklets. Further, we believe based on our many years of experience that all fishing vessels should have their stability check every five years. (see attachment 4)

New fishing vessel construction is covered in US Code 4503-2019.  US Code 4503-2019 also clearly outlines the required maintenance schedule, and requires a stability review every five years, it seems to me that between US Code 4503-2019 and the Voluntary Safety Initiatives it would be easy for the Coast Guard to put together a  mandatory Alternate Safety Compliance Program, as required by CGAA 604(e)(1). (see attachment 5)

Thank you,



Garrett Norton
Farrell and Norton Naval Architects

Title: Comment Submitted by Sladijna Maksimovic, Office of Coast Survey (OCS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
Comment: SEE ATTACHMENT

Title: Comment Submitted by Beni Bacon
Comment:
The additional changes to the code listed recreational boats having a life jacket on, for every person in expose locations during bar crossing events. Commercial vessels had the option for an immersion suit, instead of a life jacket. As many serious Cruisers also have immersion suits aboard, would it be possible to include Impressions suits as an option for recreational boaters as well.

In addition in rough weather most serious Cruisers will have Jack lines, harnesses and safety tethers to keep them aboard. I consider that Superior to a life jacket in keeping oneself and crew aboard at all times, in rough weather. Perhaps it would be good to include a paragraph about Jack lines and tethers as well. Of course it adds complexity with requirements of suitable hardpoints and proper rigging of the jacklines and tethers. In a rough weather Crossing of a bar I would definitely be wearing a tether and harness to keep me firmly attached to the vessel.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I do not believe the accident data supports the need to make these entrances Regulated Navigation Area's. There is currently no issues with recreational or commercial vessels experiencing accidents while transiting these areas due to unsafe weather conditions. I am not convinced that leaving the decision to close or restrict these areas to the local Coast Guard unit, Sector or Small Boat Station's, is in the publics best interest. Closing or restricting an entrance bar based on a vessels length, simply does not make sense. For example, saying that a 26' vessel is more seaworthy than a 16' vessel based solely on length is inaccurate. This does not take all factors into consideration such as the competency of the vessel operator, or vessel construction features such as self bailing decks, subdivision, reserve buoyancy, and level flotation. Using a one size fits all approach doesn't work for this situation.
Leave what is in place now alone. Having the Captain of the Port close the entrances when there is 20' plus surf is appropriate. However, leaving the decision up to the local Coast Guard units to start restricting the bar every time the tide ebbs and they think it is dangerous for a smaller vessel to cross, is not the right approach and is not supported by statistics.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeremiah O' Brien, Morro Bay Commercial Fishermens Org
Comment:
My Name is Jeremiah O'Brien and currently V. Pres. of The Morro Bay Commercial Fishermens Org. as well as of the Morro Bay Harbor Advisory Board. My comment on the proposed regulation is that given our southern location we seldom are impacted by the 
conditions that exist in the areas of Oregon that currently are using this system. We hear do not have the tragic losses in the numbers that are happening to those in the north. The second issue is with the Impact Statement that indicates no impact on small business in the area. We have over 100 members in our Org. that are all small businesses
and each and every one will be adversely affected. Morro Bay is a small town and the impact on this many businesses and unemployment will be much more of an impact on a larger area. We are very disappointed that you did not contact anyone here before coming up with your decision that there were no impacts. Please recognize the commercial  
fishermen and the many things that do impact us. Have the courtesy to at least ask us 
rather than mislead those that are not aware of our hardships. This has the potential
to cause more than 200 people to be unemployed every day it is enforced.
Thank You 
Jeremiah O'Brien
V. President Morro Bay Commercial Fishermens' Org.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
The proposed RNAs for Northern CA is unwarranted and would put undue burden to small businesses in these ports where small commercial fishing operations and UPV recreational fishing operations are a significant proportion of vessels transiting these areas and making a living in small coastal towns. I am one of them and I am shocked that this is being presented as "necessary" because I feel that this will do nothing for me and my clients safety except significantly reduce my income, waste my clients time and money, and make my decisions to prepare for a trip even more difficult to plan for. As a licensed captain working out of Humboldt Bay that takes people fishing almost daily from may thru sept and many days weekly into nov also, I already have the burden of bringing people into town for their fishing trip based on very vague marine forecasts coming out of the Eureka NWS office and often err on the side of caution and cancel their trip before they put the miles on their car and have to pay for hotel rooms. I cannot have people come to town from hours or states away, get hotels, buy fishing licenses, then not go because of a bar condition that I have traversed safely countless times is now restricted due to the calculation of a couple peak waves that don't meet the requirements of a new law for a certain size vessel. Safety is my number one goal everyday I go out on the ocean with people or alone, if I'm not comfortable with current conditions or forecast it's no go. All of us that transit the Humboldt Bay bar talk before and after trips, during our transit, and watch out for one another; noting which areas are better then others or if we turned around and if there is even a safety issue at all. Safety is always our number one concern and we take it as top priority and treat it as a community issue. We all take swell height, tide state, swell period, swell direction, prevailing current, wind direction and intensity, characteristics of our vessels, and latest bottom soundings into consideration as we prepare for all bar crossings. A calculation basing transit of a RNA ultimately on boat size alone without master or captain competency is complete over regulation for a situation.

This proposed law is portrayed as a regulation to close the bars at 20ft, which is already law and I feel that is reasonable due to motor life boat limitations and is the only detail mentioned in this proposal that seems appropriate. I also commercial fish throughout the year from Crescent City and Ft Bragg on my other small commercial boats between charter work and feel that if there are unsafe conditions the captains are already making the decision to not go in those ports also. I cannot recall any casualties in recent years that would've resulted in no loss with this regulation in place. The only incident I recall was a few years back a vessel broke down that was fishing the ocean side of the south jetty and got washed onto the rocks, bar restrictions would not have prevented that incident. I don't understand why Crescent City is listed, it is known to have a nice port entry even in rough weather, there are currently no motor life boat assets stationed there except the small cutter Dorado and an outboard powered RIB, I thought RNAs were implemented by crews on MLBs on the water? 

I absolutely support and appreciated the USCG and what they do for our security and community safety but feel this regulation would be very burdensome for the small businesses working out of all the proposed ports with little to nothing gained in terms of safety. People know their limitations and don't need the decisions to be made for them before they have the choice to do so themselves. This appears to be an attempt to secure more funding for USCG small boat operations on the backs of the small businesses in small coastal ports that are trying to scrap out a living, and to present it as no impact to small business is just wrong. More public outreach and education by the USCG with the less experienced mariners should be the first approach to bar crossing safety not a blanket rule that will change the way many have made a living and safely navigated these areas for years. Penalties of $25,000 is a deterrent for transit of a RNA but if staying on the ocean in awful conditions until after dark while there is a bar restriction until a tide change occurs or wave heights drop is less safe and seems counterproductive rather then letting a vessel transit in conditions it has before if the master feels like its safe to do so. 

I respectfully request that you let the captains of their vessels make the determination if conditions are unsafe and not implement this new RNA for Northern CA. If this regulation is going to be implemented, I feel that USCG licensed captains and UPVs should have an exemption for RNA transit because they have already been judged being competent to be licensed by the USCG and will be making the best decisions for their situation.

Title: Drawbridge Operation Regulation; Chelsea River, Chelsea, MA
Topics: Bridges

Title: Comment Submitted by Edward Orde
Comment: The proposed regulations for the Chelsea Street Bridge should be approved and implemented as soon as possible. The shorter lift times offer much-needed benefits to the communities of East Boston and Chelsea, particularly for transit-dependent groups in the area who face consistently unreliable buses due to bridge operations in the area. The MBTA Route 112 and SL3 run frequently throughout the day and at peak hours there is a bus crossing the bridge about every 6 minutes. The current lift cycle causes significant delay to hundreds of transit-dependent and low-income riders and disrupts bus schedules for a significant time following the lift. This proposal to allow a shorter lift cycle offers the opportunity to provide significant benefits to these riders with absolutely no negative impacts to marine navigation. The proposal also offers benefits to general traffic and emissions in both East Boston and Chelsea, an environmental and transit justice community.

Title: Comment Submitted by Maxwell Cohen
Comment: I strongly support this proposed rule. It will significantly shorten the wait for traffic, including the bus rapid transit Silver Line, to cross the bridge, without impeding navigation.

Title: Comment Submitted by Amy Lester
Comment: I support the proposed change to the Chelsea St Bridge for a reduced height.

Title: Comment Submitted by Patrick Baxter
Comment: I support this proposed change.  As the proposal is written it will substantially reduce travel time impacts to the Bus Rapid Transit route (SL3) that travels over the bridge as well as for all other users of the street.

Title: Comment Submitted by Gary Rioux
Comment: This is absolutely a fantastic idea. The traffic needs to keep moving in the area as much as possible. The longer the bridge is up the more chaos is caused by the resulting traffic.

Title: Comment Submitted by Nathaniel Gotfredson
Comment: I support the proposed rule allowing the bridge opening height to be reduced to 139' unless otherwise requested. Allowing better reliability of the Silver Line connection to Chelsea is important to me when traveling to the airport. This proposed rule would enable better Silver Line reliability.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: In regards to the three proposed anchorage locations by the U.S. Coast Guard in the Delaware Bay and the ocean, I strongly oppose the Delaware Bay location. First of all, the proposed Delaware Bay anchorage  is too close to land and the Cape May Ferry route. It is also close to the mouth of the Bay which sees a lot of ship traffic, further congesting the area. Secondly the close proximity to the Lewes end of the Cape Henlopen State Park, and public beaches, poses a potential threat to protected wildlife and the public's usage of the beaches at Cape Henlopen and the Delaware Bay. With the potential for fueling operations to take place, and the possibility of spills, there should be no anchorage allowed in this heavily populated resort area of the Delaware Bay.

Title: Comment Submitted by Captain Stephen A. Roberts, Pilot Pilots' Association for the Bay and River Delaware
Organization Name: Pilot Pilots' Association for the Bay and River Delaware
Comment:
Docket ID: USCG-2019-0822

January 10, 2020

Comments on proposed anchorages in Delaware Bay and Atlantic Ocean


To Whom it May Concern:

I am a Delaware state licensed ship pilot working on the waters of the Delaware Coast, Delaware Bay and Delaware River.  I am also a past chairman of the Mariners Advisory Committee (MAC), the Harbor Safety Committee for the ports of the Delaware River Valley.

During my tenure as MAC chairman from 2009 through 2013 and continuing today, the Mariners Advisory Committee and the port community has supported the safe development of offshore wind energy off the Delaware Coast.  Knowing that port would lose access to important anchorage grounds between the sea-lanes, as evidenced by my supporting document on this current docket, dated August 2, 2011 and Captain Broadley's letter of July 18, 2011, the MAC proposed establishing the two offshore anchorage areas advertised in this USCG Docket.  Please note that this proposal was part of the public record for the Coast Guard's groundbreaking Atlantic Coast Port Access Route Study of 2011 (Docket Number USCG-2011-00351).  Therefor, it should come as no surprise to BOEM or wind energy developers that the port has great need of these proposed anchorages and where they should be located.  These anchorages should be established free of any transmission cables leading from the Wind Energy Areas (WEAs) to shore based facilities as well as any other related structures.  

Regarding the proposed anchorage in Delaware Bay, ships have been using that geographical area to anchor since the establishment of shipping on the Delaware and remain crucial to the operation of the Port.  It does not impede ferry traffic between New Jersey and Delaware and, by Delaware statute, may not be used to transfer bulk or liquid cargo.  The establishment of the formal, delineated anchorage where the traditional anchorage is will enhance the safety of navigation in the area as it serves to inform mariners of the dedicated use of the area and separates underway traffic from anchored vessels.

In summary, I urge the United States Coast Guard to establish the three proposed anchorages that are so crucial to safe navigation and the viability of the Delaware River port system

Respectfully submitted,

Captain Stephen A. Roberts, Pilot
Pilots' Association for the Bay and River Delaware

Title: Comment Submitted by Rebecca Weaver
Comment:
I am VERY concerned to learn that The US Coast Guard is proposing to move the anchorage areas for large ships much closer to shore, including just 2.5 miles north of the Point at Cape Henlopen State Park.    This is in very close proximity to the mouth of the Delaware Bay.  I have grave concerns about the environmental impacts of large ships so close to feeding and habitat areas for marine mammals and sea turtles.  Many of us moved to this area for the beautiful wetlands, back bays and abundance of marine life.    PLEASE RECONSIDER this move.   Once this beauty is destroyed, we will never get it back.  I for one want to be able to show my grandchildren the beauty of this natural habitat.  Don't rob my grandkids of this opportunity.  We already have a frequent number of animals washed up on the beach due to boats and other manmade problems.  Let's not increase that number.   Beaches should be for tourists (WHICH IS OUR PRIMARY INDUSTRY) not for dead sea life.

PLEASE RECONSIDER

Rebecca Weaver
Resident of Sussex Co, Delaware

Title: Comment Submitted by Renee Edge
Comment:
USCG please consider our environment, the animals, our residents, and our economy with this proposal.  People are moving here daily because of our beautiful beaches and having these ships closer to our shore will impact that.  This all trickles down to the influx of money coming into our economy that sustains the life of Delaware residents.  It will also impact the habitats of many species in a negative way.  Our marine wildlife and sea turtles will be impacted, not to mention the possible threat of invasive species coming to Delaware as these international ships come closer.  

I am from Delaware and love my state, this is concerning for myself, the animals, future growth and the residents that live here.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jo Hamilton
Comment:
Keith M. Smith,
Rear Admiral, U.S. Coast Guard, Commander, Fifth Coast Guard District.
								

Dear Admiral Smith,

I am writing to express our concerns for the proposed changes to anchorage grounds in the Delaware Bay and Atlantic Ocean off of the Delaware coast. 

The Marine Education, Research & Rehabilitation Institute, Inc. (MERR) is Delaware's marine mammal and sea turtle stranding response organization. Permitted under NOAA and USFWS, MERR collects data on both the presence of species along the Delaware coast, and on stranding events and causes.  The coastal waters off of Delaware, including the Delaware Bay and inland bays provide habitat for 32 species of marine mammals and sea turtles, some of which are endangered species, and all of which are protected under the Marine Mammal Protection Act and/or the Endangered Species Act.  We see no mention of impacts to protected species in the RFP.

The proposal to move the anchorage areas closer to shore poses grave threats to the many species that forage in these same areas.  Of particular concern is anchorage B, located just 2.5 miles north of Cape Henlopen and the mouth of the Delaware Bay.  This area provides essential habitat for many different species, and is utilized by sea turtles, dolphins and large whales as an established area to forage for food and to raise their young.  Humpback whales feed with dolphins in near shore waters where prey is plentiful.  The area surrounding the mouth of the Delaware Bay hosts an abundance of bottlenose dolphins during the summer months, and seals during the winter months.  The bottlenose dolphins in this area are the largest northern population of this species, and reside in the area for 9 months out of the year.  The area surrounding the Point is established as having significant numbers of this species, and sighting data supports that individual animals return to this same area year after year.  Seals have established a communal haul out area around the inner break wall, and require an extended expanse of feeding area surrounding that location.  Increases in shipping traffic in this same area would pose an elevated risk of ship strike for these marine species.  Vessel induced impacts remain a significant source of fatality for large whales, and our data supports that ship strike is the cause of death for over 50% of sea turtle mortalities in Delaware waters.  The additional underwater noise generated by the ship's engines will also interfere with mother and calf communication.  Mother/calf pairs of large whales, including humpback whales and the severely endangered North Atlantic right whale frequent the near shore waters to feed, and mothers will utilize this area to teach their young how to forage on their own.   North Atlantic right whales are known to exhibit matrilineal fidelity to feeding areas, taking their offspring to the same area they were taught to feed by their own mothers.  The Delaware Bay is one of these locations.  

In addition, large whale species utilize areas off of the Delaware Coast as part of their ancient migratory pathway as they make their way from their northern feeding grounds to their southern birthing grounds.  We consider the proposed relocation of the anchorage areas to be a threat to the established patterns of these endangered species, and would therefore constitute harassment and displacement under the MMPA.  

We also have concerns about the introduction of invasive species from international ships anchoring in such close proximity to the mouth of the Delaware Bay.  Many of these ships arrive from international waters, bringing with them potentially invasive species that would be introduced into this sensitive ecosystem during bilge emptying operations.  Of equal concern is the increased risk for oil leaks and spills into this currently healthy and abundant ecosystem.

We request that the USCG give serious consideration to the environmental impacts that would occur were the anchorage areas relocated to the new locations that have been proposed.   We support the status quo option as being the most sound and least impactful option for the marine environment, particularly in consideration of the fact that the offshore wind farm proposals are very controversial due to their adverse impact on the marine environment and wildlife, and may not be developed as planned.

We are happy to provide additional information, including supportive data, so please do not hesitate to contact us. I hope you can understand our grave concerns for this decision. It seems is to have little to do with the best interests of the enviroment and the marine life that visit and exists in these waters as well as the fragile eco system that is already severely stressed.  




Thank you,
Jo Hamilton

MERR Volunteer
Rehoboth Beach,De
19971

Title: Comment Submitted by Claire Simmers
Comment:
I am a citizen of Sussex county, who lives near the shore and who boats and fishes around the areas where the proposed rule change is.  I do NOT support the change to establish new anchorage grounds in the Delaware Bay and Atlantic Ocean. I hope the voice of a citizen who participates in the area's recreation as well as one who speaks for the voiceless marine animals and fish counts equally to the voices of large commercial enterprises who are requesting additional anchorage grounds closer to shore to accommodate current and future vessel traffic, improve navigation safety, and because traditional anchorage areas may not be available due to planned or potential offshore wind energy development.

 I am an ordinary citizen who is very concerned that the changed anchorage will be in very close proximity to the mouth of the Delaware Bay, negatively impacting boating safety in the area. I have serous concerns about the environmental impacts of large ships so close to feeding and habitat areas for marine mammals and sea turtles and the aesthetic changes this proposal will pose.  

Please maintain the status quo and do not move anchorage in closer.  

Thank you.

Seals have established a communal haul out area around the inner break wall, and require an extended expanse of feeding area surrounding that location.  Increases in shipping traffic in this same area would pose an elevated risk of ship strike for these marine species.  Vessel induced impacts remain a significant source of fatality for large whales, and our data supports that ship strike is the cause of death for over 50% of sea turtle mortalities in Delaware waters.  The additional underwater noise generated by the ship's engines will also interfere with mother and calf communication.  Mother/calf pairs of large whales, including humpback whales and the severely endangered North Atlantic right whale frequent the near shore waters to feed, and mothers will utilize this area to teach their young how to forage on their own.   North Atlantic right whales are known to exhibit matrilineal fidelity to feeding areas, taking their offspring to the same area they were taught to feed by their own mothers.  The Delaware Bay is one of these locations.  
 
In addition, large whale species utilize areas off of the Delaware Coast as part of their ancient migratory pathway as they make their way from their northern feeding grounds to their southern birthing grounds.  We consider the proposed relocation of the anchorage areas to be a threat to the established patterns of these endangered species, and would therefore constitute harassment and displacement under the MMPA.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joelle Morris
Comment:
January, 28, 2020

RE: USCG-2019 -0822 

Dear Admiral Smith,

I am deeply concerned about the changes to anchorage in the Delaware Bay and surrounding area. If implemented, these actions would have devastating environmental consequences in a location that supports great biodiversity.

Some of several impacts would include disruption of marine mammal migration, increased risk of polluting and disrupting  productive habitat and potential introduction of invasive species. Of special concern is proposed anchorage B -- an especially sensitive area.

I hope that you might reconsider this proposal or, at least, consider comprehensive environmental impact studies. 

Sincerely,

Joelle Morris

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: The proposal to move the anchorage areas closer to shore poses grave threats to the many species that forage in these same areas.  Of particular concern is anchorage B, located just 2.5 miles north of Cape Henlopen and the mouth of the Delaware Bay.  This area provides essential habitat for many different species, and is utilized by sea turtles, dolphins and large whales as an established area to forage for food and to raise their young.  Humpback whales feed with dolphins in near shore waters where prey is plentiful.  The area surrounding the mouth of the Delaware Bay hosts an abundance of bottlenose dolphins during the summer months, and seals during the winter months.  The bottlenose dolphins in this area are the largest northern population of this species, and reside in the area for 9 months out of the year.  The area surrounding the Point is established as having significant numbers of this species, and sighting data supports that individual animals return to this same area year after year.  Seals have established a communal haul out area around the inner break wall, and require an extended expanse of feeding area surrounding that location.  Increases in shipping traffic in this same area would pose an elevated risk of ship strike for these marine species.  Vessel induced impacts remain a significant source of fatality for large whales, and our data supports that ship strike is the cause of death for over 50% of sea turtle mortalities in Delaware waters.  The additional underwater noise generated by the ship's engines will also interfere with mother and calf communication.  Mother/calf pairs of large whales, including humpback whales and the severely endangered North Atlantic right whale frequent the near shore waters to feed, and mothers will utilize this area to teach their young how to forage on their own.   North Atlantic right whales are known to exhibit matrilineal fidelity to feeding areas, taking their offspring to the same area they were taught to feed by their own mothers.  The Delaware Bay is one of these locations.

Title: Comment Submitted by the McKinley Boat Owners Association, Inc
Comment:
Please see the attached file which outlines our concerns regarding additional restrictions on bridge opening across the Milwaukee River System.

Our contact information is contained within the file.  Please don't hesitate to contact us if you have any questions.

Title: Comment Submitted by Mike & Sue Johnson
Comment:
Greetings USCG-
We are very active boaters in the Milwaukee Area. We too have been following the unprofessionalism of Alderman Bob Bauman and his personal quest to limit bridge operations in Milwaukee. His disapproval of the boating community is no reason to proceed on a blind call to make changes. We feel the limits suggested by Mr. Bauman are not practical for the area boaters and hinder our well earned enjoyment of the city. We would be for a compromise on the bridge openings. Mr. Bob Bauman has taken the approach that this is his way or the highway.

Lets work together as you did in Miami to appease both parties easing traffic flows and still permitting vessels to pass.. That is what my government should be doing. We are also members of McBoat. The McKinley Marina Boat Owners Association. They represent over 600 boats in the Milwaukee basin.
Please consider a compromise. Thank you for your efforts and to here our concerns. If you wish to contact us for further comment. we welcome your call.

Mike & Sue Johnson
E-Dock Slip #2
18450 Heathway Lane
Brookfield, WI 53045      
262-894-2998

Title: Comment Submitted by Mike & Lynn Bauman
Comment:
Hello to the USCG and thank you for your service. My wife Lynn & I have been boaters on Lake Michigan for nearly 50 years. We are members of the Milwaukee Harbor Yacht Club (past Commodore) as well as South Shore Yacht Club. We keep our 36' power cruiser moored at the McKinley Marina in Milwaukee and are members and Board Member (Lynn) of the McKinley Boat Owners Association, McBoat. I am also a USCG Licensed 50 ton Captain. (currently not working) I realize that my comments alone don't hold much weight, but I would like to make my thoughts known.

I am Not related to Alderman Bauman. The Alderman, with his actions, is looking to essentially shut down recreational boating on the Milwaukee River. 

There are several issues I would like to comment on. (See the Authority Section of the proposed rule)
> I don't see an issue with adding 30 minutes to the afternoon drive time. Traffic has gotten busier. The midnight to 7 am, 2 hour restriction seems a bit early. I would think a 1 am to 7 am would be more palatable especially on the weekends where recreational boaters may tend to stay out later. I believe this should be consistent with all Milwaukee rivers as noted in other sections of the proposed rules.

> As indicated in the proposed rules, I believe there are a number of commercial vessels under 50 ton that regularly use the river. I would like to see this rule eliminated and allow all commercial vessels full use of the river. To allow some commercial vessels and restrict others is a restraint of trade.

> As indicated in the proposed rules regarding "winter hours". There are still many boats in the water well beyond November 2nd, both in the marinas and along the river. Nov 2nd seems a bit too restrictive. November 15th may be a better date. Many boats need to get out of the river to be pulled out for storage, or up the Kinnickinnic River to one of the marinas.

Regarding the 2 Hour advance notice:

> With having to adhere to a 2 hour notice for bridge openings, this is going to pretty much shut down recreational boats from transiting north on the Milwaukee River to enjoy the restaurants and cultural activities along the river way. The issue with a 2-hour notice for transiting, has to do with dockage availability. If I put in my 2-hour request for Bridge openings and get to where I want to be, if there is nowhere to dock, now I'm stuck, having to wait numerous hours to make my bridge opening time heading back. In the meantime, I'm floating in the middle of the river, likely impeding other traffic and if it's a windy day, more complications arise. You can see that with these limitations most would not take the chance of going north of the St. Paul Bridge. (mile 1.21) The limitations he wants to put will definitely reduce business to those restaurants and entertainment sites above mile 1.21.  This essentially cuts off the north section of the Milwaukee River from being used by recreational boats needing an opening. 

The unfortunate thing is that it appears that Alderman Bauman did not reach out to the boating community to seek advise &/or compromise. The noise complaints are few and far between. Numerous people at a public hearing noted that the river traffic was an intriguing part of living along the river. In fact, I believe there may have been only one complainant. (As I do not live in the City of Milwaukee, I was not in attendance and watched a video replay of the meeting) My feeling is that this has more to do with City finances than noise complaints. I also believe the Alderman has a negative view of recreational boaters as he made a comment that they are just the rich people from the suburbs cruising up the river with their cocktails.

I certainly hope that some compromise can be negotiated with the proposed rules. Thank you for taking the time to read my thoughts.

Mike Bauman

Title: Comment Submitted by Mychal Ortiz
Comment: Great idea! This needs to happen otherwise we risk a security threat.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I agree with passing this proposed rule. We need to prepare for the worse case scenario to ensure the best case scenario occurs.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I appreciate the zone of security because it's protecting our Miami-Dade County from hostile attacks during our city's time of hosting the Superbowl 2020.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This is a good idea - appreciate the increased security for this event.

Title: Comment Submitted by John Doe
Comment: It is important to communicate whether private parties will be allowed access in the security zone during the duration of the Superbowl, and any time before or after as well.

Title: Comment Submitted by Safama S., George Mason University
Comment: I agree to the Coast Guards propping to establishing a temporary security Zone over the Biscayne Bay when the Superbowl is being held in Miami Florida in 2020. I think its a great idea to be cautious and have high tech security for such a big event. Because there are so many football fans who will be traveling from different parts of the country or even local states.  Its really important to know whats going on or be careful of your surrounding and if you see anything suspicious make sure to report it.  I really like the fact that zone of security will be protecting the Miami Dade county from terrorist attacks or any type of attacks that can distract or put people in risk or danger during the time of the biggest porting event. So this passing of this rule is really a good idea and I am grateful to know this is happening knowing Miami is really close to the ocean. This just helps being prepared for the worse case of scenarios to make sure everything and everyone is safe.

Title: Comment Submitted by Christopher Amezcua
Comment: I support the temporary security zone around Bayfront Park in Miami, Florida during the 2020 Super Bowl event. I support this regulation because of recent terrorist attacks on major sporting events and large crowd attendance. High attendance rates can result in specific locations to cause an act of terror among large crowds. For example, the Boston marathon had a high attendance rate and caused around 264 casualties. These large crowds are vulnerable to mass homicides. According to NBC NEWS, Super Bowl 53 had a team of counterterrorism and law enforcement officials prepare for a threat assembly in which they concluded no threat. However, the biggest football game of the year made it a target for terrorist groups. There are no credible terrorist threats to this years game. But its high profile could make it a desirable target. Many sports venues sparked a wake up call after the deadly 9/11 attacks according to athleticbuilding.com. They stated The events of 9/11 proved a wakeup call across the country, prompting individual sports venues to take a closer look at their security policies and driving league- and organization-wide reforms. This wake up call brought more security options like cameras to make sure everything was safe.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jack Darrow
Comment: I feel that this is a very important measure to take. The Super Bowl is one of the most well attended events in the country each year; as a result, ample precautions should be taken to ensure the safety of all involved. I am supportive of any Coast Guard measures that protect the safety of everyone at the event.

Title: Comment Submitted by Lukas Carlson
Comment:
Security Zone; Super Bowl 2020, Bayfront Park, Miami, FL
As a frequent watcher of the Super Bowl I very much support this Security Zone. The Super Bowl is the most watched and anticipated sporting event in the country and that makes it a target for people with ill intentions. The Super Bowl being in Miami so close to the Ocean makes it especially susceptible to attack then it would be if it were in any other stadium. This legislation will be extremely important to the security of the stadium come February.
Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by Ashley White
Comment: I am in full support of the proposed rule to establish a temporary security zone in connection with SuperBowl 2020 in Miami, FL by the U.S. Coast Guard. This year, a temporary flight restriction was put in place in Atlanta, GA for SuperBowl 2019 prohibiting the flight of drones on the date of the event and the three days prior. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) made the airspace around the Mercedes Benz stadium a "No Drone Zone". I believe that any and all safety measures should be put in place for any large event taking place in the United States. The SuperBowl is one of the highest trafficked events as it is the end all be all, for the American football season. South Florida's Sun Sentinel shares that an estimated 65,000 visitors will attend the 2020 game, and another 200,000 will be around the area for "side gatherings". This is a substantial amount of people and an easy target for any types of terroristic threats. As a visitor to several public events including concerts and sporting events, I am in agreement with putting safety measures such as this temporary security zone in place.

Title: Comment Submitted by Savannah Brown
Comment:
After reviewing the proposed rule and researching its planning, implementation and effects, I support the proposal. The Coast Guard and COTP Miami have demonstrated a well thought strategic plan to keep the surrounding communities safe with the large influx of attendees for the Super Bowl. The partnership between the two agencies is striving to achieve a level of security to protect navigable waterways around the city because of the security threat for visitors. The proposed rule addresses how it does not have any significant effect on the small entities in the area as it will only be enforced for a period of eight days. The rule also does not affect traffic through these areas. Mariners are only allowed to travel through instead of anchoring, except for emergencies, thus not impeding traffic patterns. 

I think this is an effective rule because it clearly addresses the authority of the Coast Guard to enforce it while also providing the details of the location and time of the rule. Because it is already being discussed, the public will have extensive notice to prepare any traffic delays or interference with their daily schedules. This proposed rule establishes accountability with the Coast Guard because it has allowed the public to address their concerns and ask questions about the details of the rule.

Title: Comment Submitted by Rachel Morris
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I agree with the proposed rule to enable the U.S. Coast Guard to establish a temporary security zone related to Super Bowl 2020 in Miami, FL.
This is a massive event the entails thousands of individuals in attendance.  Safety needs to be top priority for large events taking place in the United Sates.
Due to these large numbers this may be a target for some type of attack.
As a visitor to public events, I am in agreement with putting safety measures such as this temporary security zone in place.

Title: Comment Submitted by Sarah Treger
Comment: I agree that it is a good idea to use the U.S Coast Guard for a temporary security zone. The super bowl 2020 is of our nations greatest attractions with 98.2 million viewers just on television. Not to mention that if any attack were to happen, the death toll would be so high as well as the emotional damage it will cause to our nation. Using the Coast Guard as a temporary security zone will help comfort the people of the United States.

Title: Comment Submitted by Andrew Creath
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment Submitted by Drew Hobbs
Comment: The protection of these high ranking officials and celebrity's is of the utmost importance with the world we live in today. There are ways for the coast guard to protect the VIP as well as being mindful of the importance. Going by the EPA regulations the coast guard must protect from debris and litter to contaminate the ocean surrounding. They are by Law required to ticket and/ or criminalize this, this must be brought up in the briefing meetings, and must be mindful to regulate it, in order to protect the environment, as well as protecting the people.

Title: Comment Submitted by Genesis Logan
Comment: I agree with the proposed rule that there should be more temporary safety around the parking spaces for the Super Bowl 2020, in Miami, Florida because the Super Bowl is one of the most ancipated events that have been going on in American History for the last century and many more years to come. I feel that in this time and age, that violence is very skyrocket all across the globe and that anything can happened on small events just like this one, with small ill intentions. That why I proposed that this rule for security protection in temporary parking spaces of the Super Bowl 2020 in Miami, Florida.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
USCG-2019-0837

As a member of the public, I think stopping boating and human traffic on this stretch of the river would be beneficial to the public and anyone traveling on or around the river at this time.  Fireworks are large, loud, and distracting displays that can easily draw an individual's attention away from the task at hand.  Distracted boaters and members of the public can cause harm to themselves, others, and the surrounding landscape especially during late hours of the night, in dark and unlit areas, and while operating heavy machinery such as marine vehicles.  Halting travel on the stretch would allow boaters and individuals to observe the fireworks from a safe distance and proceed with business after the displays have stopped.

Title: Comment Submitted by Contract Drilling & Blasting LLC
Comment: Contract Drilling & Blasting LLC should be allowed to engage in their drilling efforts. With a population of roughly 8,000 people(Ketchikan, AK), the Coastal Guard is able to survey and draft an accurate statement as to who would be impacted be the proposed rulemaking. The confirmation from the Coast Guard that very little small-entities would be impacted, along with no realized environmental impacts reflects that the drudging efforts of Contract Drilling & Blasting LLC should granted.

Title: Comment Submitted by Derek Anderson
Comment: I think this proposed rule is a good one. I think it is keeping in mind the welfare of people and the environment. My only question would be what potential impact it has on ships. Are there a lot of ships that are going to be diverted? How will the Captain of the Port choose who can go through and who cannot? Overall, I like the idea of this proposed rule and think it is a good idea, but I also think that these two issues should be addressed before this is put into place.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I agree with this proposed rule because it relates to safety. The safety zone for specific waters of the Tongass Narrows is crucial because it will be establish to protect those who pass along the Tongass Narrows. The length of the scheduled action is around a month and a half which is not an extremely substantial amount of time, especially if this operation is necessary to ensure the safety of others. However, a question that I have is if there is any chance that this operation may be longer than the allotted time? On the other hand, is there any chance that this operation would be shorted than the allotted time? It is imperative to have the use of the safety zone authorized by the Captain of the Port Southeast Alaska, or another official, in order to maintain the safety of that area.

Title: Comment Submitted by Cornell Ousley, Jr.
Comment: I support having a safety zone in these waters. If the point of it is to simply provide better safety for vessels and other life in the area while demolition is ensuing, then this is necessary. Without the announcement of a safety zone, then it is very possible for someone to accidentally get injured  during this process, and that is something that is very avoidable with this act. A detractor to my argument may state, that it is unnecessary to be in the Tongass Narrows to begin with. To that, I would say that once this area has been selected already, and we must make this zone as safe as possible.

Title: Comment Submitted by Luke McGrath
Comment: One thing that I think still needs to be considered when creating this temporary safety zone for explosive dredging is a different kind of environmental effect. In the environment section of the proposal, their is a lot of emphasis on the "human environment" and the "economics environment", both of which will be relatively unaffected by the new regulation. However, I feel that they have not fully considered the impact that the explosives could have on the ecosystem in the area. This body of water alone is a very complex environment where explosives could interrupt a number of organisms. Also the effect on the quality of the water and the potential to effect nearby shorelines should be considered before doing anything. If these different things can be confirmed and there is no major effect on the environment or ecosystem then the regulation should be put in place.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I support closing off the area and turning it into a safety zone. They will start drilling and conducting explosive dredging starting from December 16 to January 31. This could be hazardous for anyone in the area. To stay on the safe side it would be smart to mark off the area as a safety zone. Also according to their background information on regulation it says that it would not be following the new regulation laws if they did not create a safe zone. So I think the proposed rule is a something to consider.

Title: Comment Submitted by Jeff Bezos
Comment: I find this to be a little concerning being that the only thing we are worried about in this situation is human life. It would be a given that humans should not be near the area when explosives are being detonated however, I am relatively concerned with the disregard to plant and animal life and the entire ecosystem itself.  I am not particularly educated on the area however, I am familiar with the process of dredging and its destructive nature for a hopeful benefit to our infrastructure or some economic.  Upon doing some research of the proposed plan I found there were 8 species of marine mammals in the area that were expected to experience disturbances from this.  Past the marine mammals I imagine there is hundreds of marine species in general that will be affected or harmed by the disturbances or inevitable leaking of chemicals into the waterway.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I recommend not using explosives to dredge to better protect wildlife and the environment. I recommend using smaller vessels instead of dredging.

Title: Unrelated Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Just as the Coast Guard capably guards America's coasts, President Tiny Hands feebly guards his polls. In facing the coronavirus crisis he is most concerned about protecting his numbers.

So far this hasn't worked too well. After Trump and Mulvaney hyped the stock market, it fell like a rock. Similarly Trump predicted that the number of coronavirus cases in the US would not exceed 15:

"... you have 15 people, and the 15 within a couple of days is going to be down to close to zero, that's a pretty good job we've done." - President Tiny Hands, Feb 26 2020

Well now there are over 300 cases, but Trump is still doing his best to cook the books. He's pushing for passengers to remain on the Grand Princess cruise ship - because onshore cases don't really count:

"experts... would like to have the people come off. I'd rather have the people stay but I'll go with them. I would rather because I like the numbers being where they are. I don't need to have the numbers double because of one ship that wasn't our fault." - President Tiny Hands

Title: Mass Mail Campaign 1: Comment Submitted by Howard Klug, Total as of 2/26/2020: 26
Comment:
As someone who is concerned about public safety and the economy, I urge you to approve the permit for BNSF Railway to build a new railroad bridge over the Missouri River in Bismarck and Mandan, North Dakota. 



The bridge is more than 100 years old and BNSF says it soon needs to build a new one to continue safely hauling North Dakota's grain and other commodities. 



Keeping the existing bridge in place could create flooding issues, increase costs significantly, and add delays to construction. 



I urge you to approve the permit so that a new bridge can be built soon and the railroad can safely ship goods that our economy relies on.

Title: Comment Submitted by Serena Carlson
Comment:
Freight railroads privately fund maintenance and replacement of their infrastructure, with BNSF Railway typically spending about half their capital expenditures each year on maintenance activities. Constant renewal of infrastructure is important to operating safely across rail networks. 

The railroad bridge over the Missouri River between Bismarck and Mandan, N.D. is private transportation infrastructure that's critical to the state's economy. More than 100 years old, the bridge is approaching the time when it won't be able to safely carry train loads of North Dakota's grain, coal, crude oil, and other industrial products.

As someone who is concerned about public safety and the economy, I urge you to approve the permit for BNSF Railway to build a new railroad bridge over the Missouri River in Bismarck and Mandan, North Dakota. 

The bridge is more than 100 years old and BNSF  needs to build a new one to continue safely hauling North Dakota's grain and other commodities. 

Keeping the existing bridge in place could create flooding issues, increase costs significantly, and add delays to construction. 

The best course is simple: build a new bridge and remove the old one. Keeping the existing bridge in place is problematic. Building a new one next to it could create flooding impacts for private property, and impact Bismarck's water reservoir and a dedicated nature preserve. BNSF's project costs would increase $10 - $75 million and take one to four years longer to construct if forced to keep the old bridge in place.

Action is needed now. For two years, BNSF has been in the permit process. No credible plan has emerged for funding or ownership of the current bridge. BNSF needs to build its planned bridge project without further delay so they can help keep ND's economy on track.

I urge you to approve the permit so that a new bridge can be built soon and the railroad can safely ship the goods upon which our economy relies.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This is one of North Dakota's most iconic landmarks. Losing the bridge would be a tragedy.

Title: Comment Submitted by Nickie Bradbury
Comment: The rail bridge is a cultural anchor in our community. It serves as the icon of our place on the northern plains. People use the image of the bridge to commemorate birthdays weddings family gatherings and other events. Businesses use the bridge in advertising locally and in representing North Dakota to the national business community. It has been the most important piece if architecture in our community for over 100 year since before we became a state. Please make every effort to keep it standing as the symbol of our history.

Title: Comment Submitted by Killian Knapp
Comment: ND doesn't have mountains or forests, and as pretty and the Badlands are, a lot of our visual appeal is based on our historic and interesting architecture. It would be a shame to not preserve and find a new use for this bridge. A walking and/or bike path would be amazing.

Title: Comment Submitted by Kathy Poppke
Comment: I love this Bridge and hope it can be saved. Perhaps repurpose to a bike and walking trail with gardens and plantings. The new Gateway to Science museum is being constructed on the river bluff on the east side. I believe funds , big funds can be raised to preserve and refurbish as needed. Resident born in 1953 in Bismarck. Thank you

Title: Comment Submitted by Ice Man
Comment: Most of ND save for the Badlands is mundane landscape and buildings. The long span bridge & granite peers is an example of old school craftsmanship. If preserved the new bridge would also have to be long span. So the new bridge would also be more astetic.

Title: Comment Submitted by Renae Grimes
Comment: The bridge is a landmark in our community. The concept of it being a walking path is perfect. We already blew up a icon bridge 8 years back it I don't care how safe the project is, our river still get impacted from destruction like this. Even if the bridge isn't a walking path it's still a important icon to us bismarck residents

Title: Comment Submitted by Joel Bismarck
Comment:
Hello,

My name is Joel Land and I am a Bismarckian born and raised. After graduating HS, I went to college in Tennessee in 2007, got married in 2013 and have lived in Chattanooga, TN until last year. I moved my southern wife and our young family back to Bismarck because we believe it is the best place for us to raise our family.

Chattanooga is not dissimilar to Bismarck. It is a city built around a river. It has a growing and thriving downtown. There is a large population of people living there who love outdoor recreation. This city also has a number of bridges that cross the TN river near downtown.

I have attached a picture of my family on the Walnut Street Pedestrian Bridge in Chattanooga, TN from 2018. My parents (Tom & Carol Land) came to visit from Bismarck, ND and we were proud to take them to this gorgeous city attraction. What if we could do the same in our city? Hundreds and thousands of people walk across this bridge every day. It is a hub for locals and tourists alike. *Read more here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walnut_Street_Bridge_(Chattanooga)

Imagine the positive impact on our community and the way it would "bridge" the gap between Bismarck/Mandan. I have seen many positive changes in Bismarck since I moved back, and I strongly desire to see this landmark preserved and put to good use.

Bismarck has amazing things to offer. We can't afford to tear them down.

Thank you for reading,
Sincerely,
Joel Land

Title: Comment Submitted by Joe Burgum
Comment: I'd love to see this bridge saved and turned into a pedestrian and biking path. There are not many pieces of historic architecture in the northern plains of this scale. It would be wonderful to preserve it and elevate its significance.  Roadway and transit access is a critical baseline for commerce and workforce, but most people do not move or open a business in a community because of a new bridge. The opportunity at hand to preserve a significant bridge and turn it into a community amenity is something that people look for when moving to a new city. Outdoor recreation is a top-three factor for workforce retention and attraction.

Title: Comment Submitted by Nicholas Bradbury
Comment:
There is large opportunity for leaders to take positive action in preserving the Railroad's, North Dakota's and our Nation's history by honoring and preserving the existing Historic Bridge where it stands across the Missouri River.

With the 1864 land grant, the Northern Pacific Railway took one of the largest transfers of public land (over 50 million acres) to a private corporation in the history of democratic government. The Northern Pacific Railway has played a key role in westward expansion of the United States in the 19th and 20th Centuries. This includes large-scale infrastructure projects and countless scores of employees and homesteaders. Since the market crash of 1873, the Northern Pacific has capitalized on the government's largess to a grand degree, even spinning off entire new industrial corporations taking advantage of the forest lands of the Pacific Northwest. The legacy of the Land Grant has had indelible impacts on large swaths of the NW United States.

The arrangement has worked out very strongly in the railroad's (and Warren Buffett's) favor of late. With record quarterly profits recently, the railroad is reaping billions and billions of dollars in profit annually from the arrangement established with the government back in 1864, now 156 years ago.

A key feature in the development of the railroad was the arrival of the first trains in Bismarck, North Dakota, in 1873, followed 3 months later by a global financial collapse spawned by the bankruptcy of the Northern Pacific Railroad. For nearly 10 years, westward progress was halted at Bismarck, North Dakota, with the Mighty Missouri River blocking the way. During those 10 years, the US Army remained at this site, with George Armstrong Custer even working in the Railroad's employ performing survey work during this time.

Incredibly, the river presented such a daunting challenge that a tunnel underneath the river was considered more likely for nearly a year prior to settling on the Bismarck-Mandan Rail Bridge as the solution to the problem. This allowed Bismarck to grow large enough to be designated as the Territorial Capital and later to become the state capital. Pressure toward westward expansion was so strong that the first trains across the river were carried by barge and even, in a first-ever action in world history, a never-before-seen act of bravery and hardiness, in 1879 the first trains crossed the Missouri River under their own power on tracks laid directly upon the ice! Crossing the Missouri River by rail remains a monumental accomplishment to this day.

The bridge was built at a very high-profile site in Northern Plains history, the exact site where bison crossed the river on their annual migrations, where Native American tribes had gathered for centuries to hunt the bison, and a major cultural crossroads on the plains. The site was known as "The Crossing", where Native Americans had retreated to cross the Missouri River ahead of General Sibley 20 years earlier after being chased out of Minnesota. Amazingly, the bridge has handsomely withstood the test of time and its hand-carved stone pillars remain a sturdy testament to this history today.

The bridge at this location represents far more than simply one of the most impressive engineering feats of the American Frontier, engineered by George Shattuck Morrison. Construction used methods similar to those used to construct the Brooklyn Bridge in New York, completed the same year as the Brooklyn Bridge. It tells the story of the Northern Pacific Railway better than any other surviving feature of the Road. It is a National Treasure. The parties deciding the fate of this bridge must introduce more of this consideration into the rhetoric surrounding the new construction project. There is large opportunity here for BNSF, the Coast Guard, North Dakota leadership, and local leadership to take positive action in preserving their own and our Nation's history by honoring and preserving the existing Historic Bridge. I am grateful for this opportunity to express my feelings in this instance, as the bridge is THE ICON of the Northern Plains and an anchoring cultural touchpoint in the local community and the state of North Dakota and deserves respect as such.

Title: Comment Submitted by
Comment:
Dear United States Coast Guard,

The Historic Railway Bridge Across the Missouri River is an integral piece of North Dakota's heritage.  In a young state, without a large population density, the urgency of keeping what we have is vital.

The state strives to keep its population health and a good place to raise families, the bridge can be a part of that system.

As a third-generation North Dakotan, my family and I are in 100% support of preserving our heritage by saving this bridge structure for future generations to see and experience.

Dear United States Coast Guard,

The Historic Railway Bridge Across the Missouri River is an integral piece of North Dakota's heritage.  In a young state, without a large population density, the urgency of keeping what we have is vital.

The state strives to keep its population health and a good place to raise families, the bridge can be a part of that system.

As a third-generation North Dakotan, my family and I are in 100% support of preserving our heritage by saving this bridge structure for future generations to see and experience.

Title: Comment Submitted by
Comment:
Greetings, 

I am writing in support of the preservation of the BNSF Railway Bridge. 

Built by the Northern Pacific Railroad Company from 1880-1883, the rail bridge represents the unprecedented industrial expansion of its era. As the first bridge to span the upper Missouri River, it contributed significantly to the growth of the rail roads, now known to be one of the greatest infrastructure projects in American history. 

Built in the same decade has New York City's Brooklyn Bridge, it is deserving of similar preservation and treatment for future generations to marvel at and enjoy. 

Bryan Leininger, Professional Landscape Architect
Fargo, ND

Title: Comment Submitted by
Comment: There are many many people that have very speciual memories of the bridge that was torn down and want this bridge left as part off the wonderful historical structure that it is. What is left? I our Carnegie library is gone, the memorial bridge is gone ,Please keep this bridge .

Title: Comment Submitted by
Comment:
Using the rail bridge would be a wonderful way for the people of Bismarck and Mandan to enjoy a unique walking/biking trail experience.   It would be a fun way to exercise as they take in the immense  beauty of the Missouri River. 

Signage showing the history and construction of the bridge would  be educational and great for school children field trips. They would be able to walk the bridge above the Missouri River which would be so awesome as it is a stunning view.  Many people would walk the route just for the experience. 

It would also be a fantastic addition to the Northern Plains Heritage Area as they highlight and promote the historical aspects of life along our Missouri River. Please let us keep the bridge. Thank you.

Title: Comment Submitted by
Comment: The bridge is an iconic symbol for the city, and could be a valuable recreational asset as well. It would connect the Missouri River Nature Area to the Bismarck trail system in a beautiful and safe pedestrian-friendly manner. This is a huge opportunity for preservation and recreation.  I, personally, would use it all the time. But I could see this being a financial asset to the community too as it could invite additional opportunities for running and trail racing.

Title: Comment Submitted by Cole Bernhardt
Comment:
Please give strong consideration in helping our community save and preserve this historic bridge for future generations to enjoy. This bridge is emblematic of our community. Its image appears in the vast majority of advertisements and branding for both private industry of the region and the city in general. Its historical significance is a centerpiece for the region and the western expansion of the nation.
On a personal note, I can say that myself as well as countless others in the community would be heartbroken to see this bridge fall into the river. Please help us retain this amazing structure and priceless piece of history.

Thank you,
Cole E. Bernhardt
Bismarck ND - lifelong resident

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymouc
Comment:
The bridge should be saved. It's historic, it's iconic, state of the art technology was used when constructing it. Workers would get decompression sickness if not for the airlocks. Seattle and the the West wouldn't of been accessible without this bridge. I heard it would cost an additional 30-50 million dollars to keep. That is nothing to the multi billionaire - Oracle of Omaha, Warren Buffett. Bismarck-Mandan is up and coming, we need more river front walking paths and things to do on our community.  Please take 11 minutes of your time to watch the attached video.

Thank you-

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FO_-qTF_DoM

Title: Comment Submitted by Austin Schmidt
Comment:
The Bismarck-Mandan Rail Bridge deserves to remain an icon in the community because it holds a piece of regional history. The bridge was a gateway staple in the Railroads expansion westward and would not have been possible without the bridge over the MO River. Aside from Indigenous people in the region beforehand, the cities of Bismarck and Mandan would not have been. Recognized as a site of conscience due to its impacts in white settlement and Native American communities, the bridge has become more than a piece of regional history but US history.

Being built in 1883, the bridge predates the Brooklyn Bridge in NYC/Brooklyn, making it one of the oldest historical figures in the Midwest. As the bridge connects Bismarck-Mandan through rail line; converting the bridge has a pedestrian trail that has been proven feasible by study, as well as providing both communities a better way of life. Trails more specifically rail to trails have been proven to increase happiness and healthiness within local communities.

The residents of both Bismark-Mandan are pleading with you, PLEASE do the right thing and save the bridge.

Title: Comment Submitted by Cheryl Schmidt
Comment: I think the bridge that is used by Burlington Northern crossing over from Mandan to Bismarck should be left.  If the railroad does not want to continue the use of it, then another use should be looked at.  This bridge is a link between the communities along with a historical appearance.  History artifacts seem to get replaced too often and beauty is lost.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: The Bismarck-Mandan Rail Bridge is a monument to upper the Midwest and is an iconic figure in architecture to this state I call home. It would be a tragedy to witness this unique space destroyed while there is so much opportunity for it. Professionals, yes even in the state of North Dakota, study and design for spaces just like this. A monument re-purposed is the exact architecture we need. This site gives hope to the people and therefore not only connects two cities together, it can connect people to the space and experience this bridge deserves. Please, let us young design professionals experience something innovating to design in our state.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: This bridge is an important part of our local history as well as the country's. Conversion to a trail system would be excellent and greatly benefit the Bismarck-Mandan area

Comment: See attached file(s)
