Title: Comment Submitted by Chuck Fetters
Comment: Would be nice if you bothered to mention in what state these stations are.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I recommend we make any redundant stations marine sanctuaries and definitely not allow any development or real estate greedy hands on this property. This property must remain in public hands and for public enjoyment only.

Title: Comment Submitted by Brett Sause
Comment:
Rear Admiral Sibley, 

I am responding with comments regarding the Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations.  I am an active yachtsman and a USCG Master Licensed Captain on the Chesapeake Bay. I have been boating the Chesapeake for over 46 years. 

This news is both shocking and what I believe to be a hazard to the marine community of the Chesapeake Bay.  The town of Oxford, first and foremost, love the Oxford USCG Station. Next, the Tred Avon River, as well as its immediate surrounding tributaries, are some of the most highly traveled and worked waters on the Bay and in North America.   

The need for emergency resources on the Bay is critical.  The Maryland Dept of Natural Resources Police has limited crews and duty stations. There is often no crew on duty in the area you need them when an emergency may arise, due to the vast size of the Bay. This, of course, slows the response time to any emergency. So then the public must rely on the Volunteer Fire companies and the USCG.  If we take away the Oxford Station, this makes a significant impact on the mariners of our Bay, which will include imports and exports on the Bay, the shipping industry,  and also Maryland Watermen.  An estimated 3,000 men and women brave the elements daily to catch their respective limits and sell to the markets.  

As you know our current stations include: Boat Stations
Annapolis
Crisfield
Curtis Bay
STA (Small) Stillpond
Ocean City
Oxford
St. Inigoes
Washington
This span between the stations is incredibly vast. The next closest station to Oxford would be Annapolis.  The response time would be tremendous. A decision to remove the Oxford Station in great tragedy.  

I hope you will reconsider.  

Respectfully,

Capt. Brett M. Sause 
USCG Master

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Keep Station Shark River open. Back waters. Fast on scene rescue needed.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Close these stations.  Close many more that aren't needed because boats have engines now and the Coast Guard has helicopters.  Send the people saved by closing these stations to conduct the grossly understaffed Marine Safety mission.

Title: Comment Submitted by Angie Hengst
Comment:
Rear Admiral Sibley,

I am providing comment on the Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations, in particular concerning the proposed closing of the Oxford Station. My name is Angie Hengst and I am the Race Director of the two IRONMAN triathlons in Cambridge, IRONMAN 70.3 Eagleman which takes place in June and IRONMAN Maryland which takes place in September. Both of our events secure a Marine Event Permit from the Coast Guard and since the events' inception, we have relied on the resources and personnel from the Oxford Station to provide support during the swim portion of both of our events (1.2 mile and 2.4 mile swim for each race, respectively). Our Eagleman event has upwards of 2500 participants and IRONMAN Maryland has close to 2300 participants. As you can imagine, having that many people in the water and keeping them safe requires many resources. While we have rescue boats, lifeguards and other swim safety personnel to monitor the swimmers, the Oxford Coast Guard monitor boat traffic and keep our swim course secure during the event. They will also provide any backup emergency response, if needed. The Station personnel report to our swim course and are in place by 6am for each of our races. If this station was closed, personnel from stations over an hour to two hours away would need to arrive at this time to support our events. Additionally, the Oxford station is very familiar with our waters and courses and are able to provide the exact support needed to keep our event and participants safe. While I understand these events only happen twice a year, the number of participants is significant. We have several All Agency meetings prior to the event and the Station's close proximity to Cambridge allows them to easily attend these meetings and work closely with other local agencies and IRONMAN staff prior to the event. I believe that closing the Oxford Station could negatively impact our event and on behalf of IRONMAN would urge that it's consolidation be reconsidered.

Thank you,
Angie Hengst
Race Director
IRONMAN 70.3 Eagleman
IRONMAN Maryland

Title: Comment Submitted by Nolan P.
Comment:
The consolidation of U.S. Coast Guard station sites has both positive and negative attributes. For one, the consolidation would most likely increase efficiency regarding communication between those in distress and the U.S. Coast Guard, as calls would be directed to a singular site within a given region. In addition, as mentioned in the summary, there are fewer distress calls compared to that of the past, due to an increase in boating technology and safety. This, of course, creates less of a demand for a large quantity of coast guard stations. Consolidation would also prove to be a great financial benefit for the U.S. Coast Guard, as the funds saved from closing the five U.S. Coast Guard stations could then be used to update current technology or increase the number of personnel on-site. 

On the opposite end of the spectrum, although our boating technology has increased over the years, a larger quantity of U.S. Coast Guard stations would ensure that emergency situations may be reached at a faster rate. Although more stations involve a "complicated response system," when on the water, time is crucial. Additionally, if these stations were to be shut down, there are externalities that can affect the surrounding community. The stations that were shut down hold the potential to fall into decay if not immediately sold, creating a public nuisance. 

In conclusion, I believe that the U.S. Coast Guard should begin consolidation one station at a time instead of five. This action would provide a sample for what the larger impact might be on both the community and the response times for emergency situations. Once the trial period is over, I believe that a decision to close the remaining stations can then be made.

Title: Comment Submitted by Thomas Bixler
Comment:
Oxford Bellevue Ferry
(Established in 1683)
27456 Oxford Rd
Oxford, MD 21654
410-745-9023

March 12, 2020
Re: [Docket Number USCG-2020-0042]

Rear Admiral Sibley
United States Coast Guard
c/o regulations.gov 

Dear Admiral Sibley,

     I am responding to your request for comments on the Consolidation of Redundant Coast Guard Boat Stations.  I am the owner/operator of the oldest privately operated ferry, Established in 1683 and have been a USCG 100 Ton Master for 48 years.  

     The news of the Oxford Station being on the list for closure would be a terrible mistake and a hazard to the mid bay safety to the many recreational and commercial mariners who ply the waters daily.  The current central location in this heavily utilized section of the bay lends great support to the overall safety of our area.  While there are other assets available thru the Maryland DNR and local volunteer fire departments, they are not manned full time and of course it is well noted the volunteer departments are suffering from severe manpower shortages.  All the well-known short comings, contribute to the delayed response times, which may have catastrophic consequences.  The distance to the Annapolis Boat Station is over 25 miles and the response times due to weather and crew availability can quickly become extended.

     Please reconsider the Oxford Station closure in view of the long-term negative impact on the Chesapeake Mariner community. 

Very truly yours,
Captain Tom Bixler
Owner Oxford Bellevue Ferry

Title: Comment Submitted by Jonathan Fuller
Comment:
Hello,

Please reconsider the closing of the Fishers Island, NY Coast Guard Station.  The station is located only a short distance from Race Rock Lighthouse, which is in the most treacherous waters of Long Island Sound.  On any given weekend during fishing season, there are as many as 60 boats fishing in that area.  Countless others boat through that passage year-round.  The waters flow extremely fast in that location and make it very dangerous.  The Fishers Island Coast Guard Station is needed to protect lives and rescue people who run into problems there.  I have had problems in the past at that location.  I was able to self help, but it's comforting to know that the station is less than a mile from such a dangerous waterway.  Please do not close the Fishers Island Coast Guard Station.  

Thank you,
Jon Fuller

Title: Comment Submitted by Anthony Soltys, CT/RI Coastal Flyfishers
Comment: The station at Silver Eel should remain in operation. It is close to the Race a really dangerous body of water on the tip of Fishers Island. Response there to the many commercial, USN submarines,fisherman and sailors who might get in trouble must be quick to be effective. The Fishers Island station makes a quick response possible and therefore should be kept in operation.

Title: Comment Submitted by Fred Conti
Comment:
On behalf of the hundreds and perhaps thousands of recreational fisherman who fish the waters of the Race in Long Island Sound, I respectfully object to the closing of the Coast Guard Station Fishers Island. My objection is solely based on the issue of safety of the recreational fishermen who ply these waters. 
The maximum flood and ebb tide velocity in the Race exceeds 4 knots. The resultant rip tides make survival of boaters experiencing an emergency extremely difficult. Any excessive delay in providing assistance could prove fatal.
Maintaining the Fishers Island Station is essential to the safety of the many boaters who transit this extremely dangerous body of water.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: Proposing this rule of having temporary regulations on the water between the Bill Burton Fishing Pier State Park beach and the Dorchester County Visitors Center beach is in the best interest of safety to the participants and non-participants of this open water swim. Swimmers and operators would not need to worry about safety concerns with the help of safety kayaks and boats through this channel that contains multiple public and private facilities along both shorelines. Minimizing the number of vessels passing through this channel over the course of four hours may also decrease any potential discharge on the surface of the water that participants would swim through. My only concern is how close the participants are swimming to the fishing piers, would there also be a four hour pier fishing restriction for the safety of the participants? For this short amount of time and small portion of the Choptank River, I do not see a large negative environmental impact. Possibly, non-participants could be encouraged to pick up any litter they see while walking the shoreline and piers watching the swimmers, this could promote a positive environmental impact.

Title: Comment Submitted by Marissa Hill
Comment: As long as the people of that area are given notice prior to this event happening, I believe that it is perfectly plausible for a submission from Coast Guard is appropriate.

Title: Comment Submitted by Adam Bradley
Comment:
As a sailor and spectator of these events I have seen how not having specific zone effects the event. Also having zones that address the needs of all participating in the event. From the racers to the spectators and the general public who are boating separately. Not allowing other boats to operate during events can have a negative on the event, an event that is trying to increase the number of sailing events for everyone to watch.

(v) Zone "D" means the No Spectating or Loitering Area. This zone will allow vessels to transit in and out of marinas, piers, and vessel launch areas throughout the duration of the Sail Grand Prix. All vessels shall maintain headway and shall not loiter or anchor within the confines of Zone "D". Mariners can transit Zone "D" during the Sail Grand Prix 2020 event, decreasing the impact of the special local regulation to the San Francisco waterfront.

Having section (v) inplace helps inform how the general public is meant to navigate during the event. Without this, others might navigate their normal ruites without knowing the impact.

Thank you for providing a well thought out regulation.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: As a frequent sailor in SF Bay, I am pleased that Sail GP has returned. However, as a frequent kiteboarder at Crissy Field, I must object to the extreme length in time of the exclusion period. Preventing access between 11:30 am and 5:30 pm effectively bans kiteboarding from Crissy field, one of the few good access points to kiteboarding on the bay, on those days. With Sail GP's stated goal of 20 minute races, and 3 races a day, I must request that the closure be shortened, perhaps to 150-180 minutes. This would seem to still allow plenty of time for the sailboat racing, while still allowing residents access to the waters near their home.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I am opposed to any restrictions beyond 3 pm especially just to monetize a possible international viewing opportunity.

For sailors of all kinds, the waters offshore of Crissy Field in San Francisco are one of the wonders of the world. There are literally dozens of races held there each year, from the iconic Big Boat series, to the more prosaic Thursday and Friday night kiteboard and windsurf races. The waters are used by many others, including paddle boarders for their iconic race to Ocean Beach, outrigger canoes, kayaks, and fishing boats. Most of these activities occur without disruption to other users, relying on common courtesy and the right-of-way rules of the water to allow users to participate simultaneously. Only a few eventsAmerica's Cup, Fleet Week, and SailGP seek restrictions on other users.

The right of access to the water is so important in California that it is enshrined in the State Constitution. California has taken a number of steps to assure that access is protected, from establishing the nation's first coastal program to adopting legislation to encourage development of a Water Trail. Crissy Field has been designated under the Bay Plan as an important recreational beach where access for windsurfing is protected, and has also been designated as a Water Trail site.

Title: Comment Submitted by Joachim Pfeiffer
Comment: For many years, events such as two seasons worth of America's Cup races and practices, the annual SFYC Rolex regatta, outrigger events and numerous small sailboat regattas have co-existed with windsurfers, kiteboarders and others launching at Crissy Field / East Beach without much detriment to either side. I consider this a track record that should serve as a model for large events such as SailGP, which provided substantial benefits to commercial events while minimizing negative impacts to the local sailing community. Even the extraordinarily high-profile America's Cup avoided large take-over style exclusion zones by maintaining passing channels nearshore for small craft, and limiting exclusions to around 3pm PST. I want to encourage the US Coast Guard to inform decision making on SailGP exclusion zones and times accordingly. Sincerely, Joachim Pfeiffer, San Francisco

Title: Comment Submitted by Maxim Sokolov
Comment: As a kite foil racer I understand desire to restrict access to the area during competitions, but after 3pm seems excessive and unduly burdens other users. California has laws to protect access to the water and we should respect them.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
Allow windsurfing, kite-boarding and general access from East Beach Crissy field  - IIRC even the AC for two seasons worth of races kept a channel open on the inside for small craft to pass, and were done by 3 pm anyhow.

It's a pretty obvious tactic at the end of the day SailGP: Ask for the sky, and see what falls from it. If they can inch something out that way, hey, they can still chalk up a win while claiming how they'd given all these #faux concessions.
I take it that all this is going to have to go through the process with the powers. Other than that I am inclined to think the proposal in front of us should be dismissed off-hand and replaced with something that mirrors what regattas were doing in the past and that was agreeable to all parties involved.


No closure after 3 pm.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment: I am opposed to any restrictions beyond 3 pm especially just to monetize a possible international viewing opportunity.

Title: Comment Submitted by Anonymous
Comment:
I windsurf crissy field regularly over the past 25 years and want water access after 3pm.
Thanks you.
